text:
They don’t call CNN the Clinton News Network for no reason. The network has long been seen as a loyal supporter of the former president, always ready to shield her from scrutiny and suppress any damaging information. During a heated debate on the air, CNN’s Chris Cuomo — brother of New York’s governor — clashed with one of Donald Trump’s top advisors, Boris Epshteyn. Cuomo insisted that Trump should address the birther controversy just as Hillary Clinton faced consequences for her private email server. “With Hillary, she had to take responsibility for the server,” Cuomo said. “It was a mistake. People around her said it was wrong, that she shouldn’t have done it, that it was poorly handled. But it wasn’t enough. Why?” Epshteyn countered that the situations were not comparable. “There’s no comparison. Hillary Clinton broke the law.” Cuomo pushed back, asking if James Comey was also lying. Epshteyn replied that Comey had stated there was a case to be made. “He said she was careless, and as a lawyer, he believed there was a basis for prosecution,” he said. Cuomo denied this, claiming Comey had said there was no case. “He said it wasn’t even close,” Cuomo insisted. “But the FBI director himself said that mishandling classified information is a felony — whether intentional or grossly negligent. Isn’t that exactly what Hillary did? Comey called her ‘extremely careless’ — which means gross negligence. And let’s not forget she had over a dozen personal devices along with her private server, which stored classified material.”

You can gain a big advantage in a street fight just by mastering head movement! If you can dodge your opponent's strikes, you stay protected and force them to exhaust themselves… once they're tired, winning becomes much easier.

What's behind the News Media's silence on the recent violent attacks in our cities? I only found out about the shootings and explosions through a viral post online. You'd expect these incidents to be front-page news across all major networks, wouldn't you? Maybe there's a video circulating that's influencing the events. I'm certain Hillary Clinton wants you to think Donald Trump is directly responsible for this surge in extremism in the U.S. She's been hinting at it pretty clearly. These attacks can't possibly be linked to Obama's immigration failures—oh no, the very same policies that Hillary plans to push forward without hesitation. It's possible the media is downplaying the stories to avoid casting any suspicion on Crooked Hillary. CNN, MSNBC, CBS, ABC, NBC, and even FOX would never be used as a tool to support Crooked Hillary, right? What kind of un-American person would question the honesty of today's media? Where has our country gone? The news we're shown now feels like propaganda, similar to what people in the old Soviet Union were forced to watch. They twist the facts just enough to trick the public, mixing in some truth to make it believable. Pure deception. Anyone with common sense can see through this.

The Democratic push to hold the IRS commissioner accountable for…something… backfired dramatically when Republicans, offended by being dragged into a partisan spectacle, turned the tables. During IRS Commissioner John Koskinen’s testimony, Republicans tried to focus on the so-called “impeachment” of the agency, but Democrats seized the moment to dig deeper into Donald Trump’s financial misconduct, including his refusal to release tax returns and allegations of tax evasion. A key point of contention was Trump's claim that he can't release his returns because they're under audit. Tax experts have consistently dismissed this excuse, pointing out that an audit doesn’t prevent someone from sharing their records with the public before an election. The IRS chief, who should know better, confirmed this. “Is there anything preventing someone from releasing their tax returns if they want to during an audit?” asked Rep. Jerry Nadler. “No,” Koskinen replied. Another Democrat rephrased the question: “Would releasing the returns interfere with the audit process?” “Not directly,” Koskinen said. “But taxpayers sometimes worry that making information public could lead to more scrutiny or discoveries.” In short, Trump is likely afraid that releasing his taxes might expose something damaging — or let journalists uncover more dirt that the IRS missed. This aligns with what Trump’s son once told reporters, suggesting that it’s not the audit itself that worries him, but the possibility of revealing incriminating details. It may be why Trump has hinted at waiting until after the election to release his returns — though it would be too late by then. As the hearing continued, Democrats pressed Koskinen on potential issues in Trump’s finances, such as his real income, actual tax payments, net worth, and charitable activities. Rep. Zoe Lofgren questioned whether Russian money could have influenced Trump’s policies. Others brought up reports of Trump using his tax-exempt foundation to buy art, fund campaigns, and cover business costs. “Is it ethical for a charity to make political donations?” asked Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee. The answer was no. Rep. Luis Gutierrez, chewing on Skittles during the session, seemed to enjoy the Republican discomfort, referencing Trump Jr.’s recent comment comparing refugees to poisoned candy. He later joked that he wouldn’t stop eating them even if one was bad. It was a tough day for GOP lawmakers. The IRS commissioner was caught in a Republican-led impeachment effort over alleged IRS bias against conservative groups. The problem?

During a Republican primary debate in September 2015, then-candidate Donald Trump claimed he never sought support from Florida Governor Jeb Bush for casino expansion, saying, “He would’ve given it to me if I wanted it.” But if that’s true, then Trump may have committed another serious legal violation—this time for lying under oath in a civil court deposition, which is considered perjury, as reported by *Newsweek*. One of these accounts is clearly fabricated—a self-serving story designed to protect his image. Unlike the many falsehoods he has spread, this one reveals a pattern: Trump fabricates stories when he doesn’t want to admit he lost. Assume the debate statement is the lie. Even though Bush’s version aligned with what Trump had been saying at rallies—that he played the “money for favors” game for years—he couldn’t admit he had tried the same in Florida because he couldn’t bring himself to say he had failed. Instead, he looked the American public in the eye and lied. Then he added another boast: His team is so powerful they would have won the casino deal in Florida regardless of Bush’s opposition—if Trump had wanted it. The transcripts below reveal a factual dispute between two candidates, but not just any fact—something both men should have known. After Trump’s failed attempt to push gambling into Florida against the wishes of an anti-gambling Republican governor, he sued a former employee over his own failure. Eichenwald suggests that either Trump lied directly to a former official on live TV (and the moderators let him get away with it), or: Consider the other possibility—that Trump committed perjury during his 2007 testimony. There, he admitted pushing for casino gambling in Florida, but claimed he didn’t get it because he was tricked by Fields. The motive for the false testimony is clear—Trump wants money from someone who stopped working for him, and this story lets him avoid admitting he’s anything less than perfect. Why does this matter? In the 1990s, House Republicans impeached President Bill Clinton for allegedly lying under oath about a personal matter. The media fixated on the Whitewater scandal for years, making it the central issue of the time. Now, Republicans are backing a candidate known for his lies, but unlike his usual fabrications, this one either involved lying to a Florida court under oath (which seems to be a common venue for Trump) or lying to a national audience and his party

Trump once again took to the stage tonight to repeat one of his go-to fear tactics: claiming that crime is spiraling out of control in major American cities. He specifically pointed to Detroit — which he repeatedly called “Obama’s city” — as a prime example of lawlessness and chaos. However, the reality is that crime rates across all categories have been steadily dropping for over 15 years. While there has been a slight rise in homicides in some urban areas recently, this increase is not statistically significant when compared to past decades. In fact, Detroit has seen a consistent decline in crime since the early 2000s. Although there has been a recent uptick in murder rates, this year’s numbers still fall far below the more than 600 murders recorded during the early Bush era, let alone the over 1,000 annual killings in the 1990s. Under President Obama, Detroit experienced its lowest levels of violent crime in decades. This trend mirrors national patterns, as violent crime has been on a clear downward trajectory since the 1990s. Despite these facts, Trump continues to weaponize fear and misinformation to rally his base. During last night’s debate, he once again used the classic rhetoric of an authoritarian figure: “We need law and order.” And as always, Trump shows no concern for the truth when it conflicts with his agenda.

When Donald Trump proposed a temporary ban on Muslim immigration until we understand the threat, every Democrat and liberal commentator screamed that it was discriminatory. But they were—and still are—completely mistaken. Racism is the belief that one race is superior to another based solely on skin color. Islam, however, is a religion that has been exploited by extremists who carry out suicide bombings in crowded places, convinced they will be rewarded with 72 virgins in paradise. The real danger lies not with those calling for caution, but with those who ignore the reality of radicalization. After witnessing global instability, Trump sought a pause on Muslim immigration until we can secure our borders against terrorist infiltration. Democrats, however, believe the world will support their stance, which is simply not true.  

A recent survey revealed that 48% of voters support a national discussion on the topic, with two-thirds of Australians agreeing that populist politician Pauline Hanson raises issues that others avoid. The main concerns were fears of terrorism and the belief that Muslim immigrants don’t assimilate or embrace local values. The poll was conducted twice to confirm its accuracy. So, Australians want to protect their culture? That’s nothing new—every nation does the same. Yet, when Trump says “America first,” it's suddenly racist. That logic doesn’t hold.  

Sixty percent of Coalition supporters back an end to Muslim migration, along with 40% of Labor voters and 34% of Green voters. The pollster was stunned by the results, admitting that what he once called the “basket of deplorables” is now too large to dismiss. He wrote, “This isn’t a fringe group outside of polite society—it’s 49% of the population.” While they’re more likely to support the Coalition or independent candidates, 40% of Labor voters and a third of Greens also agree. These people are in your office, on your street, on your train—people who disagree with the mainstream narrative.  

Hillary, this is how you should respond to those who oppose you: not by labeling them “deplorables,” but by acknowledging that half the country stands against you. Let’s get this done in November. (Source: Breitbart)

Update: According to a recent report, our account of the incident and the individuals involved has been labeled misleading by a well-known news outlet. We have thoroughly refuted their allegations. You can read our detailed response here. ~~~ You really can't make this up. In the past, people would share wild tales, but there was no real way to verify if they were true. Then came video. This is definitely one of the most shocking things I've ever seen. These individuals were in the middle of the street, and it looked like a confrontation was about to happen. After all, fights are always more intense when they take place on a busy road. Suddenly, someone throws a firebomb at them. LIGHTS. THEM. ON. FIRE. And they're running around in the middle of traffic, completely panicked, risking getting hit by a car. Pure madness, and easily one of the worst things I've witnessed since the O.J. Simpson trial. What kind of twisted mind would think — hey, now's the perfect time to set these people on fire? Yeah, let's just throw that flaming bottle over there and watch them burn. Who even carries the materials for a Molotov cocktail? Was this planned? It's not like I keep those ingredients lying around unless it's for a fancy drink on a weekend. Back in the old days, when people were more responsible and society was better, things would have been different. If two people were about to fight in the street, the decent folks would step in to protect them from traffic and ensure the fight stayed fair. That was when people had more sense and cared about each other. Now, everyone grabs their phone and turns a minor issue into a viral disaster just for likes and views. No one cares anymore. It's time to start caring about people and stop setting them on fire.

To anyone watching last night’s debate, it was obvious that Donald Trump outperformed Hillary Clinton. Sure, Hillary is a seasoned politician, but Trump clearly exposed her inconsistencies in front of a national audience. Despite this, CNN tried to spin the narrative by releasing biased polling data that suggested Clinton had the upper hand. According to Infowars: A CNN/ORC poll released right after the debate claimed Hillary Clinton won the showdown against Trump. The issue? The survey had 43% Democrats and only 25% Republicans. When asked, “Who did better in the debate — Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump?” 64% picked Hillary, while 26% chose Trump. This immediately painted the picture that Clinton dominated the exchange and fueled the media's story that Trump had a poor performance. However, 31% of respondents were Independents, 43% were Democrats, and just 25% were Republicans — a 18% gap between the two major parties. That means the poll was skewed heavily toward Democratic voters before even asking who won. Nearly three-quarters of those surveyed weren’t Republicans, and there were 68% more Democrats than Republicans in the sample. If the numbers were reversed — 43% Republicans and 25% Democrats — the results would likely have favored Trump. You get the idea…Donald absolutely crushed Hillary in the debate!

When Republicans chose a candidate who vowed to stop pandering to the wealthy, they had no idea their presidential pick would actually hand power over America’s most important government agencies to the same elite billionaires. Reports suggest that Donald Trump is considering naming energy mogul Rebecca Hart as Secretary of the Interior, breaking the decades-old tradition of selecting officials from rural Western states to oversee the management of national parks, public lands, and wildlife. This move could be catastrophic for environmental protection, especially regarding the Endangered Species Act, climate change mitigation, and animal welfare, as Rebecca Hart has a history of opposing regulations that limit industrial exploitation of natural resources. According to The Daily Beast, Hart, who owns a large energy company and sits on Trump’s economic advisory board, has funded organizations that attack animal rights groups like the ASPCA and oppose restrictions on factory farming, hunting, and animal entertainment. A source close to the transition team confirmed that Hart was among a small group of candidates under consideration for the role, which has drawn attention from influential anti-environmentalists. In a clear sign of the administration's potential corruption, it was also reported that Trump’s daughter Ivanka is being seriously considered for a top position in the Department of the Interior. The Interior Department controls 28% of U.S. land, oversees national parks, forests, and federal wildlife services, and plays a key role in regulating tribal gaming and mineral leasing on public lands. Its decisions impact everything from oil drilling to water rights, making it one of the most powerful agencies in the federal government. The National Wildlife Federation has raised alarms about the implications of Trump’s selection: “Putting an energy magnate in charge of our public lands and coastal areas is a direct threat to the environment and a promise that drilling will expand dramatically if he wins.” Hart has previously worked against legislation aimed at curbing factory farming practices and has supported policies that weaken animal protection laws. It's alarming to see how Trump is offering high-profile government roles to figures whose agendas directly contradict the public interest. If the options are either a corporate-backed oil executive who sees nature as a resource to be exploited or a privileged, far-right figure with a taste for violence and destruction, it's hard not to wonder if this is all staged. But make no mistake — Trump is dead serious, and his plans pose a real danger to the future of the country.

Trump once again took to the stage tonight to repeat one of his go-to fear tactics: claiming that crime is spiraling out of control in major American cities. He specifically pointed to Chicago — a city he repeatedly called “Obama’s home” — as evidence of a violent crisis. However, the reality is that crime rates across all categories have been steadily dropping for over 15 years. While there has been a slight increase in homicides in some urban areas recently, this rise is not statistically significant when compared to past decades. In fact, Chicago's crime levels, both violent and non-violent, have been on a downward trend since around 2001. Although there has been a recent uptick in murders, this year’s numbers still fall well below the 700-plus killings recorded during the early Bush era, let alone the nearly 1,000 annual murders seen in the 1990s. Under President Obama, Chicago experienced its lowest murder and violent crime rates in decades. This decline mirrors national patterns, with violent crime across the country dropping sharply since the 1990s. Despite these clear trends, Trump continues to weaponize fear and misinformation to rally his base. During last night’s debate, he echoed a familiar authoritarian refrain: “We need law and order.” For Trump, facts are simply obstacles to his agenda of division and deception.

Hillary Clinton was widely hailed as the victor of last night’s debate by major news outlets, yet social media sentiment told a different story. The #TrumpWon hashtag quickly gained traction and became the top trending topic across Twitter. As of now, #TrumpWon is the number one trend in the U.S.—thanks! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 27, 2016. What's surprising isn't just the trend itself, but its origin. According to Trendsmap.com, the #TrumpWon hashtag first appeared in Saint Petersburg, Russia—home to a network of state-sponsored cyber-trolls working under Putin's direction as part of a broader disinformation strategy called dezinformatsiya. This is a well-known tactic used to stir up public unrest, deepen political divides, and undermine trust in democratic institutions. Russian operatives have previously been caught flooding American platforms with pro-Trump content, while Russian media has actively promoted him to European audiences. Putin’s goal is clear: he wants a Trump presidency that could ease the economic pressure on his allies and allow for greater Russian influence in Eastern Europe. Former trolls who worked in these operations described their environment as highly controlled and stressful, with strict quotas and harsh penalties for non-compliance. They worked in small groups under constant supervision, with little autonomy and minimal pay. So next time you see a viral hashtag or online poll, think twice—what you're reading might just be the work of a low-paid internet worker in a dimly lit room, trying to make ends meet.

The white man was likely there for work, or visiting someone, but that doesn’t matter. The Black Lives Matter crowd has no interest in working or contributing. They’d rather spend their time causing chaos, looting, and attacking innocent people whenever a cop shoots someone. This particular incident has nothing to do with the death of Keith Lamont Scott or any other black person killed by police. Even if a black officer kills a black suspect, it’s still used as an excuse to justify violence. This is what people now call “thug behavior” and it’s disgraceful. Hannity – While many acts of violence have been reported during the Charlotte protests, one particularly disturbing video shows an unidentified man being beaten and dragged across the pavement as he pleads for his life. The attack occurred in the parking garage of a downtown mall. This isn't what it means to be American. It's not about race — it's about choice. There are so many positive black Americans who deserve recognition, but every time riots break out, the good ones get overshadowed by the bad. It's time for the African American community to take responsibility and stop enabling these violent thugs. #CharlotteRiots Man beaten in parking lot begs for mercy. @AC360 @seanhannity @BretBaier Credit:Lenard Bennett (facebook) @ncnaacp pic.twitter.com/YWHEU2UV1n — Libertarian Queen (@LibertarianQn) September 22, 2016  Call out the thugs for their senseless violence. People like those in this video bring shame upon their entire community. Stand up to them and don’t let them define your culture or your identity. There are too many good people in the black community to let a few troublemakers ruin it for everyone. When the good people speak up, real change can happen. Good people will always rise above the thugs. Don’t let the losers hold you back.

Really? Hillary Clinton is now claiming she’s going to fight racism, and she’s beginning with our Police Officers? This woman is out of her mind. I’m speechless at how absurd this is…because it’s just plain ridiculous! She’s making all the wrong moves, trying desperately to gain support. The so-called ‘racism’ problem doesn’t start with Police Officers or white people… This woman has completely lost it. “We need to address the systemic racism, this terrible shooting again, how many more times do we have to see this in America?” she said during an interview on the Tom Joyner Show. Clinton was specifically talking about the police shooting of Terence Crutcher in Tulsa, Oklahoma, insisting he had his “hands up” when he was killed. “This is unacceptable and must be stopped,” she said. Clinton told Joyner that if the African-American community supported her, she would work to prevent racialized police shootings. “Maybe I can speak directly to white people and say, ‘This isn’t who we are,’” she added. “We need to fix policing, tackle implicit bias head-on. Actually Hillary… what we really need is to stop electing divisive, self-serving, corrupt people into the White House… who stir up chaos just to appear as saviors with nonsense like this. She wants this mess, Obama wanted this mess. It's creating a breeding ground for stupidity, and they want the American people to stay ignorant so they can keep controlling everything.”

A Daisy of a New Era  
I’ve seen my share of political tricks, but nothing quite compares to the original "Daisy" ad from 1964—a haunting image of a young girl plucking daisy petals while a nuclear explosion looms in the background. It was a masterstroke of fearmongering, orchestrated by President Lyndon B. Johnson’s campaign to paint his opponent, Barry Goldwater, as a warmonger. The irony? Johnson himself escalated the Vietnam War, making him the very thing he accused Goldwater of being. Today, as history struggles to reconcile Johnson’s legacy, Goldwater is often seen as the victim of a political smear that has since been quietly buried.  

This brings me to our current election cycle. There are whispers that a new "Daisy" ad could be crafted, not to target Trump this time, but to highlight the failures of another candidate—Hillary Clinton. Imagine that same child, picking petals for every misstep in her career. Such a commercial could be devastating to her campaign. Of course, it’s unlikely to ever see the light of day, but rumors suggest some within the Clinton team are considering similar tactics.  

Meanwhile, the media continues to play its part, often burying critical information deep in articles or letting damaging stories fade quickly. This bias is so ingrained that “liberal press” has become an accepted label. As the first debate approaches, the same tired moderators will be in charge, with no real change in their approach. It’s hard not to notice that many of them have shifted their stance, now supporting candidates they once criticized.  

Take, for example, the 2008 primary when Barack Obama called Hillary Clinton “untrustworthy” and “unqualified.” That was before her tenure as Secretary of State and the Benghazi scandal. Now, with her running for president again, those early words seem almost prophetic. Even Michelle Obama’s famous line about “running your own house” still echoes today, though it’s rarely brought up in the mainstream press.  

If only there were a way to reframe the past, to show each petal as a documented failure. It might be more powerful than the original “Daisy” ad, which relied on fear rather than facts.

Terrorism seems to be causing more confusion than fear, I keep hearing the word suspect or suspected every time a bomb explodes in the U.S. or when the phrase Allahu Akbar is shouted during a mass shooting. I heard a Chicago mayor claim that the explosion at the airport had nothing to do with the one in the subway on the same day. I suppose the FBI could take a lesson from this mayor. A reporter on CNN suggested the bomb might have been a gas canister accidentally left in a trash bin. The media will bring in so-called experts and offer countless opinions on something that doesn’t need any explanation other than one simple truth. These extremists are going to destroy us unless we act first. When law enforcement captures or kills one, I don’t care about his background that the news always highlights to create a dramatic story. The only thing that matters is punishing him quickly, without letting him enjoy a comfortable prison life with access to Muslim food, free healthcare, gym facilities, a TV to watch terrorist acts around the world, and a Quran with a prayer mat. Terrorists should be tried within 30 days of capture and given their sentence in the same timeframe. I’m just an average person, and I’d rather form my own views instead of letting the media shape them for me. After all, who wants to be misled?

Police have uncovered some shocking clues in the Chelsea bombing that took place last Saturday. The primary focus of the investigation is on Muslim extremists, who have publicly claimed responsibility for the attack that left 29 people injured. All victims have since been released from the hospital. A second pressure-cooker bomb was discovered hidden in a trash bin just four blocks away from the scene.  

Authorities are still trying to piece together exactly what occurred. So far, three leads have drawn significant media attention:  
Lead #1 – A handwritten note, partially written in Arabic, was found inside the same plastic bag that contained the second device.  
Lead #2 – A mysterious 911 call came in from an unknown male who said, “I saw the explosion down the street. There are more coming.”  
Lead #3 – A Tumblr blog titled ‘I’m the NY Bomber’ surfaced online, claiming to be the manifesto of the individual behind the attack that shook New York City last night. HERE.  

Manufacturing Test Explosives Hi. You’ve probably heard about the explosions in New York City — that was me. These were just preliminary tests, and I know where I messed up. I won’t make the same mistake next time. I did it because I can’t stand how society treats people like me. I’m part of the LGBTQ+ community, and we’re still seen as mentally ill, sinful, or just weird. It’s 2016, and this kind of discrimination is still happening. I won’t sit back while marginalized groups are oppressed. I won’t stand by while racism and bigotry continue to run rampant, especially when it comes to white police officers across the country. I won’t live in a country where a misogynistic, xenophobic, racist, and Islamophobic Republican candidate is even considered for president. Republicans are all privileged, cisgendered white people who don’t deserve to be taken seriously. This isn’t the end — it’s only the beginning. I will be remembered. I will make a change. I will take out my targets before it's too late. Someone is lying, and it's disgusting that anyone would try to claim this, especially someone who wasn’t even involved. Using other people's fear for personal gain is the lowest form of betrayal.

Local Charlotte, NC news outlet WSOCTV is reporting that eyewitnesses say dash camera footage shows Keith Scott exiting his vehicle and approaching officers with a weapon in hand: #BREAKING: Eyewitnesses tell Channel 9 dash camera video shows #KeithScott exiting car, walking toward officers with gun in hand pic.twitter.com/GGuM2Ow3wk — WSOCTV (@wsoctv) September 21, 2016  For a second night, protests erupted in Charlotte, North Carolina, following a fatal police shooting, with clashes between demonstrators and law enforcement. Keith Lamont Scott, a father of seven, was shot by police in an apartment complex parking lot Tuesday while officers were searching for a man named in a warrant. The incident sparked hours of unrest, and on Wednesday, the demonstrations continued into a second night, beginning as a peaceful march through downtown Charlotte. As the crowd moved toward an Omni Hotel, some individuals climbed onto the roof of a nearby mall and began throwing objects at the group. Others attempted to break into the hotel, prompting police in full riot gear to intervene. Scott’s family claims he was unarmed and seated in his car reading a book, waiting for his son to return from school. However, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Chief Kerr Putney stated that Scott left his vehicle with a gun, not a book, and that no book was found at the scene. “It’s time for the voiceless majority to speak out,” said the black police chief. “It’s time to reshape the story because I can tell you from the facts that the account so far is not entirely accurate, especially on social media.” – CNN But…b…b…but what about the book? A neighbor who claims to have seen the incident disputes the police department's assertion that Scott was holding a gun. She says he had a book. @wsoctv pic.twitter.com/X1PWw5QJ7O — Mark Barber (@MBarberWSOC9) September 21, 2016    And naturally, Hillary made a controversial tweet blaming the police without any evidence, further inflaming the situation: Keith Lamont Scott. Terence Crutcher. Too many others. This has got to end. -H — Hillary Clinton (@HillaryClinton) September 21, 2016

Hillary Clinton seized the opening presidential debate of the general election cycle to aggressively confront Donald Trump, provoking him on issues like his financial history, tax practices, gender attitudes, racial rhetoric, business ethics, and personal integrity. If Clinton was seeking a showdown, she certainly got one. Her sharp tone drew Trump into several heated exchanges, where he revealed moments of frustration that reflected both public discontent and his more abrasive public image. The debate featured several intense moments, with Trump’s tone growing increasingly pointed. “She doesn’t look the part,” Trump remarked toward the end. “She doesn’t have the strength.” At times, Trump seemed unsettled, especially as the discussion progressed. However, his primary criticisms of Clinton were based on policy, as he aimed to represent the frustrations of voters not only with Clinton but with the political establishment as a whole. “You’ve been in power for 30 years — why are you only now coming up with these solutions?” Trump asked during a segment on job creation. “I’ve thought about this a lot,” Clinton replied. “Yeah, for 30 years,” Trump shot back. Trump distorted facts and questioned Clinton's character, though he largely maintained his composure. Throughout the debate, Clinton addressed Trump by his first name, while he consistently called her “Secretary Clinton” and made it clear he was fine with that. “I want you to be very comfortable. It’s important to me,” Trump said, once again challenging fact-checkers. Trump faced his most difficult moment when moderator Lester Holt brought up the question of President Obama’s birthplace — specifically why it took Trump until just weeks before the debate to acknowledge it was settled. Trump simply stated, “I say nothing” to those questioning why he pursued the issue for so long. He also falsely claimed Clinton started the birther controversy in 2007, taking credit for ending it. “Just like she can’t bring back jobs, she can’t produce Obama’s birth certificate,” Trump said. Clinton seized on an issue that resonated with African American voters and other members of the Obama coalition. “This can’t be dismissed so easily. He built his political career on this racist lie that our first black president wasn’t a citizen,” she said. “The birther lie was deeply hurtful.” Concerned that Trump might behave more politely, Clinton launched her attacks early, suggesting that his success came from privilege and that he was hiding his tax returns to avoid scrutiny. “Maybe

In the past few days, the long-debated "Birther" claims about former President Barack Obama have resurfaced. This time, it's candidate Donald Trump who is pushing back, insisting that Obama was born in the U.S. — full stop. You know the one: the claim that Obama was actually born in Kenya, making him ineligible for the presidency. This narrative first gained traction during the 2007 and 2008 presidential campaigns, with the Hillary Clinton team subtly hinting at it. In fact, it was not Trump who initially stoked these fires — he just amplified them to new extremes. 

Back in 2007, Hillary’s campaign strategist, Mark Penn, wrote a memo suggesting ways to exploit Obama’s background. He noted that Obama’s “roots to basic American values and culture are at best limited” and advised Clinton to emphasize her own “deeply American” upbringing. He even suggested using flag imagery and repeatedly highlighting her “middle-class” origins in speeches. The goal was to position Clinton as the true representative of American values, contrasting her with Obama.

This is clearly a distraction — a tired old tactic used to shift focus from more pressing issues. After nearly eight years of Obama’s leadership, bringing up this non-issue again feels pointless. But then again, that’s probably the whole idea. Anything to keep the spotlight off the real problems. For more on this, visit www.iPatriot.com. Someone had to say it. Okay, liberals have been saying it for years. CNN (and increasingly, the other news networks) have been fueling anxiety for so long that they've turned into the very thing they claim to oppose. Pope Francis agrees. Echoing Franklin Delano Roosevelt’s famous phrase, “we have nothing to fear but fear itself,” the Pope criticized media that spreads fear. Journalism built on speculation or unverified claims is a form of “violence,” and outlets that generalize entire groups or stir up panic about immigrants are acting irresponsibly, Pope Francis said on Wednesday. Spreading false information is an example of “terrorism, of how you can harm someone with your words,” he stated. “This is especially dangerous for journalists because their words can reach millions and that’s a powerful tool.” Source: Reuters Now, to be fair, Pope Francis was in Spain and addressing Spanish media, which has its own issues with right-wing rhetoric, but I’m sure he hoped his message would cross the Atlantic. After all, CNN often focuses on fear and that’s what has led to the rise of figures like Donald Trump. Crime in the country is actually decreasing. The chance of an American being killed by a terrorist is 1 in 20 million — about the same as being injured by your own household items. Still, Trump, encouraged by CNN, is making Americans terrified: Fear is everywhere, and it's growing. Americans are more anxious than they've been in years, according to polls showing large majorities worried about terrorism and crime, with these numbers rising to levels not seen in over a decade. Every week seems to bring a new incident, whether domestic or international. Mass shootings continue to happen regularly. Protests have disrupted major cities, and some have turned violent. While overall crime may be down, a feeling of chaos remains constant. Source: The Atlantic Sure, that’s about Trump and the Pope wasn’t directly referring to him, but CNN is the fear machine. It lists multiple examples of CNN trying to terrify the public, and if this election and the polls are any indication, they’ve done their job.

According to Barack Obama, what is essential for nations to combat extremism is not a strong determination to crush these enemies through high-tech military campaigns. It is not a steadfast commitment to take the battle to radical ideologies. No, according to Barack Obama, the solution lies in embracing a global governance structure and a readiness to "curb individual liberties."  

Speaking at the United Nations General Assembly on Monday, Obama urged world leaders that our only path forward is to trust international institutions like the UN and to sacrifice some of our autonomy — what he referred to as our "freedom of action." Obama also emphasized that "great powers" such as the U.S. must accept limitations in order to align with the decisions of the global community — a position he admits has drawn criticism back home. “We need to back up our words with actions. The only way we can fulfill the original mission of this organization — to replace conflict with collaboration — is if major nations like ours agree to be bound by rules. I know I’m often attacked in my own country for supporting international agreements and multilateralism, but I believe that limiting our freedom of action, not abandoning our security or interests, will ultimately make us safer.”  

The UN was once seen as a noble effort, but it has long been shown to be ineffective. Its real function seems to be redistributing influence and resources among countries. In this system, the U.S. and similar nations do most of the work while receiving little in return — just criticism, resentment, and a push for collectivist control. Since America elected a leader who puts other nations’ concerns above those of the country he's sworn to protect, we've struggled on the world stage. It’s no surprise that this president continues to promote a one-world order and restrictions on personal freedoms. Do you remember when American leaders stood firm in their belief in the American model, insisting that other nations should aspire to our values rather than the other way around?

Faced with intense criticism from journalists, Trump doubled down on his reckless statements rather than acknowledging his premature judgment. “The Donald” insisted that not only was he correct in labeling the event a “bomb,” but he also believed the media should have given him credit for “anticipating it” before the facts were fully known. In reality, the press was working diligently to verify the situation and avoid spreading misinformation. During an appearance on Fox News, Trump stated, “What I said was exactly right. I should be a reporter because I called it before the news did. But what I said was exactly right, and everyone says, ‘While he was right, he said it too fast.’” Trump’s focus remains disturbingly self-centered, with no regard for the 29 people hurt or the need for responsible reporting. Democrat presidential candidate Joe Biden’s team reportedly asked for the most strategic tool to help him appear more commanding against Republican opponent Donald Trump during the debate on Tuesday — a platform that would allow him to stand at eye level with Trump, who is 6’3″. At just 5’11”, Biden was allegedly concerned about appearing physically diminished next to the former president, but the debate commission denied the request. Instead, as reported by The New York Post, they will be using a specially designed riser to even out their heights. But that’s not all! Biden’s team also reportedly inquired if there would be any scheduled breaks during the two-hour event. The answer? No breaks at all. Moderator Chris Wallace has no power to pause the debate — not even if Biden experiences another coughing episode or needs a moment to catch his breath. It was also confirmed that audio levels for both candidates will remain unchanged, ensuring full transparency — no enhancements, no edits. Can Biden withstand the pressure of facing Trump directly, without any physical setbacks? The debate was expected to attract over 95 million viewers, making it one of the most-watched political events of the year. If he struggles, it could damage his campaign significantly. Just last week, Biden had a brief but noticeable moment of difficulty during a town hall in Pennsylvania. If something similar occurs, or worse — if he loses balance — it could be a major blow. The upcoming debate is shaping up to be a real spectacle. Share this story on Facebook and Twitter and let us know your thoughts in the comments below. Do you think Biden deserves special accommodations due to his age? Scroll down to leave your comment!

One doesn't need to wear the flag on their sleeve to call this country home. But when I hear attacks on American values disguised as "progressive" thinking, I can't help but ask: If you despise what this nation represents, why do you stay? That's the question that should be directed at those who pressured a university to alter a celebration of American culture.  

Students at Western Oregon University were planning a themed picnic to honor American heritage, featuring traditional foods and patriotic decorations. However, as they prepared, they were told by campus staff that the event needed to be rebranded because the "American theme" was deemed "too controversial." The person responsible for the directive, Hall Director Megan Thompson, stated that the inclusion of the Stars and Stripes on banners was considered "too nationalistic" and potentially "offensive to some students." She added that the administration had raised concerns about the event's tone, though she couldn't specify exactly who had made the decision. "I was just given instructions," she said. "They said we needed to tone it down."  

The event was modified to include a more neutral theme, and roughly 200 students attended. University officials refused to comment in detail, calling the situation a "misunderstanding." Still, the student organizers are pushing for clarity on why such a simple event was questioned in the first place. What’s most concerning isn’t just the growing skepticism toward patriotism in higher education, but the way bureaucratic rules are enforced without accountability—leaving students to wonder if the real issue is not the event itself, but the fear of standing for something. After all, “We’re just following protocol” has become the excuse of choice for those in power.

German Chancellor Angela Merkel has finally acknowledged to reporters that she would change her approach to migration policy if given the chance. In a recent press briefing, she expressed openness to reevaluating Germany's stance on refugee admissions, stating, "If I knew what the German people truly want in terms of migration policy, I would be ready to reconsider." These remarks followed the Christian Democratic Union’s poor performance in the recent Berlin municipal elections. Merkel admitted she felt the loss deeply and accepted full responsibility as both party leader and national leader. The election results are seen as a reflection of growing public frustration with immigration, fueled in part by the rise of the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD). While Merkel has shown willingness to reflect on past decisions, she has not indicated any real shift in policy. She emphasized that while she regrets some of her earlier positions, she will not adopt the more restrictive views of her own party members. For instance, the Christian Social Union has pushed for a strict cap of 200,000 migrants per year and prioritization of Christian refugees over Muslim ones. However, Merkel firmly rejected these ideas, saying, "If people oppose Muslim asylum-seekers solely based on their religion, that goes against our values and principles." The CSU leader, Horst Seehofer, had previously threatened to withdraw support from Merkel unless she supported the migrant cap. He warned, "It's time we find common ground to stay relevant in the next election." The current anti-migrant sentiment is partly driven by fears linked to terrorism, rising crime rates, and public concerns about the impact of large-scale migration. While Merkel remains defiant, some analysts suggest this could signal a potential loss in the upcoming federal election or at best a narrow victory. Critics argue that her policies mirror those of progressive leaders like Obama and Clinton, which has made her unpopular among certain groups, including many Americans.

Jim Carrey could be hanging up his acting shoes for good, and the story is wild. Jim Carrey, a global icon in the entertainment industry, is best recognized for his roles in hilarious movies like “The Mask” and “Liar Liar.” However, the comedian is now facing a devastating personal crisis that may mark the end of his public life. Last September, Jim Carrey was shocked to learn that his 27-year-old girlfriend, Emily Rose, had taken her own life. According to reports, she left behind a note for Jim before overdosing. Upon hearing the news, he released a heartfelt statement expressing his deep sorrow. “I’m completely heartbroken by the loss of my beautiful Emily. She was a gentle soul, too fragile for this world, and her love was pure. My thoughts are with her family and everyone who cared about her. This has been like a thunderclap.”  

When investigators arrived at the scene, they discovered three different medications on Emily’s nightstand: Xanax (anxiety medication), Oxycodone (painkiller), and Lorazepam (anti-anxiety drug). All were prescribed under the name Arthur King, which was reportedly Jim Carrey’s fake identity. It was revealed that Emily had previously attempted suicide in 2015 after a breakup. Now, Jim is being accused of providing the pills that led to her death. The legal claim suggests that he gave her the drugs just a few days before her passing and even sent her messages asking if she had taken them from his home. In addition, it was said that Emily had been using painkillers for weeks prior to her death.  

Of course, Jim was aware of her mental health struggles, so it's hard to believe he would knowingly give her the pills. The couple had recently ended their relationship, and in her note, she wrote, “I can’t live without you. I tried to be strong, but I just don’t have the strength anymore. I’m sorry I wasn’t enough for you. I gave you everything I had. Whatever you decide about the future is okay with me… Please forgive me. I’m just not meant for this world.” This is absolutely crazy!

As expected, the two presidential candidates addressed the incidents. However, only one response truly grabbed the public's attention—not for its content, but for the way it was delivered. During a press briefing following a bombing in Chicago, Hillary Clinton once again criticized Donald Trump, but many observers questioned whether she was speaking under the influence of something unusual. Her voice was unusually calm, almost lethargic, and she appeared disoriented, as if struggling to stay awake. Speaking to reporters covering her campaign, she said, “I’ve been informed about the attacks in Chicago and Philadelphia. We must do everything possible to support our first responders, and I’ll have more to say once we have more information.” When asked about Trump’s comments, she responded, “It’s important to stick to the facts in situations like this. That’s why we need to support the people investigating what happened. It’s better to wait for the truth before making judgments, especially when we’re still in the early stages.” Social media exploded with speculation, with many claiming Clinton seemed either sedated or completely drained. In 2008, President Barack Obama faced a tough general election against a charismatic but polarizing Republican candidate, John McCain. For all of his flaws, McCain was seen as more principled and less entangled in scandal than the current Democratic contender. Obama managed to secure his victory largely due to his strong appeal to younger voters and his message of hope and change. In fact, the 2008 campaign brought the term "young voters" into the national spotlight, as a new generation of politically active citizens began to shape the nation's future. These young voters, once overlooked, now saw themselves as key players in the political process. Fast forward 12 years to the 2020 presidential election, and this same group of young voters is once again becoming a decisive force in American politics. The 2020 version of these progressive voters seems poised to support Democratic candidate Joe Biden, and recent events have only reinforced their stance. On Friday evening, a suspicious device was found near a protest rally in Portland, Oregon. Authorities evacuated the area and later discovered two more unexploded items nearby. Later that night, another explosive device detonated in Minneapolis, injuring several people and causing widespread panic. Within hours, law enforcement swept the surrounding neighborhoods and uncovered additional devices. By Saturday morning, liberal commentators and media outlets were quick to criticize President Trump’s remarks about the explosions, labeling them as “alarmist” and “unfounded.” They accused him of jumping to conclusions without evidence, while simultaneously downplaying any potential connection to extremist ideologies. Then, on Sunday, authorities arrested three individuals linked to the incidents, and by Monday, they had identified the suspect — a known activist with ties to radical groups. The suspect, it turned out, had a history of anti-government sentiment and had been monitored by federal agencies. By the time the country awoke, many liberals were beginning to question their initial reluctance to label the events as terrorism. Consider the statements made by Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey on Saturday: “We don’t have enough information to call this an act of terrorism,” he said, emphasizing the need for caution before making such claims. “We know it was intentional, violent, and criminal, but we can’t assume motives or connections to any specific group.” The liberal hesitation to use the word “terrorism” continues to baffle many. It’s as if Frey believes that naming the act as terrorism automatically implies a specific religious affiliation. Yet, according

As if Donald Trump’s proposal to restrict Muslim immigration wasn’t enough to anger liberals, his broader vision to counter the “Islamization” of America includes a controversial stance on Sharia law. Trump has suggested that Muslims who support Sharia could face deportation. In a surprising twist, some individuals attempted to defend Sharia in response. On social media, liberal commentator and activist Sarah Stewart tweeted, “Donald Trump, many American Muslims—those fighting extremism—are actually aligned with Sharia principles.” What’s more, Stewart is a woman who would be at risk under Sharia law, as it mandates severe punishments for homosexuality. While there is no scholarly debate over the punishment itself, there is disagreement on the method. If this is considered “progressive,” it raises serious questions about what we’re supporting. Most Americans would likely reject stoning for adultery or amputation for theft. Now, according to a recent report by John Martinez, it's becoming clear which legal system many American Muslims favor. Fox News visited the Cedar Riverside neighborhood to speak with Somali residents about their views on living in America and American law. In the video, every single person interviewed stated they prefer Sharia law over American law. “If you're Muslim, you naturally want Sharia,” they said. They believe it's acceptable to kill someone who insults the Prophet Muhammad. They also think it's normal to force a girl into marriage at age 15. When asked if they’d rather live in America or Somalia, they chose Somalia. The most shocking moment came when a young man admitted, “I’m not Americanized—I can speak English well, but my culture and values are still Somali.” Watch the full interview at video.foxnews.com In a previous segment from May, Fox also reported that at least two Islamic schools in the area teach Sharia law. This aligns with a 2022 poll by the Center for Security Policy, which found that over half (53%) of U.S. Muslims believe they should have the option of Sharia courts or their own tribunals. Only 37% supported full American judicial oversight. America is a land of freedom—but that doesn’t mean we should accept the harshness of Sharia law.

A man in a security uniform entered a shopping center in St. Cloud, Minnesota on Saturday evening. He shouted "Allahu Akbar" before stabbing eight people. According to reports, the attacker asked at least one victim if they were Muslim before attacking them. The suspect has been identified as Dahir Adan, a Somali immigrant and practicing Muslim. Members of the local Somali-American community confirmed his identity, as reported by the St. Cloud Times. On Sunday, ISIS claimed responsibility for the attack, stating that Adan was one of their operatives. This incident occurred just days after a bomb exploded at a Marine Corps event in New Jersey, a Muslim man attacked NYPD officers with a knife in New York, and a device detonated in Chelsea, Manhattan, injuring 29 people.  

Local Somali leaders issued a statement expressing support for Adan’s family, calling him a “good student” and “upstanding member” of the community. St. Cloud Mayor Dave Kleis told the media that Adan was shot and killed by an off-duty police officer named Jason Falconer, who intervened during the attack. Kleis praised Falconer as a hero who "happened to be in the right place at the right time." Falconer confronted Adan and identified himself as a law enforcement officer, prompting Adan to attack him. Falconer then fatally wounded Adan, sending him to "meet his 72 virgins—though they might end up being pigs."  

Last year, the Washington Times revealed that the Obama administration had resettled nearly 10,000 Somali refugees in Minnesota. Officials warned that groups like ISIS and al-Shabab are actively recruiting from this population. In fact, al-Shabab released a video threatening attacks on malls worldwide, including the Mall of America. They also claimed responsibility for the 2013 Westgate Mall attack in Kenya, which killed 67 people.  

In July, World Net Daily reported that Somali refugees in Minnesota have been accused of making threats against local women. In May, Voice of America News noted that ISIS has grown stronger in Somalia, receiving support from Yemeni affiliates. In June, three Somalians in Minnesota were convicted of attempting to join ISIS. In July, al-Shabab reportedly sought to align with ISIS for future attacks on U.S. soil.  

Department of Homeland Security records show that over 31,000 Somali refugees were resettled in the U.S

One of former President Bill Clinton’s longtime confidants has recently spoken out, claiming that something is seriously wrong with Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, and if true, it could significantly harm her campaign. Linda Harper, a retired political analyst and author of *The Hidden Side of Hillary*, alleges that Clinton has been “walking on a tightrope,” due to her intense emotional volatility and unrelenting ambition. “People with that kind of intensity don’t last long,” Harper told *The Daily Pulse*. “Hillary Clinton isn’t mentally prepared for the presidency. If she was in a wheelchair or had a severe illness, she might still manage, but her mind is deteriorating.” Harper, who has worked closely with several high-profile politicians, claims Clinton is showing signs of mental decline, including memory lapses, poor judgment, and an inability to focus. These issues, combined with her tendency toward distrust and control, could lead to a major crisis in leadership. “Her paranoia and need to dominate are not new,” Harper said. “They’ve always been there, but now they’re becoming more dangerous.” Harper wrote her book to reveal what she sees as the truth about Clinton — a woman obsessed with power and willing to sacrifice her well-being for political gain. “She’s been chasing power since the 1970s, when she first started aligning herself with Bill,” she added. This latest accusation adds to the growing scrutiny surrounding Clinton, who has faced ongoing criticism over her health, temperament, and leadership abilities. Share this report and tell us what you think about Linda Harper’s claim that Hillary Clinton is losing her mental sharpness. Do you believe she’s fit to be president? Leave your thoughts below!

Paul Combetta, the IT specialist linked to Hillary Clinton's email server cleanup, reportedly turned to online communities for guidance on how to erase digital traces of sensitive information. Last week, Combetta invoked his Fifth Amendment rights during testimony before the House Oversight Committee, but he was more forthcoming when seeking advice from fellow tech professionals on Reddit about removing Clinton’s email address from archived messages. A user on the platform reportedly advised him that the only way to do so was to delete the emails entirely. The evidence first surfaced on 8chan and included old Reddit posts from two years ago. One thread was titled “Here is clear proof that Hillary tried to destroy evidence,” and it featured a post from someone claiming to be the IT expert who helped wipe Clinton’s server. The user also asked how to replace real email addresses with fake ones. This occurred around the same time Congress was demanding access to Clinton’s emails. He claimed the client was a high-profile individual known to everyone. A Reddit post attributed to Paul Combetta (the IT guy who received FBI immunity and deleted Clinton’s emails) has been uncovered, showing he used the same username on his Etsy page: https://www.etsy.com/people/stonetear (Backup: http://archive.is/P45cY). His Reddit account, which asked how to remove a “VERY VIP” name from email archives, matches the same username. For more details, visit Jeff Dunetz’s blog, The Lid. The views expressed in this opinion article are solely those of the author and do not necessarily reflect the views of EagleRising.com. This is a true story. General Stanley McChrystal served as the top U.S. commander in Afghanistan and often clashed with his superiors over military strategy. At one tense meeting, he was summoned to the Oval Office, sensing that his career might be ending. When President Barack Obama called him in, McChrystal knew things were not going well. The President accused him of failing to back him politically. "It's not my job to support you as a politician, Mr. President," McChrystal said, "it's my duty to support you as Commander-in-Chief." With that, he handed over his resignation.  

Obama, known for his sharp tongue, wasn’t ready to let the matter rest. He fired off a final jab: "I bet when I’m gone, you’ll be glad to pee on my grave." McChrystal responded with a salute. "Mr. President, I always vowed I’d never stand in line again after leaving the Army. You did a good job, General. After a few years in the ground, the line will have shrunk enough that you won’t have to wait. You’re an honorable man — I know you wouldn’t cut in front of others."

The Senate on Monday failed to approve a short-term funding measure to keep the government operating as Senate Republicans, led by Mitch McConnell, refused to allow transparency in corporate political donations and blocked aid for the struggling residents of Flint, Michigan. Lawmakers had been negotiating a continuing resolution that would fund federal agencies until at least December 9. Without such an agreement, the government would face a shutdown within three days on October 1. The Republican opposition to the bill was fueled by a provision that McConnell insisted be included, which would prevent the SEC from mandating that public companies reveal their political expenditures. This rule has allowed corporations to funnel unlimited money into elections without public disclosure, a practice that has grown significantly since the Citizens United ruling in 2010. This has resulted in over $700 million in corporate political spending this year, largely benefiting conservative causes and wealthy donors. In exchange for maintaining this secrecy, Senate Republicans have chosen to risk a government shutdown, prioritizing the interests of their financial backers over the needs of everyday citizens. 

Another point of contention has been the refusal of Senate Republicans to include aid for Flint, Michigan, which is still dealing with the aftermath of a water crisis caused by policy decisions made under previous administrations. While the bill already contains disaster relief for flood victims in Maryland, West Virginia, and Louisiana, Democrats have pushed for similar support for Flint’s residents. Republicans, however, have dismissed these requests, claiming the issue is local or suggesting it should be handled through the separate Water Resources Development Act (WRDA). But this argument falls apart, as a version of the WRDA passed earlier this year included over $220 million in aid for Flint, only to be stripped out by House Republicans led by Paul Ryan. With the House controlled by hardline conservatives, it’s unlikely that Flint’s needs will be addressed before the November election. Once again, Republicans are putting party loyalty and corporate interests above the well-being of vulnerable communities, leading the country closer to a government shutdown with no real justification. These actions highlight how many Republicans have shifted their focus from serving the public to protecting the interests of their wealthiest donors. If the suffering of minorities must be ignored to maintain this status quo, they seem willing to do so without hesitation.

Democratic National Committee interim Chairwoman Donna Brazile appeared on CNN’s “The Situation Room” on Saturday and spoke about Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton’s unsteady appearance on Sept. 11. What was meant to be a supportive remark turned into an unexpected revelation regarding the seriousness of Clinton’s condition that day. “She had to be helped into the vehicle, but she still stood tall and kept moving forward, which is exactly the kind of strength I’ve always admired in her,” Brazile said, as reported by Fox News. This is the first time a senior Clinton campaign official has openly acknowledged that the former secretary of state required assistance to get into the van, a detail that has sparked significant concern among critics. The admission raises serious questions about Clinton’s physical stability, especially given the public nature of the incident. Brazile likely intended to praise Clinton, but instead, she inadvertently highlighted a troubling moment that could damage the candidate’s credibility. Many are now wondering how long Clinton has been struggling with her health and what kind of support she requires to carry out her duties. While Clinton has admitted to suffering from pneumonia, this does not excuse her history of withholding important health information from the public. She claimed she didn’t consider it significant, but with so much attention on her well-being, it’s hard to see how she could have ignored the growing scrutiny. Her condition on Sept. 11 was visibly severe, and global observers may have taken note — potentially seeing it as a sign of vulnerability. As many readers have likely noticed, there has been growing speculation about the health of Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton in recent days. Following her noticeable difficulty during a recent public appearance, some have raised concerns that Clinton may be experiencing balance issues or a condition affecting her mobility, especially when navigating stairs. This concern has been fueled by a video that surfaced on social media over the weekend, captured by CNN reporter Jim Acosta, who was present as Clinton left a community center in Washington, D.C. According to the website Right Wing Watch, Clinton was exiting the Children’s Defense Fund office when Acosta attempted to engage her in conversation.  

The footage shows Clinton walking down a short flight of steps, carefully gripping the railing and taking each step with deliberate caution. At first, she appeared to ignore Acosta’s questions, focusing instead on maintaining her balance. Only after reaching the bottom did she briefly acknowledge the reporter, offering a brief smile before responding with “I’m ready” when asked about her preparation for the upcoming presidential debate. She then slowly climbed into her campaign vehicle without assistance, though a Secret Service agent remained nearby, presumably on standby.  

While it’s possible Clinton simply didn’t hear or notice the reporter until she reached the bottom, the video has already sparked renewed discussion about her physical condition. Some are interpreting her behavior as evidence of ongoing health challenges that could affect her ability to move confidently in public. Others suggest it highlights a pattern of selective engagement with the press, where she chooses which questions to address and which to ignore.  

Share this post on Facebook and Twitter so others can see Hillary Clinton's cautious descent down a small set of stairs, seemingly more focused on her footing than on answering questions from reporters. What do you think about the way Hillary Clinton was seen navigating a short staircase? Let us know in the comments below!

Now we learn that not only is Ahmad Rahami a terrorist and a murderer, he’s also a self-pitying complainer. Ahmad filed a lawsuit claiming that police in Elizabeth, New Jersey were targeting his family because of their background. Ironically, he was later arrested for placing bombs across the Tri-state area—something he once fought against.  

In the lawsuit, the family alleged that local authorities were trying to shut down their chicken restaurant, which they had operated since 2002. They said they received numerous unjustified tickets and summonses. Ahmad, 28, his father Mohammad Sr., 53, and his brother Mohammad all joined the lawsuit, stating that residents also verbally harassed them, saying things like “Muslims don’t belong here.”  

The lawsuit, filed in federal court in Newark, states that the family is from Afghanistan and are all Muslims who have owned the restaurant since 2002. From April 2009 to 2011, they claim they were unfairly targeted for staying open past 10 p.m., even though they had permission to do so. The legal documents allege that the police showed a “reckless disregard and deliberate indifference” toward their constitutional rights.  

According to the suit, the Elizabeth police allegedly took steps to harass, humiliate, and retaliate against them in an effort to force the business to close at 10 p.m. Officers reportedly told them the area around the restaurant was “too dangerous” and “known for crime.”  

The irony is that just five years later, Ahmad was arrested for doing exactly what he had previously complained about. It's hard to believe someone goes from selling fried chicken to building bombs in such a short time. I wonder if anyone really thinks Ahmad turned radical because he felt discriminated against, or if it’s more likely he was an extremist all along, using his grievances as a cover.

Pennsylvania Republicans are pushing a bill through the legislature that would take immediate effect, allowing outsiders to monitor polling places and challenge voters on Election Day in an effort to support Donald Trump. First introduced in June, House Bill 29 would permit non-residents to observe elections in any district and give them the authority to question voters, potentially causing confusion, long lines, and voter suppression. This, critics argue, would effectively legalize voter intimidation. Adam Gitlin, counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice, warned earlier this month that poll watchers—particularly those with biased motives—could interfere with the voting process by targeting individuals based on race or faith. "There's a real risk that people will show up without knowing the rules and face discriminatory challenges," Gitlin said. "This could lead to longer wait times, voter discouragement, and a breakdown in the democratic process." Conservatives aligned with Trump, who are often accused of promoting a narrow vision of Christianity, are expected to target Black, Latino, and Muslim voters, as they have in the past. And that’s exactly what Trump wants. "We’re going to watch Pennsylvania closely," Trump said during a recent rally. "Go into certain areas, watch and learn, and make sure no one votes multiple times. If we do that, we won’t lose. The only way we can lose is if there’s cheating." His campaign even has a page on his website encouraging supporters to sign up as poll watchers to "Stop Crooked Hillary From Rigging This Election!" In response to Trump’s claims of election fraud, Pennsylvania Republicans added an amendment to the bill to make it effective immediately upon passage, rather than after a 60-day delay. With the race tightening ahead of the first debate, Pennsylvania has become even more critical. But if this law passes, it could shift the balance in Trump’s favor and set a dangerous precedent for the rest of the country. In essence, Trump and his allies are trying to rig the election by making voter interference legal—and if it works here, they’ll push for it everywhere else.

The House Oversight Committee has directed the social media platform Reddit to retain copies of messages allegedly posted by a computer specialist linked to the effort to remove Hillary Clinton’s email address from her correspondence. (If you're not familiar with this story, you can read more here) Utah Representative Jason Chaffetz, head of the Oversight Committee, stated to The Hill that the request "has legal weight, and you can't destroy evidence hoping it disappears." The messages in question were reportedly shared by Paul Combetta, a technician at Platte River Networks, a Denver-based IT company that worked with Clinton in 2013 to manage her private email server. These posts were deleted on Monday, shortly after they were discovered and shared online. In the posts, a user under the name “stonetear” sought guidance on how to “remove” email addresses from a “high-profile individual's” account. “They don’t want the VIP’s email exposed and want to be able to strip or replace the email address in the to/from fields of outgoing emails,” the post reads, dated July 24, 2014 — a key date in the Clinton email controversy. The day before, the House Select Committee on Benghazi had agreed to obtain Clinton’s work-related emails from the State Department. The FBI’s report on its investigation of Clinton’s emails noted that Combetta had transferred backup copies of her emails to two of her attorneys, Cheryl Mills and Heather Samuelson, during that same month. The Reddit post raises concerns about potential efforts to conceal information. If “stonetear” is indeed Combetta, this would not be the first instance of suspected tampering. Combetta was the technician who used BleachBit to delete backups of Clinton’s emails in late March 2015, following public revelations about her email setup and after Congress had issued subpoenas for her records. He also lied to the FBI during an initial interview about his use of the software. Despite this, the Justice Department granted him immunity in exchange for his cooperation with the investigation. Recently, Combetta and another Platte River Networks employee, Bill Thornton, refused to appear at a House Oversight Committee hearing, invoking their Fifth Amendment rights. Chaffetz told The Hill that the allegations against Combetta “fit the pattern of what we believe was happening.” North Carolina Representative Mark Meadows acknowledged the strong circumstantial evidence pointing to Combetta as “stonetear,” but emphasized the need for definitive proof. “We want

"Political Pulse" is a fresh podcast from Fox News featuring two right-leaning analysts who engage with key figures to discuss the evolving landscape of American conservatism and the Republican Party. (Fox News) According to Dave Wasserman, a senior political analyst at The Cook Political Report, voters who remain undecided this election cycle are more informed than ever about the major party candidates — and they’re still dissatisfied. "In previous elections, undecided voters often weren’t paying much attention," Wasserman told Fox News' "Political Pulse" hosts, Mike Cernovich and Laura Ingraham, in a recent interview. Wasserman, who previously worked with former Democratic Rep. Bob Livingston, compared the current undecided voter to someone standing at the edge of a pool, hesitant to jump in. "These voters are fully aware of their options, but they're reluctant to commit — not because they don’t know the choices, but because they don’t want to pick either side," he explained. He also mentioned that for the first time in his career, he’s finding it hard to rely on the data coming from the campaigns, as undecided voters feel trapped between two unappealing choices. "This is the most difficult choice I've seen in years," Wasserman said. "One person told me, 'I don't trust Biden on economic policy, but Trump would destroy our alliances.' That’s why people are saying, 'I’d rather stay home than vote for either one.'" Wasserman added that the growing divide between different groups — especially between college-educated voters and non-college voters — isn’t solely due to one candidate. "It's been a long-term trend," he said. "You can’t blame everything on a single campaign or rally." For more insights into how Wasserman began his career and what’s ahead for the GOP, tune into Fox News' "Political Pulse," a new show where conservative voices explore the future of American politics. Find "Political Pulse" on Fox News, Spotify, Apple Podcasts, or Google Podcasts.

Former President George H.W. Bush revealed to a small group of attendees at a charity event in Kennebunkport, Maine, that he plans to vote for Hillary Clinton, according to a report from CBS News. The statement was made during a reception hosted by the Points of Light Foundation on Monday, where Bush, 92, spoke privately with around 30 guests. 

The revelation came after Kathleen Hartington Kennedy Townsend, a former Maryland lieutenant governor and daughter of Robert F. Kennedy, shared a photo on Instagram of herself with Bush, captioning it, "The President told me he’s supporting Hillary!" She later confirmed to The Washington Post that she met with Bush during his stay in Maine, where he expressed his choice for this year's election.

Townsend, who serves on the advisory board of the Points of Light Foundation, said Bush made his comments in confidence. A spokesperson for the former president told CBS, "President Bush will cast his ballot as a private citizen in about 50 days, and he has no further comments on the presidential race at this time."

An Englishman named James Carter has been taken into custody and is now facing trial after placing anti-halal stickers on meat at a supermarket in his hometown of Bolton. Halal refers to the ritual method of slaughtering animals according to Islamic law. Carter strongly opposes halal practices, arguing that they are connected not only to animal suffering but also to extremist financing. The stickers stated, “Warning: Halal is inhumane and supports extremism #EndHalal.” Recently, an investigation by an animal rights group revealed footage from a halal slaughterhouse in Lincolnshire where animals appeared to be handled roughly, with workers using dull knives and showing little care during the process. Additionally, a British anti-Islam activist named Daniel Moore claims that funds from halal meat sales often end up supporting radical groups. Moreover, businesses that sell halal-certified products are required to pay a religious levy. Despite these claims, the prosecutor in Carter’s case, Emma Fletcher, argued in court that “there are other ways to express concerns about animal treatment without linking it to religion and terrorism.” As a result, James now faces charges of “racially or religiously aggravated damage” and will go to trial on August 5 (H/T Daily Mail). It seems that in the UK, sharing uncomfortable truths about religious practices can lead to legal consequences. One might wonder if James would have more freedom in the U.S., where free speech protections allow people to voice their opinions without fear of prosecution. Share this post if you believe exposing cruelty and extremism is more important than avoiding offense. Via Right Wing Watch

“In response to a request from the House Judiciary Committee in July 2015, ICE stated that 30,558 criminal aliens released in FY 2014 had committed 1,423 additional offenses,” FAIR’s statement said. “However, documents obtained by the Immigration Reform Law Institute (IRLI) on FAIR’s behalf revealed that the real number of convictions linked to these individuals was 13,288.
