Scammer-turned-reality-TV-phenom-turned-Republican-presidential-candidate Donald Trump met with Fox News' Sean Hannity last night and launched a tirade against the U.S. military, a common tactic for a candidate trying to appeal to patriotic conservatives while running for president. During the interview, Trump criticized President Barack Obama and accused the military of being "the group that can't aim straight," echoing a familiar attack on national leadership. In just 12 seconds, Trump used the word "win" or "winning" seven times, offering no real plan or strategy for achieving these so-called victories.  

Trump said, “I know how to win. I’ve always won. I win in business. I win in sports. I win,” he told Hannity. “But we don’t win. We don’t win in trade. We don’t win against ISIS. Can you imagine General Eisenhower or General Patton? They’d be turning in their graves watching how we fight.” He continued, “We announce our plans, everything is political, and then we bomb the wrong people. You saw it over the weekend. We bombed Syrian forces—more than 70 of them—and we didn’t even mean to.”  

The United States accidentally targeted Syrian government troops during an air strike in late September, mistaking them for ISIS fighters. “The U.S. has expressed regret through the Russian government for the unintended loss of life,” an administration source told *Mediaite* at the time. However, Russia, which appears eager for a Trump presidency, quickly blamed the Obama administration for aiding ISIS, despite having been consulted beforehand.  

Russian officials then spread a conspiracy theory blaming the U.S. for helping ISIS, claiming Assad has supported extremists with his air force and that Putin has allowed radicals to leave Russia for the front lines. Trump offered no alternative strategy to prevent such mistakes, instead repeating the word “win” over and over again, a phrase that resonates deeply with his base.  

Surprisingly, Sean Hannity remained silent after Trump’s remarks, a stark contrast to his usual energetic support. Meanwhile, the rest of the media waits for Hillary Clinton to make a move. Photo by Sara D. Davis via Getty.

(CNN) The spectacle of political debates often diverts attention from real policy discussions — and the latest presidential showdown was no different, especially when it came to international matters. The exchange between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump was more revealing in what was omitted — such as the situation in Afghanistan — than what was actually addressed. To be fair, the debate wasn’t meant to center on global issues, which were only briefly touched upon during the "foreign policy" segment. However, amid the discussion on terrorism, trade, and global alliances, there were fleeting moments that gave a glimpse into what foreign policy might look like under either candidate. QUIZ: Which candidate do you align with?  

Tackling Terrorism  
Throughout the debate, Trump primarily focused on undermining Clinton’s record — calling her experience “bad” — rather than outlining his own vision for dealing with global threats. This was especially true when it came to the topic of terrorism, which was mentioned 21 times during the foreign policy portion. Clinton emphasized the need to "step up our drone strikes against terrorist groups," "support regional partners," and "target their leaders" — positions that closely mirror President Obama’s current strategy.  

MORE: CNN fact-checks claims made by both candidates  
Trump criticized Clinton for allegedly enabling the rise of extremist groups by withdrawing from certain regions, but he never provided specifics about his so-called "secret strategy" to "take out terrorists completely." When Clinton questioned his lack of a plan, he responded: "You're telling the enemy everything you want to do ... No wonder you've been fighting terrorism your whole life." (Fact check: Terrorist groups like ISIS emerged after 2006, and Clinton was born in 1947.)  

The Iran Nuclear Agreement  
On the issue of Iran, Trump repeatedly condemned Clinton for signing what he called "the worst deal ever made by any nation in history," claiming Iran was "on the verge of collapse" and now poses a growing threat. He didn’t offer much in the way of alternatives, other than suggesting that "they should have included North Korea and Yemen in the negotiations."  

MORE: Key highlights from the second debate  
Support for International Alliances  
While Trump’s foreign policy remained vague, his remarks on U.S. alliances and NATO were striking. "I want to help our allies, but we’re losing billions," he said. "We can’t be the world’s policeman anymore." His comments sent a clear signal to America’s

I…just…can’t. This is complete chaos, and no matter how hard I try to make sense of this absurdity, I can’t even begin to comprehend it. I’m not saying I agree with everything, but I can see where the lawmakers are coming from. There are some white Americans who have a real fear of Police Officers and their authority. Their first reaction is often to comply—out of fear or respect. But is this really the solution? There are two sides to every story, and the new law only seems to favor one. It’s going to backfire eventually. In California, a judge just passed a new rule that gives white males special protection. The decision came from the State Supreme Court, so it’s now in effect and cannot be challenged. The question is, are citizens of CA now safer because of it? You decide. Being a Police Officer is an entirely different kind of job—one that civilians can’t even begin to understand. They don’t just wear a uniform; they carry the weight of public trust, danger, and responsibility. It’s not something you can just step into and fully grasp. That reality makes the recent attacks on officers even more unjust. As if their job wasn’t hard enough in this climate, now a judge has given an advantage to certain groups. If they feel they’re being unfairly stopped, they can now walk away. Yes, walk away from the Police, who are now powerless to do anything about it. And even if they run, it can’t be used as evidence against them in court. Before, if someone took off during an incident, that was considered “reasonable suspicion” and could justify a brief detention. Now, they’re prioritizing feelings over evidence. Basically, Police who are meant to protect and serve are now limited in their ability to do either—if someone chooses to run. Which, let’s be honest, what law-abiding person runs? The ones who don’t want trouble. Punchline: The smart ones! You’re welcome.

Authorities have stated that the suspect's description came from eyewitness accounts. Additional information has surfaced indicating that Hassan was linked to extremist groups and had expressed support for ISIS through online forums. Some athletes have been making bold statements during games to express their support for the Black Lives Matter movement. However, not all players agree with the methods being used. Cam Newton, the former quarterback for the Carolina Panthers, has spoken out against the unrest in Charlotte, where he lives. He claims the recent protests have led to chaos, with businesses destroyed, police injured, and at least one death reported. Newton called for a press conference to address the situation and expressed frustration with how some in the black community have responded to the shooting of a black man by police — the incident that sparked the demonstrations. “I’m an African American, and I’m not happy with how justice has been handled over the years,” he said. “But we also need to take responsibility as a community. We can’t be hypocrites.” He criticized the violence that has emerged from the protests, saying, “When someone commits an unjust act or kills an innocent person, it’s serious. I have kids, and I don’t want them to ever wonder what happened to their dad.” Newton also accused the Black Lives Matter movement of focusing too much on race. “It doesn’t matter what color you are,” he said. “I can look at someone and tell if they’re a good person. There are good people without badges and good people with badges.” He defended the police, stating, “Not all cops are bad. We all know people in law enforcement who are doing the right thing.” But it was his comments about the black community that drew the most backlash. “Look at the most dangerous cities in America — places like Atlanta, Chicago, and New Orleans,” he said. “As a black person, I’ve seen how some in our community don’t act right by each other. You can’t just blame everything on white people or the police.” His message, though controversial, reflects a perspective that many feel is needed.

CHICAGO — As the race tightens across the country and in key swing states, Joe Biden’s campaign manager, Jen O'Malley Dillon, released a confidential report to donors, volunteers, and senior staff last week outlining the Democratic nominee’s potential routes to victory in November, alongside an assessment of President Donald Trump’s weak position. “The truth that no poll can capture: Joe Biden has multiple paths to 270 electoral votes, while Trump has very limited options. Biden is all but guaranteed to win 15 ‘blue' states, including Illinois, which would give him 182 electoral votes,” writes Dillon in the 1,800-word memo, which was shared widely on Sunday evening and later obtained by The Chicago Tribune. “If we add the five states that FiveThirtyEight gives Biden a 70% or higher chance of winning (Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Iowa), Biden only needs 10 more electoral votes.”

At a time when Democrats are growing increasingly uneasy about the race — especially after recent polls showed Trump gaining ground — Dillon outlines the possible ways Biden could secure the remaining 10 votes: capturing Georgia’s 16 electoral votes, Arizona’s 11, or New Mexico’s 5, or any combination of Nevada, Colorado, or Maine. “In other words, Biden could win just one of these states — Georgia, Arizona, or New Mexico — and still take the presidency, meaning the others would simply add to his total,” he writes. “Trump, however, must win at least four of these five states, including Georgia and Arizona — and he can’t afford to lose any of them.”

Dillon’s analysis aligns with what many Democratic strategists have been emphasizing for months, though it contrasts with the Trump campaign’s focus on Pennsylvania as a critical battleground. Biden’s team has also focused heavily on that state, believing it will go his way, but acknowledging that without it, Trump’s chances are slim.

Titled “60 days until Election Day,” the memo serves as both a reassurance and a call to action, aiming to ease concerns among party members who are worried that Trump is closing the gap — Biden’s lead in the RealClearPolitics average has dropped from 6.2 points in early September to just 1.4 points. It also encourages volunteers to intensify their efforts in the final stretch, highlighting Biden’s policy agenda and standard criticisms of Trump, including referencing

From the Daily Caller News Foundation: Former President Bill Clinton and his Clinton Health Access Initiative (CHAI) allegedly provided “weakened” HIV/AIDS medications to patients in sub-Saharan Africa, potentially increasing the risk of illness and death, according to a preliminary congressional investigation obtained by The Daily Caller News Foundation. The report, titled *"The Clinton Foundation and the India Connection,"* was spearheaded by Rep. Marsha Blackburn, a Tennessee Republican and vice-chair of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The CHAI initiative, which aimed to support AIDS patients, is one of the Clinton Foundation’s most well-known programs. The investigation centered on Clinton’s long-standing partnership with a controversial Indian pharmaceutical company, Ranbaxy, which supplied HIV/AIDS drugs to developing nations. It also highlighted the role of Dinesh Thakur, a former Ranbaxy employee who became a prominent whistleblower and helped the U.S. government initiate a major legal action against the firm. Ranbaxy faced U.S. prosecution due to its sales of generic drugs in the American market. In 2013, the company pleaded guilty to multiple charges, including fraud and distributing substandard drugs, and was fined $500 million. "This case represents the largest false claims prosecution in the District of Maryland and the biggest financial penalty ever imposed on a generic drug company," said U.S. Attorney Rod J. Rosenstein at the time. "When companies distribute contaminated or ineffective drugs, they compromise the FDA’s approval process and put patients at serious risk," added Stuart F. Delery, acting assistant attorney general for the Department of Justice. The report stated that the Department of Justice alleged Ranbaxy's diluted medications "increased the risk of harm and death" among patients. Blackburn questioned, "How many lives were lost because of this? How many people were misled?" The possibility that CHAI distributed compromised HIV medications could damage the reputation of the Clinton charity and raise new concerns during Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign. Blackburn submitted the report to the inspector generals at the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of State, where Hillary Clinton served as secretary of state. The study also revealed troubling connections between Bill Clinton and two Indian-American figures who had previously faced regulatory actions from the FDA and SEC. The most alarming findings involved the Clinton Foundation’s continued promotion of Ranbaxy despite evidence of repeated quality control failures and attempts to conceal them through misleading reports to the FDA. It remains unclear how many AIDS patients received these weakened

What emerged, however, was in structure and visual style reminiscent of previous debates — two individuals behind podiums — only this time featuring a veteran statesman and an inexperienced candidate. And it was Trump, expected to shine with charisma, who at times appeared unsettled, one of several distractions that had less to do with the substance of his remarks than with how he delivered them. The back-and-forth didn’t result in a standout performance, to be sure, as political spectacle. But for those who believed that hosting "The Apprentice" would prepare Trump for this kind of event, it turns out that the skills required were quite different from what he needed on that night. Clinton, clearly, entered the debate with a clear plan: to appear composed, confident, and largely unbothered by Trump’s comments, while slipping in a few well-rehearsed jabs. This included mentioning that she had thoroughly prepared for the debate, offering a sharp contrast to some of Trump's scattered responses. There were also effective moments, such as when she responded to one of Trump's long-winded answers by saying, "Just listen to what you just heard." Related: One thing Clinton and Trump didn't debate: the debate itself. Trump, on the other hand, having faced numerous opponents during the primary season, seemed out of place in this one-on-one setting. With so many candidates on stage before, his aggressive style stood out; here, with only Clinton to contend with, it was harder to maintain that same approach. He interrupted Clinton frequently — initially to make a point, but as the debate continued, those interruptions increasingly felt like frustration, as if the attack ads she had been running against him (which he mentioned) had gotten under his skin. Trump’s persistent coughing throughout also became a distraction — not a major issue in theory, but one that social media was quick to mock. His attempts to dominate certain topics created challenges for the third participant in this mini-drama, Lester Holt. Holt, the "NBC Nightly News" anchor, faced perhaps the most difficult task imaginable, given all the anticipation beforehand and the inevitable post-debate analysis. Holt handled himself adequately, occasionally fact-checking Trump’s claims — especially when he tried to deny direct quotes attributed to him — and pushing him for concrete answers. Those moments when he challenged the candidate may not have gone over well with Trump's most loyal supporters, but Holt avoided the role of a passive moderator who simply asks questions and stays out

What would you do if a group of angry people blocked your path on the road? You slow down, trying to see if they’ll let you pass, but instead of moving, they start walking toward you. You remember the incident in which a man was attacked by a crowd, and now you're faced with a choice: try to drive through and risk harming someone, or stop and risk being attacked yourself. What’s your move? Maybe it's how I was raised, but I've always believed that when your life is in danger, your first priority has to be survival. I'm not alone in that thinking. A recent event at the University of Wisconsin shows just how dangerous it can be to block a road with protests. In the video below, you can see a group of demonstrators taking over the street. But one driver clearly has somewhere to go. Instead of stopping, they speed forward, knocking over a protester. Watch the video below:  
Some say the protest was about police brutality, but that’s not what this was about. The group was upset over racist graffiti that had been painted on the university walls—words like “KKK” and “Go back to Africa.” The message was removed, and the school apologized, but the anger didn’t fade. Black Lives Matter activists were furious. Let’s be clear—there’s no shame in putting your own safety first. It’s better to risk hitting someone than to be hurt or robbed by a group that thinks they’re entitled to take from you. As the saying goes, “Better to be judged by 12 than carried by six.” This isn’t just about protecting your home—it’s about protecting yourself. When you’re surrounded by an angry crowd that wants violence, there’s no good reason to stop. What would you do in that situation? Would you keep going, or would you hit the brakes?

We’ve all seen political promises that backfire. One of the most infamous was “read my lips…no new taxes,” which helped George H.W. Bush win an election but ultimately led to the largest tax hike in history. Now, Donald Trump has made a statement that could rival that fiasco. In response to the weekend attacks in Chelsea and Minnesota, he promised to “destroy the threat of terrorism” in America. But what does that really mean?  

Take a look at this statement from @JasonMillerinDC:  
Statement on Last Weekend’s Terror Attacks https://t.co/DZlIvkcHmB pic.twitter.com/l3EVTvLcfO — Official Team Trump (@TeamTrump) September 19, 2016  

While the attacks were tragic, Trump didn’t offer a realistic plan to combat terrorism—no strategy for countering online radicalization, no proposal for increasing counterterrorism funding. Instead, he spoke about “destroying” terrorists and ending the threat “on our soil.” That kind of language is dangerous. It implies a broad, sweeping approach that could lead to racial or religious profiling.  

Consider the case of a suspect being investigated by the FBI. He may be a Muslim, but he's also an American citizen with rights. Under Trump’s rhetoric, he might be treated as a target without due process. This kind of blanket statement opens the door to a new kind of fear-based policy—one that could lead to increased surveillance in Muslim communities, mass detention, or even worse.  

If you think this is just political hyperbole, consider the implications. Trump’s words suggest a vision where terrorism is not just fought, but eradicated through extreme measures. That kind of mindset is not only unrealistic—it’s reminiscent of authoritarian tactics. The promise to “destroy” terrorism sounds appealing to some, but it’s more likely another empty slogan designed to play on fear rather than address real problems.  

Like so many of his campaign promises, this one is more about emotion than substance. And just like the “read my lips” line, it’s probably another empty promise that will collapse under scrutiny. The truth is, terrorism isn’t something you can simply “destroy” with a catchy phrase. It takes real policy, real leadership, and real solutions—not fearmongering.

Since the Nixon era, Americans have been fed a narrative that suggests inherited wealth is more legitimate than income earned through work. Republicans push for complete tax exemption on all inheritances, while Democrats generally oppose this stance. The current system taxes only estates worth $5.45 million or more ($10.9 million for married couples), leaving everything below that untouched. Now, Joe Biden, under pressure from progressive voices like Elizabeth Warren and her supporters, has updated his approach to estate taxation—and let me tell you, the children of billionaires won’t be pleased. Initially, Biden proposed reinstating the 2009 estate tax rate of 40 percent, lowering the threshold to $3.5 million. But now, he’s shifted course, adopting a plan similar to his former rival, and is pushing for a progressive estate tax that increases the top rate to 65 percent. The last time the tax reached such a level was in 1981, when it also applied to smaller estates. In addition, Biden has indicated he would eliminate the "step-up in basis" rule, which lets heirs avoid capital gains taxes on assets they inherit. Overall, the proposal is expected to generate roughly $200 billion over the next decade. Source: The New Republic  
Currently, the estate tax system is a farce. In 2015, over $1.4 trillion was transferred through inheritance, with less than 1 percent actually taxed. The Republican claim that estate taxes harm small businesses is misleading—only 25 family-owned farms and small businesses paid estate taxes nationwide in 2014. Another common argument is that estate taxes constitute "double taxation," but this ignores the fact that much of the wealth in large estates comes from untaxed capital gains. Even if Biden wins, passing this reform will be difficult, especially with Mitch McConnell controlling the Senate. He wants to ensure that the offspring of the wealthy pay nothing in estate taxes. And let's not forget—Biden himself may not pay any taxes at all.

I woke up this morning to see a similar headline trending on my social media: Here’s Facebook: Naturally, my first thought was, “Oh no, what did Bill Clinton do this time to mess up his wife’s campaign?” The headline sounded extremely damaging, playing right into the narrative that the Clinton Foundation is all about backdoor deals — something Trump has been repeating for years. But if you look past the headlines, which most people don’t, you’ll find the truth — there’s no evidence of any pay-to-play scheme. “It was normal for people who were our allies and friends to reach out and ask for help,” Clinton said in an interview with *The New York Times* last week. “And I assumed the State Department would handle things appropriately.” Source: *The Daily Beast* In short, people might have made requests, but that doesn’t mean they received favors. Emails released during the investigation show that some donors met with Clinton, while others were denied. There's no proof that anything was exchanged for influence. Meanwhile, let's not forget about the foundation the media rarely brings up — the Trump Foundation. Trump hasn't contributed to it since 2008, but he's collected money from others and used it under his name. Reports suggest he spent charity funds on personal items like a $15,000 portrait of himself and a custom football helmet. New York Attorney General Letitia James recently stated that her office is looking into Trump’s charitable organization, citing concerns over potential violations of state charity laws. This comes after *The Washington Post* reported that Trump allegedly used donor money for personal gain, including reselling contributions to make them look like they came from him. Source: *Media Matters* Media Matters highlights the unfair double standard in how the press covers Trump and Clinton. Last month, TV news outlets covered Clinton’s brief illness more than 10 times as much as they covered the Trump Foundation story. This week, coverage of Trump’s charity issues was minimal compared to the attention given to his appearance on *The Dr. Oz Show*. This biased reporting is helping Trump and hurting Clinton. Trump has gained significant momentum lately, partly because the media focuses on every small Clinton issue — like her health — while ignoring the many controversies surrounding Trump, which are numerous.

I’d say our leader is ineffective, but this goes way beyond that — it's outright indifference. He’s made some questionable decisions and said a few thoughtless things in the past, but this? This is just out of touch in the worst way. If you're following the news, you already know about the shootings in Chicago and Dallas last week, plus the fire at the courthouse in Atlanta. You'd expect someone in his position to at least acknowledge these tragedies, especially when they happened on American soil. You'd hope the people who elected him would show some compassion, even if it's just for political reasons. But apparently, our leader doesn’t see it that way. I’ll provide more updates as I get them.” But no, he didn’t even do that. Unbelievable.

Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt were once considered one of Hollywood's most iconic power couples. However, it seems their relationship has come to an end: Angelina Jolie has officially filed for divorce. At 41, Jolie cited irreconcilable differences as the reason for ending her two-year marriage to Pitt. The couple first met in 2004 while filming *Mr. and Mrs. Smith*, at a time when Pitt was still married to actress Jennifer Aniston. They divorced in early 2005, and just months later, Pitt and Jolie began dating, with Jolie introducing him to their adopted son Maddox. She later adopted a daughter from Ethiopia and became pregnant with Pitt’s child. The pair welcomed another adopted child in 2007 and then had twins in 2008.  

Although they were together since 2004, the couple didn’t get engaged until 2012, reportedly waiting to marry until same-sex couples could also legally wed. Some sources claim Jolie was frustrated with Pitt’s parenting methods, feeling he wasn’t always reliable around the kids, was upset about his alleged drug use, and believed he had unresolved anger issues. It’s also been said that Jolie hired a private investigator to monitor Pitt during the filming of his latest project in London, suspecting he was being unfaithful. Those concerns were reportedly confirmed by the investigator.  

Jolie is widely recognized for her humanitarian efforts and serves as a United Nations special envoy, recently addressing the UN on behalf of Syrian refugees. Meanwhile, Pitt was said to be more focused on his film career and social life. According to reports, Jolie is seeking full custody of their six children, with Pitt limited to visitation rights. She is being represented by attorney Laura Wasser, who previously handled Amber Heard’s divorce from Johnny Depp.

At a campaign event in Ohio, Trump expressed frustration over the suspect being treated by top doctors and having a strong defense attorney. "We're giving him amazing medical care, a nice room, maybe even room service. And he's got a great lawyer who will drag this out for years. In the end, he might walk away with just a slap on the wrist. What a disgrace," Trump said. He also called for quick trials and harsh sentencing, suggesting that "any legal methods" should be used to extract information from the suspect before it's too late. Here's the video via YouTube. The Fifth Amendment states: No person shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law. Farooq is innocent until proven guilty, so denying him proper medical care could result in serious harm or even death, violating his right to due process. The Sixth Amendment ensures that everyone has the right to a lawyer, regardless of the crime they're accused of. This principle is deeply rooted in American history, as seen in the actions of Thomas Jefferson, who defended British soldiers after the Boston Massacre. In short, no one should be denied their legal rights based on their background or religion. But Trump seems to want to rewrite the Constitution to favor only certain people.

Seahawks Quarterback Russell Wilson has always been open about his deep faith and commitment to helping others. For him, serving his community and guiding people toward a more meaningful life is just as important as his role on the football field. Off the field, Wilson focuses on spreading hope and positivity through his actions, believing that true joy comes from making good choices and having faith in something greater. On the field, he's all about winning, but off the field, his mission is clear: to inspire others to find peace and purpose. When the NFL asked him to refrain from discussing his faith, it didn’t stop him from sharing his message. He believes that actions speak louder than words. Wilson has often said that God comes first in his life, followed by family and friends, and then football. This order, he says, keeps him grounded and focused. “Faith is everything to me,” he once said. “If you put things in the right order, good things happen. You don’t get caught up in the noise.” It’s inspiring to see someone with such influence using their platform for good. Unfortunately, many in positions of power start with good intentions but eventually lose sight of what truly matters. They begin to seek recognition for themselves instead of staying true to their roots. Some might call it luck, but I think it’s more about character. In a world where corruption is widespread and truth is often twisted, it’s rare to see someone like Wilson who remains steadfast in his beliefs. The NFL told him to stay quiet about his faith—strange how some things are treated as sensitive while others are not. It’s one thing to avoid talking about God, but it’s another to ignore the values that have shaped our country and its heroes. In this climate, the truth becomes harder to see. Words like “tolerance” are used to blur the lines between right and wrong. When men like Wilson stand firm in their convictions, they face strong opposition. Ask yourself, when did doing good and helping others become a bad thing? There’s only one force that seeks to prevent good from happening. And in Obama’s America, it seems many have forgotten that truth.

Doesn't this outrage you, just a little? The way the NFL and college athletes are treating the national anthem these days, especially with the Black Lives Matter movement, it's like nothing can stop them. But when someone speaks out against BLM, they get punished—like a full season suspension. Seattle Mariners' star pitcher Jake Reynolds was just suspended for criticizing Black Lives Matter and President Obama. "BLM is a joke! Obama is a disgrace! Everyone involved in these riots should be thrown in jail!" he wrote on his social media. He also posted, "Black people attacking whites after a black officer shot a thug—haha, that’s funny! Keep kneeling for the anthem!" The team released a statement on Thursday saying he would be suspended for the rest of the season without pay. According to reports, Reynolds could lose around $40,000 in earnings. And naturally, the apology followed. In a statement, Reynolds said, "I want to sincerely apologize to the Seattle Mariners, my teammates, my family, and the fans for the distraction my tweets caused. I never intended to be offensive or racist. My comments were in response to what I saw on the news and were poorly worded. I understand how they could be misinterpreted." "I grew up in Chicago, a city I love, and I was raised in a diverse neighborhood. I’ve always valued people for who they are, not what color they are. My friends have never been defined by race, and I’ve never been judgmental. I just hope people don’t judge me based on one tweet." "I believe in free speech and supporting law enforcement. I’m frustrated by what’s happening in the world and want to be part of the solution. I hope we can all work together to make things better." "Once again, I apologize to anyone I may have offended and ask that you not judge me based on social media. Thank you and God bless." While BLM continues to cause chaos, destroy property, and put police in danger, they still get support from officials like DC saying, "We feel your pain." Meanwhile, this guy gets hit with a severe punishment for just expressing his views online. Sometimes I really wish this world was different—and this is one of those times.

Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's campaign is in chaos, and he's trying to squeeze as much public funding as possible before facing a decisive defeat at the polls by Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. According to recent FEC disclosures, Trump's team has allegedly bilked the U.S. Secret Service out of $1.6 million for the "privilege" of guarding him. The Secret Service typically reimburses campaigns for the costs associated with agents traveling with candidates, usually covering airfare and then being repaid by the campaign. However, Trump has exploited this system by using his own company, TAG Air, Inc., to charter flights for the Secret Service, effectively allowing him to profit from the arrangement. In contrast, Clinton’s campaign has used Executive Fliteways, a company with no ties to her or her team, ensuring no personal financial gain. While Trump supporters would surely be furious if Clinton were benefiting from such arrangements, their outrage seems to be selective. Trump’s campaign maintains that all actions were fully compliant with FEC rules. A spokesperson, Hope Hicks, stated, “We followed all guidelines and regulations. For more information, please contact the Secret Service.” Additionally, there are reports that Trump may be extracting money from media outlets for the travel expenses of journalists accompanying his campaign. It’s also rumored that the Secret Service has been forced to pay for Trump’s stays at his luxurious gold-plated hotels, as he often chooses to stay at his own properties, reportedly due to his preference for the cheapest Chinese-made beds available.

Congressional investigators and intelligence agencies are looking into whether one of Donald Trump’s so-called foreign policy "advisors" has been engaging in secret conversations with senior Russian government officials, some of whom are currently under U.S. sanctions. According to several sources, these discussions have reportedly focused on the potential for a future Trump administration to remove the economic penalties imposed on Russia following its 2014 annexation of Crimea, an act that Trump has consistently refused to condemn. The adviser in question, Michael Flynn, is a former military official who previously worked as a consultant for a Washington-based firm specializing in energy sector relations with Russian entities. He is based just a few blocks from Trump's office in New York. Flynn was first publicly named by Trump in March as part of his "foreign policy team," a group that includes conservative military figures, Middle Eastern sympathizers, and former officials from Iraq. Since then, he has become one of Trump’s most visible foreign policy voices, though the campaign insists he is not officially affiliated with the ticket. Flynn has deep financial ties to Russia, including investments in Rosneft, the country’s largest private oil company, and has frequently traveled to Moscow for meetings with high-ranking Russian officials. A U.S. diplomat in Moscow described him as “unapologetic in defending Russian actions.” Particular attention is being paid to Flynn’s trip to Moscow in May, where he met with Sergey Ivanov, a long-time Putin ally and former deputy prime minister who now serves as an advisor to Rosneft and is under U.S. sanctions. According to multiple U.S. officials in the region, Flynn reportedly discussed with Ivanov strategies to lift the American sanctions, a move that would significantly benefit his business interests. Earlier this year, Flynn told a news outlet that “many of my contacts have suffered due to the sanctions” and expressed hope for “a more favorable environment.” During that same trip, Flynn also met with Alexei Gromov, a top Kremlin official involved in shaping Russia’s election interference strategy, according to U.S. intelligence assessments. The initial inquiry into Flynn stemmed from the congressional probe into Russia’s hacking of the Democratic National Committee and voter systems in several U.S. states. While Democratic leaders in the House and Senate have concluded that Russian intelligence agencies are actively working to sway the U.S. election—actions they say only come from the highest levels of the Russian government—Trump has shown no typical bravado in the face of this unprecedented

Donald Trump took to the airwaves on Monday morning and blamed the recent attacks in New Jersey and New York City on refugees, insufficient law enforcement screening, and the First Amendment. Conservatives, he claimed, always bypass the First Amendment and focus only on the Second. While Trump criticized refugees, the bombing suspect, Ahmad Khan Rahami, 28, is actually a naturalized U.S. citizen. During a segment on Fox & Friends, a host asked Trump how he would stop "radicalized individuals here." In response, Trump pointed the finger at "freedom of the press," claiming, "They're all talking about it so beautifully because it's called 'freedom of the press,' where you buy magazines and they tell you how to make these bombs that I saw." He added, "They tell you how to make bombs. We should arrest the people who do that because they're committing a crime. Instead, they say, 'Oh no, you can't do anything—this is freedom of expression.'" He continued, "The websites are the same thing; those people should be arrested. They're inciting violence, okay? They're making violence possible. They should be arrested immediately… yet we don’t want to touch them because of freedom of speech." Watch the full exchange around the 21-minute mark: [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3GTRabASaY8] However, incitement is already an exception under the First Amendment. Think Progress notes that proving incitement is a high standard—and Trump may have good reason to be thankful for that. Under a more lenient interpretation, he could potentially face charges for his own rhetoric. Earlier this year, his comment that "Second Amendment people" might take action against Hillary Clinton drew sharp criticism as a veiled threat. On Friday, he urged Clinton’s security team to "disarm immediately," adding, "Let’s see what happens to her." Trump has frequently attacked the freedom of the press. Most recently, his campaign had a VICE reporter detained. The GOP nominee has also defended Vladimir Putin for killing journalists. When confronted by Joe Scarborough about Putin’s record with media, Trump said, "He's running his country, and at least he's a leader. Unlike what we have here." Freedom of the press is part of the Constitution. It's not up for debate—unless Melania Trump wants to sue bloggers for quoting sources. But if you ask Donald Trump Jr

On Tuesday, Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) took to Twitter to reference the arrest of a suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing investigation, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, as a way to subtly criticize NFL quarterback Tom Brady, in what appeared to be a poorly timed effort to link Brady’s recent social activism with acts of violence. Rubio tweeted “You’re welcome” following the announcement of Tsarnaev’s capture, seemingly implying that Brady should be grateful for the country’s security efforts. Rubio likely expected the tweet to position him as a voice of reason and highlight his stance on law and order, but instead, the internet quickly turned against him. His passive-aggressive jab was swiftly labeled as “Thanks, Brady” by online critics, drawing comparisons to the “Thanks, Obama” trend that once mocked conservative attempts to tie unrelated events to presidential policies. The tweet gained traction among several high-profile accounts, including CNN’s Anderson Cooper, who briefly shared it, amplifying the backlash. In the end, Rubio’s attempt to make a political point backfired spectacularly, and many are hoping he takes the lesson to heart—instead of using national tragedies to boost his own image.

What do Tom Brady and Russell Wilson have in common? Neither is a starting quarterback in the NFL anymore. The other difference is that Tom Brady is a champion and highly admired. The other is a fraud. Tom Brady was very brief when a reporter asked him about Russell Wilson's recent comments on social injustice and the treatment of minorities in America. Brady is known for his leadership, calm demeanor, and ability to win games. His response to Wilson’s remarks was as follows… “When people have strong opinions,” said Brady, “it’s important to express them, but it’s also important to do so with respect and consideration.” The key word here is “respect,” which Wilson seems to be missing, especially given that he’s still getting paid to sit on the bench. He’s a high-earning backup who doesn’t seem to care about the fans or the values this country stands for. If he wants to speak out, that’s fine, but he should do it outside of the stadium, not during the national anthem. He can take to social media, join a peaceful protest, or even go to a community event. There are plenty of ways to make a statement without undermining the game or the flag. And let’s not forget that no one in this country is truly oppressed. Saying you're oppressed is just an excuse for not working hard enough. How did Martin Luther King Jr. achieve his goals? Was he oppressed? He fought for change, not handouts. The guy worked for what he got, so he wasn’t oppressed. Name one person who actually is oppressed, and I’ll show you why they’re not making the most of their opportunities. I can tell you what they could be doing instead of blaming others. If anyone is really oppressed, it’s the people who lost out because of policies meant to help others. Tom Brady didn’t say much because he knows better than to get caught up in controversy. He’s focused on his future and helping the team he’s on. Good for Brady, and I hope he finds a new role where he can continue to lead. Screw Wilson.

Newly uncovered video has added alarming details to a 2011 police shooting in St. Louis, revealing an officer fatally shooting a Black man and then placing a weapon at the scene. Officer Jason Stockley and his partner Brian Bianchi were involved in a high-speed pursuit of drug suspect Anthony Lamar Smith. In the footage, Stockley is heard saying, “I’m going to kill this guy.” The police forced Smith off the road, and the video shows Stockley firing five shots into the driver’s side of the stopped vehicle. Additional footage now shows Stockley retrieving a gun from a bag in the back of his patrol car and placing it on Smith’s body. Stockley claimed in his report that Smith had aimed the gun at him, justifying the deadly action. However, DNA testing on the weapon found no traces of Smith’s genetic material or fingerprints. Stockley is now facing charges of first-degree murder, with an initial court hearing scheduled for October 3rd. The footage of the incident can be viewed here:

Democratic National Committee interim Chairwoman Donna Brazile appeared on CNN’s “Early Start” Monday and addressed Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton’s sudden decline on September 11. What was meant to be a supportive comment quickly became an unexpected revelation about the seriousness of Clinton’s condition that day. “She had to be helped into the vehicle, but she still showed up and kept going, just like all of us do,” Brazile said, as reported by The Daily Caller. This is the first time a member of Clinton's team has openly acknowledged that the former secretary of state required assistance getting into the van, which raises serious questions about her physical stability. What seemed like a praise turned into a damaging admission for the campaign. Many are now wondering exactly how Clinton managed to stand on her own and what it took for her to do so. While Clinton has admitted to having pneumonia, this doesn’t erase her history of withholding critical health information from the public. She claimed she didn’t think it was important to disclose her diagnosis, but with the media constantly scrutinizing her health, it’s clear that her condition has become a major concern — one she can no longer ignore. Clinton’s incident on September 11 was widely seen, including by international leaders who may now view her health as a vulnerability. Hillary Clinton was widely reported as the victor of last night’s debate by major news outlets, but social media sentiment told a different story. The #TrumpWon hashtag quickly gained traction online and eventually became the top trending topic in the U.S. on Twitter. “The #TrumpWon trend is now number one — thanks everyone!” — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump), September 27, 2016. What’s surprising isn’t just that it trended, but where it started — a revelation that may shock many: According to Trendsmap.com, the #TrumpWon hashtag first appeared in Saint Petersburg, Russia, the same city where President Vladimir Putin is believed to maintain a large network of state-sponsored online operatives. These individuals, often referred to as cyber-trolls, are part of a broader disinformation strategy known as *dezinformatsiya*, aimed at sowing confusion and deepening divisions among Western nations. Russian state media has previously been caught promoting pro-Trump content across American platforms, while simultaneously portraying him favorably to European audiences. Analysts suggest that Putin's goal is to influence the election in favor of Trump, someone he believes could ease the economic pressure on Russian elites and allow Moscow greater freedom in its foreign policy, particularly in Eastern Europe. Former participants in these operations have described their work environment as highly controlled and stressful, with strict quotas and heavy penalties for noncompliance. Trolls worked in cramped offices under constant supervision, with managers reviewing every post for ideological consistency. So next time you see a viral hashtag or read an aggressive comment, remember: it could be coming from a low-wage worker in a dimly lit room, simply trying to make ends meet.

The government’s response to every failed initiative or underperforming agency is simply to pour more taxpayer funds into it. Since public education became the standard, students have become increasingly uninformed and unprepared. Yet, proponents of big government argue that the issue is always a lack of funding. So, they keep throwing money at the problem, and the issues only worsen. When the War on Drugs was launched, over $1.5 trillion was spent, yet drug use has remained steady or even increased. Rather than rethinking the strategy or addressing constitutional concerns, officials continue to fund the same approach, hoping for a different outcome. The same pattern repeats with the "War on Terror." The U.S. has invested nearly $5 trillion in counterterrorism efforts, yet global terrorism has surged. Instead of examining our foreign policy, especially in the Middle East, lawmakers just expand military operations and increase funding. Terrorism keeps growing. According to a report by Dr. Neta Crawford from Brown University, spending on defense, state, homeland security, and veterans since 9/11 has reached almost $5 trillion. Before we question how a country with over $19.3 trillion in debt can afford such massive war spending, the real question is: What has this money actually accomplished? As Reader Supported News noted last year, terrorism has risen by 6,500% since 2002—perhaps it should be called the “War of Terror.” In 2014, it was reported that 74% of terror-related deaths occurred in Iraq, Nigeria, Afghanistan, Pakistan, or Syria. As Paul Gottinger from Reader Supported News pointed out, only Nigeria didn’t face U.S. air strikes or military presence that year. However, the U.S. has long been involved in Nigerian affairs. Why wouldn’t they? Nigeria used to be Africa’s top oil producer and largest economy until recently. Ben Swann highlights a shocking fact: “Before the 2003 invasion, there were zero suicide attacks in Iraq. None in the country’s history. But since then, there have been 1,892.” Before the war, over 1.5 million Christians lived in Iraq. Afterward, more than a million fled to Syria. Today, fewer than 500,000 remain, many now targeted by groups like ISIS. As terrorism threatens national security, the government keeps passing new laws that chip away at our

An allegedly unarmed, mentally disabled white man experiencing a medical episode was shot by police on Monday afternoon. The incident occurred shortly after his brother called 911 for emergency help. Police in Riverside, California — near Los Angeles — tweeted that officers encountered a "disturbed individual" that resulted in an officer-involved shooting. The victim, later identified as Marcus Thompson, was reportedly 28 years old. Activist and community organizer Lisa Nguyen shared on Twitter that Thompson had succumbed to his injuries. Officers responded to a disturbed individual that ended with an officer involved shooting. We will share more details as they become available. — Riverside Police (@RiversidePD) October 5, 2017  

A source close to the family confirmed there was a fatal police shooting in Riverside. The victim’s name is Marcus Thompson. I’m at the scene and saw the aftermath. — Lisa Nguyen (@LisaNguyen123) October 6, 2017  

In a live stream on Facebook, journalist Jordan Lee interviewed Thompson’s brother, who said his sibling was having a severe panic attack and had not been armed. The brother claimed he called for medical assistance, but police arrived and shot Thompson within minutes. “I just wanted help, not for them to kill him,” the brother cried. “I should have called for mental health support instead of the police.”  

During a live report from the scene, local news anchor Rachel Kim captured statements from two witnesses who said Thompson was shot while holding his hands up. “I saw a man surrounded by officers, arms raised, and then they just started shooting,” one witness said, mimicking the position. “He wasn’t moving, just standing there. They fired multiple times.” Watch the full clip: #Periscope https://t.co/xyz123abc — Rachel Kim (@RachelKimNBC) October 5, 2017  

According to KABC, police took cell phones from several bystanders at a nearby café and instructed them not to share any footage. The American Civil Liberties Union of Riverside released a statement condemning the seizure. “Taking people's phones without a warrant or legal justification violates both the Fourth and First Amendments,” said ACLU attorney Michael Torres. “There is no justification for this kind of interference.” However, the police department denied the claims, stating that no phones were taken. We urge the public to avoid spreading false information. No phones were confiscated at the scene. —

The latest early polls from last night’s debate are now released, showing a clear advantage for Hillary Clinton, who displayed composure, confidence, and expertise in contrast to Donald Trump, whose frequent interruptions and unclear statements left many viewers unimpressed. According to a breakdown by VOX, the results are striking: A poll of debate viewers conducted by CNN/ORC found that 64 percent believed Clinton emerged victorious, while 26 percent favored Trump. Although CNN's David Chalian noted that the sample leaned 12 points more Democratic than usual, the margin still reflects a strong performance for Clinton. Another survey by Public Policy Polling showed 53 percent thought Clinton won, compared to 39 percent for Trump. In a separate focus group of 25 undecided voters in Nevada, 21 said Clinton had the upper hand. Meanwhile, a GOP-affiliated poll by Frank Luntz found that Pennsylvania voters overwhelmingly felt Clinton won. Libby Nelson provides further insight here. This decisive lead is significant, as nearly half of likely voters have stated that the debates will influence their choice. It appears that substance, experience, and credibility continue to resonate with the electorate, and last night’s debate reinforced that Clinton has those qualities in abundance.

Kathy Miller, the campaign chair for Trump in Butler County, Pennsylvania—a key battleground in the state—made one of the most outlandish remarks of the election season. She claimed that racial discrimination only began after the election of President Obama. This statement, which is not only factually incorrect but also deeply offensive, has sparked widespread outrage. In an interview with a local news outlet, Miller stated, “I don’t think there was any racism before Obama was elected. We didn’t have these issues back then.” It’s hard to believe someone could genuinely think that, but apparently, she does. 

She went on to make further damaging comments about the Black community, suggesting that if Black people haven’t succeeded in the last 50 years, it’s entirely their own fault. “You had the same schools, you had benefits that white kids didn’t have, and you still didn’t take advantage,” she said. Such remarks ignore the long history of systemic inequality, from slavery to Jim Crow, and the ongoing challenges faced by Black Americans today.

Racism didn’t start with Obama—it’s been embedded in our country’s foundations for centuries. Black people have dealt with segregation, discriminatory laws, and unequal access to education and opportunity. The criminal justice system continues to disproportionately target Black communities, and schools in Black neighborhoods are often underfunded and overcrowded. The economic disadvantages faced by Black families are not new—they’re the result of generations of oppression.

It’s alarming that someone in a major political campaign can so openly dismiss these realities. Her comments reflect a dangerous ignorance that undermines the very principles of fairness and equality we should be striving for. Fortunately, Miller faced significant backlash and eventually stepped down from her position. But the fact that such views are still being voiced in a presidential campaign is deeply troubling.

They’ve just announced a sweeping new policy that will hit protestors hard — anyone caught participating in riots, looting, or any form of unlawful destruction will lose their government assistance for good.  

This isn’t just about the adults. Any minors involved in the violence will also face the same penalties, and their parents could be held responsible as well. Parents of minors who take part in the unrest may lose their benefits, be referred to child protection services, and could even risk losing custody of their children. “Parents must be accountable for their kids’ actions,” said local official Maria Delgado at a press briefing. “If your child is out causing damage or engaging in violent behavior, you’ll share in the consequences.”  

Many of those arrested are teenagers from local high schools. Officials are urging parents to monitor their children closely and enforce the new curfew. “This is a serious situation,” Delgado added. “If your child is involved in this, it’s time to step up as a parent.”  

Will this new rule stop the violence? Will it prevent opportunists from using tragedy as a cover for lawlessness? It's unclear, but one thing is certain — the message is clear now. Parents may finally start taking their responsibilities more seriously, and protesters will think twice before breaking the law. The city is working to bring calm back, but for now, the streets remain tense.

Through the course of this election cycle, a persistent question has loomed over Trump’s campaign – not just one, but many. A cloud of confusion, secrecy, and controversy. But the main issue being discussed is “why hasn’t Trump released his tax returns?” The answer, as Trump revealed during the first presidential debate, is that he has not paid federal income taxes for years. Trump criticized Clinton for mismanaging public funds, claiming it has hurt vital infrastructure projects — a stance that contradicts the Republican platform he usually supports. Clinton seized the moment to push back, saying, “Maybe because you haven’t paid any federal income tax in a long time.” She set the trap, and Trump walked right into it. In an attempt to defend himself, he accidentally confirmed her claim: “It would be squandered too, believe me.” Note the word “would.” If Trump had actually paid taxes, he wouldn’t have used that phrasing. Earlier in the debate, he called paying taxes “smart,” yet now he’s avoiding disclosure. Is this why he’s resisting releasing his returns, claiming he’ll do so “against his lawyer’s advice” if Clinton releases her emails? Could it be that Trump is hiding the fact that he’s avoided his tax responsibilities? When Trump says “believe me,” take it with a grain of salt — not because his taxes would be “squandered,” but because he believes they “would” if he had paid them. A top Trump ally in Silicon Valley is now facing a major federal investigation over alleged racial bias in hiring, as the U.S. Department of Labor has filed a lawsuit against the tech firm One Medical, which is owned by Republican donor and venture capitalist Reid Hoffman. The lawsuit claims that the company, based in San Francisco, engaged in discriminatory practices against Asian applicants during its hiring process. One Medical, which provides healthcare services to federal employees, is also a contractor for several government agencies. Sources suggest that Trump is considering a high-profile judicial appointment for Hoffman, who has openly criticized free speech protections, antitrust regulations, and democratic institutions. Both Hoffman and the Trump campaign have denied the allegations. According to the lawsuit, out of 150 engineering interns hired, 70% were Asian, yet only 12 Asians were selected compared to 38 non-Asians. “The probability of this outcome occurring by chance is less than one in a million,” the filing states. Interestingly, Hoffman, who was once considered an unlikely Trump supporter, is himself the son of immigrants who came to the U.S. for better opportunities. Now, he's backing a candidate who has taken strong anti-immigration stances. Hoffman, a co-founder of LinkedIn and early investor in Facebook, gained broader public attention after revealing his involvement in funding a legal battle that led to the collapse of the website Jezebel, in retaliation for exposing his personal life. Recently, he made headlines at the Republican National Convention by openly identifying as gay, criticizing the party’s focus on bathroom policies and declaring, “Every American has a right to their identity. I’m proud to be gay and proud to be a Republican.” His speech, which received mixed reactions from the audience, came amid a GOP platform that included some of the most restrictive policies toward LGBTQ+ rights in recent history. “Federal contractors must uphold the principle of equal opportunity,” said OFCCP Director Patricia Shiu. “Taxpayers deserve transparency and fairness in how companies with public contracts treat job applicants.” A spokesperson for One Medical stated the company will “fight the accusations” and denies any wrongdoing. Now, the executive who once criticized government inefficiency will have to defend his company’s practices in court, despite the troubling data presented in the lawsuit.

I’m ready to join the global community. Scene number two – London, United Kingdom: I feel nervous. I’ve just stepped onto British soil for the first time. I’m excited. I’m filled with hope, but also anxious. It’s a new chapter. I’m chasing a better future, yet I’m still afraid. What if this is all just a fantasy? Scene number three – Manchester, England: I’m not dreaming – it’s real. I’m sitting in my first class in the UK. I pinched myself to confirm I wasn’t asleep. Scene number four – a few weeks after arriving: I had a terrible nightmare. I walked out of the classroom to see the faculty, staff, and students lined up. At the front, there was a TV in the dean’s office. A major explosion had taken place. I prayed it wasn’t true, that it was just a bad dream. But it was real. I was awake, and it was happening. Scene number five – I joined the line, my heart pounding: What if they were from my country? Please God, don’t let them be from my country. The news broke — the attackers were from my homeland, and worse, the leader was from my city. I was stunned. I covered my face in shame and tried to walk away. A British professor placed a hand on my shoulder with empathy. An older student whispered: “Be careful. Some people might react badly.” I didn’t have a car then, but a British woman I barely knew offered to drive me home. I came here to study and build a life in a progressive country. Later, I realized the greatest benefit was being among open-minded people. Scene number six – many weeks later, I was at the airport: I was being questioned at security every time I flew. Hillary Clinton, former Secretary of State, has remained consistent in her assertion that she turned over all of her official emails. Despite wiping her computer using advanced digital erasure methods, not just a regular wipe, she claims there's nothing to conceal. The twist is that even as fresh batches of emails have come to light, she continues to stand by her original statement. Recently, 30 emails resurfaced from her deleted server—emails that weren’t part of the so-called “complete” set she initially provided. These newly found messages were linked to the Benghazi incident, raising questions about what she knew at the time.  

FBI investigators uncovered the 30 emails from Clinton’s wiped server, which discussed the Benghazi attack, according to government attorneys during a court hearing on Tuesday. The disclosure came in a case involving Judicial Watch, a watchdog group, before U.S. District Court Judge Amit Mehta. The government stated that some of the recovered emails contained search terms connected to Benghazi.  

Clinton had submitted over 30,000 of her work emails to the State Department in December 2014. Of those, only 296 were released related to Benghazi and Libya, with the agency claiming they were the full set. However, in September, an additional 925 Benghazi-related emails were discovered and handed to the House Select Committee on Benghazi. It was also revealed last month that Clinton had deleted thousands of work-related emails from her server.  

Is it really taking a full day to process each recovered email? There must be something significant in there… Intriguing.

A strange package was discovered outside a Burger King in Midtown, causing a temporary shutdown of 47th Street between Broadway and Sixth Avenue. The New York Police Department cordoned off the area near the restaurant, which is located in one of the busiest parts of Manhattan. Shortly after the discovery, law enforcement arrived to assess the situation.  

Our @news12ny team was on scene when the suspicious item was found in front of @BurgerKing #midtown pic.twitter.com/9876543210 — Alex Carter (@AlexCarterNY) September 22, 2016  

Witnesses reported seeing the package and immediately contacted authorities. One passerby said, “I saw a bag left near the entrance and called 911 right away. They shut everything down within minutes.”  

After a thorough inspection by the bomb squad, it was determined that the bag contained only personal belongings and posed no danger. The street was reopened, and normal activity resumed.  

While the incident turned out to be a false alarm, it highlights the heightened awareness following recent security threats. With reports of increased surveillance and concerns about potential dangers, many are reminding the public to stay vigilant.  

As always, if you notice anything unusual, don’t hesitate to report it. It’s better to be safe than sorry.

Last night, the American public finally witnessed a rare moment: Joe Biden and Donald Trump sharing the same stage. And as expected, there was plenty of tension. By the end of the evening, it was clear who came out on top — Joe Biden. No one should be surprised. While the media had been hinting at a "Biden pivot," the reality was the same as always — what we saw was the same Trump we've come to expect: loud, unprepared, and full of empty promises. The experts know it. The polls know it. The people know it. Biden won because he was focused, composed, and ready to lead. But, as usual, Trump and his team refused to accept the truth. They claim the moderator was biased. They say the timing was unfair. They say Biden was "too prepared" and that it wasn’t a fair fight. More excuses from a candidate who refuses to take responsibility for his performance. He was unprepared, disrespectful, and failed to address key issues — instead, he attacked and lied. But let's focus on why Biden clearly dominated. His best moment came when he said, “I’ve spent my whole life preparing for this moment, not just for this debate, but for this country.” It’s reported that Biden immersed himself in policy, studied every detail, and practiced relentlessly. Trump, on the other hand, seemed disinterested, often drifting off-topic and failing to back up his claims with facts. He didn’t engage constructively, and he didn’t listen. Fortunately, Biden stayed calm and focused, even when Trump rambled endlessly. He didn’t get drawn into personal attacks, and he corrected Trump when necessary. He wasn’t “too aggressive,” as some claimed, but he stood his ground when needed. And, despite the criticism, he maintained a professional demeanor. One of the main frustrations with political debates is that moderators often let candidates dominate the conversation, allowing interruptions and time violations. A man in a security uniform entered a shopping center in St. Cloud, Minnesota on Saturday evening. He began shouting "Allahu Akbar" before stabbing six people. The attacker reportedly asked at least one victim if they were Muslim before attacking them. The suspect has been identified as Dahir Adan, a Somali immigrant and Muslim. Members of the local Somali-American community confirmed Adan's identity as the perpetrator, according to the SC Times. On Sunday, ISIS claimed responsibility for the attack, stating Adan was one of their operatives. This incident followed a bomb explosion at a Marine Corps event in New Jersey, a knife attack on NYPD officers in New York, and a blast in Chelsea, Manhattan that injured 29 people. 

Local Somali leaders issued a statement expressing sympathy for Adan’s family, calling him “a good student” and “well-respected” in the community. St. Cloud Mayor Dave Kleis told reporters that Adan was killed by an off-duty police officer named Jason Falconer, who intervened during the attack. Kleis praised Falconer as a hero who "was in the right place at the right time." Falconer identified himself as an officer, prompting Adan to attack him. Falconer then shot and killed Adan, sending him to "his reward in heaven," which some have jokingly referred to as a place with "72 virgins — or maybe pigs."

Last year, the Washington Times reported that over 10,000 Somali refugees were resettled in Minnesota under the Obama administration. U.S. officials have warned that groups like ISIS and al-Shabab are actively recruiting from Somali communities. In recent months, reports have surfaced about threats against women in Minnesota by some Somali residents. Additionally, ISIS has been gaining strength in Somalia, with intelligence sources indicating support from Yemen-based affiliates.

In June, three Somalians in Minnesota were convicted of attempting to join ISIS. In July, al-Shabab reportedly reached out to ISIS to coordinate attacks on American soil. Department of Homeland Security records show that over 31,000 Somali refugees were brought into the U.S. during Hillary Clinton’s tenure as Secretary of State. 

Breitbart News claimed that a Clinton presidency would lead to a dramatic increase in Muslim refugee admissions, potentially exceeding 1 million in her first term. It is clear that Muslim immigrants and refugees are being targeted by extremist groups. The attack in Minnesota shows the danger these individuals can pose.

In a time when government and media continue to grow in influence, a patriotic American has uncovered something that the Department of Justice and major news outlets have failed (or refused) to reveal: Evidence suggesting that Hillary Clinton was involved in covering up her improper use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State. A Twitter user known as @ConservativeAnalyst has compiled compelling information that has now been shared with the House Oversight Committee, prompting a fresh probe into the matter. Paul Combetta, who served as Hillary Clinton’s IT consultant during her time in the State Department, is alleged to have sought guidance on how to erase her name from classified emails. He reportedly reached out to the public through the online forum Reddit under the username “stonetear” during the summer and fall of 2014, leaving behind a trail of clues. In one of his posts, Combetta asked for help with removing the email address of an “Important Client” from both active and archived email systems. “Hi everyone,” one post reads. “I’m dealing with a situation where I need to remove an important client’s email from a bunch of old messages stored in an Exchange mailbox and a PST file. They don’t want the client’s address exposed. Does anyone know how to do this or have any tips?” The House Oversight Committee has requested that Reddit preserve all related content, and the investigation is now underway. Whether this leads to any significant conclusions remains uncertain, but what is clear is that an ordinary citizen has uncovered information that mainstream media and officials have ignored. The key question now is whether the username “stonetear” can be definitively linked to Paul Combetta. If not, the evidence may be considered circumstantial. If it can, it would provide direct proof of a deliberate attempt to hide sensitive information. @ConservativeAnalyst has presented several connections to support the claim that “stonetear” is indeed Combetta. This story has not gained much attention, as traditional media has little interest in highlighting a regular citizen's efforts. However, as more people become aware and the evidence is formally submitted to the committee, the role of everyday Americans as investigators and truth-seekers will continue to grow. There is a significant segment of the American public who believe the Black Lives Matter movement is not genuinely focused on protecting black lives, but rather using the cause as a cover to incite unrest and destruction. Matt Walsh of TheBlaze isn’t holding back when he calls the group “terrorists.” He lays out his reasoning with conviction, arguing that if you support the cause but disagree with the methods, this might be the most crucial opinion piece you read today. He begins by examining the recent turmoil in Charlotte, North Carolina. If you're confused about what happened there, here's the breakdown: a black officer shot a black man who was armed, leading a group of black activists to set fire to a black neighborhood and loot black-owned stores in an effort to protest racial injustice. It sounds oversimplified, but Walsh is right on point. He continues: No, it still doesn’t make sense. There are plenty of questions that arise. For instance, why do they claim the victim was unarmed when the evidence shows he had a gun? And regardless of whether the shooting was justified, why are they chanting “white cops are evil” when the officer involved was black? Even if the officer were white—and that seems unlikely theologically—why would they destroy their own community in response? And the biggest question of all: Why do we still call this violent chaos and crime “a protest”? It’s almost too convenient that every Black Lives Matter “protest” ends in destruction. I almost said it “descends into” violence, but that’s not quite accurate. After seeing these events unfold across the country for years, it’s clear that chaos and destruction are the goal, not just side effects. The media insists—just like they have before—that the Charlotte protests “started peacefully” and then turned violent. But that’s like saying a drive-by shooting “began as a calm ride through the city” until the shooters started firing. That may be technically true, but the intent was always toward violence, just as these “protests” seem to be planned from the start to lead to destruction and looting. These riots aren’t exceptions—they’re the norm. They’re expected, intentional, and increasingly severe. Read the full piece here. It’s definitely worth your time.

Instead of questioning Biden about his role in supporting the war, Schieffer kept focusing on Trump, citing a past interview where Trump allegedly expressed confidence in the mission. Obama’s presidency is coming to a close, and millions of Americans are eagerly awaiting the day he leaves the White House. He once promised to transform America for the better, but instead, his policies have led to widespread disappointment. It’s unlikely that his legacy will be viewed positively once he’s gone, as many believe his administration has left the country in a worse state than before. Yet, Obama continues to promote his record, urging citizens to defend his legacy after he’s no longer in office.  

During a recent address to the Congressional Black Caucus, Obama referenced the Jim Crow era and slavery to push voters toward supporting the "right" candidate. He emphasized that his legacy was at stake and encouraged the audience to help ensure a strong farewell by getting people to the polls. While he didn’t name Hillary Clinton directly, he strongly implied that the black community should support her, stating, “My name may not be on the ballot, but our progress is. And there is one candidate who will continue that work, and another who stands in its way.”  

He also highlighted the high voter turnout among African Americans in 2008 and 2012, warning, “If this community doesn’t come out and vote, it will be a personal blow to me and my legacy. You want to honor me? Then go vote!”  

However, the facts challenge everything Obama claims. The Democratic Party historically supported slavery and segregation, while the Republican Party was founded to end those very systems. The first African American members of Congress were Republicans, and it was Democrats who created the Ku Klux Klan to suppress black voting rights.  

Meanwhile, Obama’s record with the black community is questionable. His administration ended school choice programs in Washington, D.C., limiting opportunities for low-income students. Unemployment and reliance on food assistance have risen, disproportionately affecting black communities. He has done little to address the breakdown of the black family, the high rate of abortions among black women, or the alarming number of children born outside of marriage.  

How can he speak so confidently about his legacy when the evidence suggests otherwise? It seems he's lost touch with reality.
