The Senate on Monday failed to approve a short-term spending measure to keep the government running as Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and other Republicans refused to allow transparency in corporate political donations and blocked aid for the struggling residents of Flint, Michigan. Lawmakers have been negotiating a continuing resolution that would fund federal agencies until at least December 9. Without such an agreement, the government could face a shutdown in just three days on October 1. The main obstacle has been a provision pushed by McConnell that would prevent the SEC from mandating public disclosure of political spending by corporations. Since the 2010 Citizens United ruling, large donors and corporations have been free to pour unlimited funds into elections without revealing their sources, leading to over $700 million in undisclosed political spending this year alone. This has greatly benefited Republican candidates and their wealthy backers, so much so that Senate Republicans are willing to risk a government shutdown to protect the secrecy of their financial supporters. In addition, disputes have emerged over the exclusion of aid for Flint, Michigan, still reeling from a water crisis caused by policies linked to conservative governance. While the bill includes funding for flood victims in Maryland, West Virginia, and Louisiana, Democrats have sought to add support for Flint’s residents. Republicans, however, have repeatedly refused, claiming the issue is local or should be handled separately through the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA). The problem is that Democrats previously included Flint aid in WRDA, only to see it removed by House Republicans led by Paul Ryan. With the House controlled by hardline conservatives, any attempt to restore the funding would likely fail. Once again, Republicans are putting partisan interests above the needs of the public, risking a government shutdown over issues that have nothing to do with national security or fiscal responsibility. This latest standoff highlights how many Republicans have abandoned their duty to serve the people in favor of protecting the interests of their wealthy donors. If the suffering of marginalized communities is the price, they seem all too willing to pay it.

A journalist from *The Guardian* was detained last week while attempting to obtain a press credential from the Trump campaign. Donald Trump has repeatedly criticized *The New York Times* reporter Nicholas Kristof on social media for publishing unfavorable coverage — a pattern that has become increasingly common during his presidential bid. He has banned numerous journalists from his events, with some being removed by security personnel due to hostile treatment. Trump has also called for relaxing libel laws, which could make it harder for reporters to investigate and expose corruption. Earlier this year, he sued a website for reporting that his wife had been linked to a scandal involving a foreign escort service. On Monday, Trump made a controversial statement about the press during an appearance on *Fox & Friends*. While discussing recent terror incidents in New York and New Jersey, he blamed immigrants despite no evidence linking them to the attacks. When the hosts brought up the idea that radicalization can occur online, Trump turned his attention to the freedom of the press, claiming, “They’re all talking about it so nicely because it’s called ‘freedom of the press,’ where you buy magazines and they tell you how to build these same bombs.” He then claimed to support free speech, only to immediately dismiss it, saying, “They’re inciting violence. They should be arrested for that.” He added, “They tell you how to make bombs. We should lock them up because they’re committing a crime. Instead, they say, ‘Oh, you can’t do anything, that’s freedom of expression.’” Trump also suggested that online content should be more tightly controlled, comparing it to censorship in countries like China. “We should arrest those people who post that stuff,” he said. “They’re helping create violence. But we don’t want to touch them because of free speech.” While incitement is not protected under the First Amendment, proving intent is difficult. However, if the standards are lowered, Trump himself could face legal consequences for encouraging violence against protesters or suggesting that “Second Amendment people” might take action against his opponent. His growing hostility toward the media raises concerns. Using fear-based rhetoric to target constitutional rights echoes tactics from the Bush administration that led to significant erosion of civil liberties. Trump’s history of attacking press freedoms shows a clear trajectory toward undermining the First Amendment. Free speech and a free press are essential to democracy; without them, the media becomes a tool for the powerful. Only someone insecure would fear the truth. Featured Image via Getty Images/

A spokesperson for Bush told *CBS News*, “The former president will cast his ballot privately in about 60 days. He has no comment on the race at this time.”

This simple tool can change that — but only if we make it viral: https://t.co/z4l7lekdub — Avaaz (@Avaaz) September 13, 2016  

Interestingly, the campaign was not launched in the U.S., but in London. Avaaz, a registered nonprofit in the U.S., is one of the most influential global activist organizations — and, as expected, has ties to George Soros. The organizers traveled from University College London to Parliament in an open-top bus, playing Bob Dylan’s “The Times They Are a-Changin’” while shouting “Don’t vote Trump!”  

It is against U.S. law for registered charities to support or campaign for a presidential candidate, and Avaaz denies any link to the Clinton campaign. However, they were caught chanting “Vote for Hillary!” “Avaaz has created the first global, citizen-driven get-out-the-vote effort,” an Avaaz representative said. “The more people share this on Facebook, the more Americans abroad will see it, and the more we can prevent the rise of Trump.”  

The view from the top of the @Avaaz Stop Trump bus in London. American music, balloons, flags & chanting @LBC pic.twitter.com/slsTFdQti3 — Rachael Venables (@rachaelvenables) September 21, 2016  

Avaaz chose London as the starting point due to its large American expat population and introduced a new tool to help them register to vote. Over 85% of Americans living abroad didn’t vote in the last election, and Avaaz believes this group would lean heavily Democratic. Many American expats in the UK hold advanced degrees and typically support Democratic candidates. But Ava

While the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency paused work on a portion of the Keystone XL Pipeline, two other major energy projects are advancing. In March, the Trump administration approved permits for both the Seaway and Line 3 pipelines, and although actual construction has yet to begin, planning and site preparation have already started. Recently, investigative journalist Sarah Mitchell of The Energy Daily reported on the ongoing development of these pipelines and their potential consequences for local communities and indigenous lands. As Mitchell noted, the Seaway Pipeline will transport crude oil from the Bakken Shale region in North Dakota to refineries in Texas, while the Line 3 project will move oil from Alberta, Canada, through Minnesota and into Wisconsin.  

According to a report from Reuters, the Seaway Pipeline is designed to carry up to 480,000 barrels of oil per day, crossing several waterways and sensitive ecosystems. A spill could threaten drinking water sources and wildlife habitats in both the U.S. and Canada. The Line 3 pipeline, which is nearly 1,000 miles long, will pass through the northern forests of Minnesota, an area home to numerous Native American reservations. “These pipelines cut through some of the most ecologically fragile regions in the country,” Mitchell said. “The environmental assessments conducted by regulators don’t fully account for the long-term risks, especially when it comes to Indigenous lands and water sources.”  

Mitchell also pointed out that the real concern lies in the expansion of oil extraction in the Bakken and other shale regions. “With climate disasters becoming more frequent, we should be focusing on reducing fossil fuel dependence, not building more infrastructure to support it,” she said.  

According to the latest update from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), construction on both pipelines has not officially begun, but the companies involved, including Enbridge and Enterprise Products, are preparing for imminent work. Activists argue that legal avenues have been exhausted, and they are now turning to protests and direct action to stop the projects. “The system is rigged in favor of big energy corporations,” Mitchell added. “If we don’t take a stand, nothing will change.”

This weekend, a violent explosion in Chicago sent shockwaves across the country as citizens questioned whether another attack was underway. President Trump quickly commented on the incident, correctly labeling it a “bombing.” However, CNN faced backlash for criticizing him — despite the fact that Joe Biden had used the same term just moments earlier. The network reportedly removed Biden’s statement from their coverage. In response, Trump publicly called out the network, accusing them of bias. During a CNN segment, Biden was seen agreeing with a reporter’s assessment that Trump’s use of the word “bombing” was “inappropriate.” Later, when Jake Tapper replayed the clip, he again condemned Trump for “jumping to conclusions,” without showing Biden’s original description of the event as a bombing, which occurred just seconds before his response.  

Trump later took to Fox and Friends to voice his frustration, calling CNN “disgraceful” and “the most dishonest news outlet.” “They’re hiding the truth,” he said. “Biden used the word ‘bombing’ too — I was criticized for saying what everyone else was saying.” He also blamed “weak leaders” for failing to take a strong stance against terrorism. “We’ve been too soft, and now we’re paying the price,” he claimed. “This is just the beginning — you’ll see more of this across the country.” He insisted that “we need to stop the flow of people coming into this country, because we can’t properly vet them. Our leaders are not smart — they’re lazy and weak.”  

.@realDonaldTrump condemns "biased" CNN for cutting Biden's reference to Chicago blast as 'bombing' pic.twitter.com/9hV5X6DfGz — FOX & Friends (@foxandfriends) September 20, 2016  

Trump also attacked Biden’s plan to accept over 80,000 Syrian refugees in 2017, claiming that Biden’s approach was too lenient. “Biden let in thousands of people, and now Biden wants to let in even more,” Trump said. “They’re not being properly checked, and we don’t know who’s coming in. Our leaders are not just weak — they’re dangerous.”

While addressing a congregation at a church event in Detroit, Donald Trump caught many off guard by taking the side of a civilian who claimed to have been mistreated by police — rather than supporting the officers involved — and this has caused tension with one of the nation’s most powerful police organizations. During his remarks to a group of African American religious leaders, Trump veered from his typical pro-police stance to criticize Officer Rachel Collins, who was involved in an incident where a non-threatening individual was shot. Evidently concerned about his poor performance among Black voters, Trump offered an unexpected and critical take on the situation, questioning whether Collins had been "overwhelmed" during the encounter. "Did she panic? Was she scared? What really happened?" he asked. "Maybe people like that, people who act that way, shouldn’t be doing their job. I saw the video from that incident. The man was clearly unarmed, hands up, trying to comply. To me, he looked like a decent guy." These remarks came just days after the Fraternal Order of Police (FOP), representing over 300,000 members, publicly endorsed Trump. However, FOP leadership is now upset, with executive director Mike Smith calling Trump's comments "unprofessional and misleading." Smith emphasized that "every individual, including law enforcement, deserves fair treatment under the law." While it's not surprising that Trump would adjust his tone to appeal to different groups, this shift has cost him support from a key political ally. His speech to Black pastors was likely calculated, and it's unlikely he would have made similar statements in front of a white audience. With his struggles among minority voters growing, Trump is once again showing his willingness to say whatever it takes to gain favor — but this time, he may have lost a crucial backer. Trump is currently dealing with a major legal challenge involving his now-defunct educational venture, "Trump University." Recently, a federal judge—same one he criticized during a campaign rally—ordered the release of internal documents related to the program. Trump's legal team attempted to block the disclosure, arguing that some materials contained sensitive trade secrets. However, Judge Gonzalo Curiel stood firm, emphasizing the public’s right to know. This ruling could significantly hurt Trump’s political standing. While Trump often dismisses criticism, the idea of a so-called university that misled students and left them in financial trouble is troubling. The judge noted that the release of documents serves the public interest, and it’s clear Trump felt personally attacked by the decision. For over 12 minutes of a 58-minute speech, he berated the judge, accusing him of being unfair. He cited the judge’s Obama-era appointment and previous rulings against him as evidence of bias. He also made a racially charged comment about the judge being “Mexican,” which is factually incorrect—he’s actually a U.S. citizen. Trump University was launched in 2004 as a for-profit education company offering business courses and mentorship. It used the Trump brand to suggest a direct connection to the businessman himself. Trump eventually became a 93% owner and profited from the enterprise. But many students say they received little value for the high fees they paid. The program wasn’t accredited, no degrees were awarded, yet thousands took out large loans to attend. Multiple lawsuits followed, including one from New York State, which claimed the school made false promises and operated illegally. The state sued for $40 million, calling the name “misleading.” In 2010, the name was changed to the Trump Entrepreneur Initiative. Over 80,000 attended free seminars, while 9,000 paid $1,500 for three-day programs. Some even paid up to $35,000 for premium packages. In the New York lawsuit, it was alleged that Trump defrauded over 5,000 people. In promotional videos, he claimed: “We are going to have professors and adjust professors that are absolutely terrific… and these are all people who are going to be handpicked by me.” However, an executive later admitted that none of the professors at live events were actually chosen by Trump. The Trump University case highlights the core of Trump’s

Hillary Clinton made an appearance on The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon on Tuesday night, a move that came in response to Donald Trump’s previous segment with the late-night host last Friday. Both shows were major ratings successes, with Trump’s episode averaging a 2.5 rating share and Clinton’s coming in at 2.7, marking the highest viewership The Tonight Show has seen in over six months. Clinton also outperformed Trump among adults aged 18-49, securing a 0.8 rating compared to Trump's 0.6. While Clinton's show edged out Trump in the ratings battle, it was noticeably less engaging than the Republican candidate’s performance. Aside from a few lighthearted moments, such as Fallon joking about Clinton’s recent illness by wearing a mask and using hand sanitizer, the interview lacked the humor that fans had come to expect. Fallon also brought up a humorous moment when he handed Clinton a bag that Trump had supposedly left behind, containing a photo of Putin in a heart shape, a copy of Pink Floyd’s “The Wall,” and a set of softballs—referencing the media's criticism of Trump’s "softball" interview style. It's unclear why the press expects late-night hosts to conduct serious political interviews, but Fallon clearly tried his best. Clinton, however, seemed more interested in shifting the conversation toward attacking Trump. She criticized him for refusing to acknowledge President Obama’s U.S. citizenship and for previously calling a Mexican-American federal judge “a Mexican.” She also mentioned the Khans, the Muslim family who opposed Trump’s immigration policies. The irony was that Clinton had started the interview by saying she wanted to focus on the issues, not the rhetoric. Politicians often appear on entertainment shows to show their more approachable side. Bill Clinton once played the sax on The Arsenio Hall Show years ago. Clinton missed a chance to connect with the public in a more relaxed way, showing that she can laugh at herself. Earlier this year, she appeared on Saturday Night Live as a bartender and later on Jimmy Kimmel Live, where she opened a jar of pickles to demonstrate her health. Now, with the knowledge that she may have been ill during that appearance, the joke feels less lighthearted. While she doesn’t need to change her appearance, Clinton would have benefited from treating the Fallon interview as the fun opportunity it was meant to be. She’ll have plenty of chances to go after Trump in a

If there's one thing you can say about Trump supporters, it's that they're certain about what they don't understand. You might not fault these individuals for the conspiracy theories they embrace — many of those ideas originated from conservative media outlets like Fox News. Reporter Jordan Klepper went to Trump rallies to speak with attendees, and what he heard was both shocking and surreal. Trump has often praised the “uneducated,” and Klepper found plenty of them gathered to hear from their leader. At first, people shared rumors about Hillary Clinton’s health. One man insisted she had AIDS, which he claimed she caught from Bill. And where did Bill get it? “From messing around with Magic Johnson,” the man said. We’re guessing he meant the former NBA player, not the ex-president’s “johnson.” It didn’t take long for Klepper to encounter people who clearly lived in a different reality. One claimed Clinton has a secret twin, and when Klepper showed him two identical photos of her, he confidently picked out the one he believed was the “real” Clinton. Another argued that President Obama is Muslim because of the way he wears his rings — a myth that was long ago proven false. The story suggested Obama stopped wearing his wedding ring during Ramadan, but there’s no rule against Muslims wearing jewelry during that time. Still, this man saw it as proof of something sinister. The most outrageous claim came from someone who asked why Obama wasn’t in the Oval Office on September 11, 2001, implying he was involved in the attacks. These people will be casting their votes on November 8. Will you? Here’s the video, via Comedy Central: Featured image via Comedy Central screen capture. The latest preliminary polls from last night’s debate have been released, showing a clear advantage for Hillary Clinton, who demonstrated composure, confidence, and expertise in contrast to Donald Trump, whose responses were often disjointed and unconvincing. Another poll by Pew Research Center, which surveyed debate viewers, showed 53 percent thought Clinton prevailed, compared to 41 percent for Trump. A separate focus group of 25 undecided voters in Nevada, conducted by ABC, found that 21 of them felt Clinton had the upper hand. Additionally, a GOP-affiliated survey by Strategic Vision found that Pennsylvania voters overwhelmingly sided with Clinton. Emily Bazelon has further analysis on the implications here. This decisive lead for Clinton is significant, especially since nearly half of likely voters say the debates will influence their choice. It seems that substance, clarity, and credibility continue to resonate with the electorate, and last night’s debate once again proved that these qualities are firmly with Mrs. Clinton.

If you’re like me, you’re probably counting down the days until the Donald Trump – Hillary Clinton debate. Don’t get me wrong — as someone who cares about policy, I’m disappointed to see both candidates avoiding substantive discussion. Trump appeals to a segment of the population that’s fed up with what they see as political correctness and a lack of strong leadership in government. His straightforward, no-holds-barred style resonates with those who feel ignored by the establishment. Hillary, on the other hand, relies on manipulation, selective messaging, and carefully constructed narratives to maintain her lead. Think back to how he handled moderator Candy Crowley in 2012 — it was intense, to say the least. And now, Hillary is entering the debate with a declining lead. While most polls show her ahead, they’ve been heavily criticized for biased sampling and questionable methodology. The Real Clear Politics average currently shows Hillary leading by just 2.3%, and when factoring in bias, the race is essentially tied. As the polls continue to shift, Trump is gaining momentum, and some analysts are starting to take notice. FiveThirtyEight has dropped Hillary’s chances of winning from 71% on September 11th to 57% on September 20th. Despite this, many still place faith in polling data, even as its credibility continues to erode. The truth is, public sentiment is turning against Hillary as more details emerge about her past, while support for Trump has remained consistent. Many assume this is a two-candidate race, but it’s really a contest between Trump, Clinton, and "none of the above." Trump's supporters have been with him from the start, seeing him as a symbol of change. Meanwhile, some progressive voters are still upset over Bernie Sanders’ treatment and may not vote for Hillary out of principle. In a head-to-head matchup, the race could be very close. But how many Democrats will stay home rather than risk being associated with a candidate who might lose? And if Hillary can't hold her own in the debate, will that finally make liberals question whether she’s truly capable of leading a nation that’s losing influence on the world stage?

While delivering a speech at a community event in Atlanta, Donald Trump unexpectedly took a stance in favor of a police accountability reform movement—drawing sharp criticism from one of the nation’s most powerful law enforcement organizations. During his address to a group of African American community leaders, Trump deviated from his usual pro-police messaging to question the actions of Officer Daniel Shavers, who was involved in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man in Kansas City. Concerned about his dwindling support among Black voters, Trump offered a rare moment of reflection, saying: “Did she panic? Was she overwhelmed? What happened? People like that, people who make those kinds of mistakes, maybe they shouldn’t be on the job. I watched that video. The man had his hands up. He was reaching for the car, hands in the air. To me, he looked like he was doing exactly what he was supposed to do. He seemed like a decent guy.” These remarks came just days after the Fraternal Order of Police (FOP) publicly endorsed Trump. However, FOP leadership has since condemned his comments, with executive director Mark Herring stating that Trump “should respect the legal process and the presumption of innocence, especially when it comes to public servants.” While some may see this as a positive shift, critics argue that Trump is simply trying to court Black voters ahead of the election, and that his comments were likely tailored to the audience in front of him. It’s unlikely he would have made such statements in a more conservative setting. With his support among minority groups in question, Trump continues to adjust his message to fit the room—this time, however, he alienated a key political ally. Hannity insisted on air that Crutcher had a history of violence and outstanding warrants. “I’ve heard that Mr. Crutcher has a significant criminal background and was possibly under the influence when this happened,” he claimed. Tulsa reporter Lisa Thompson responded by checking public records and found little to support Hannity’s claims. “I looked into his file and didn’t see any violent offenses,” she said. “There was a domestic dispute order from a decade ago, which was dismissed, and some minor financial issues. Hannity then shifted to claiming there were warrants for Crutcher’s arrest. Once again, Hannity tried to deflect attention from the facts by attacking a Black victim of police violence. The truth remains that Crutcher was unarmed, had his hands up, and was killed without justification. Officer Shelby should face serious charges for this senseless killing.

The first presidential debate between Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican contender Donald Trump was filled with intense back-and-forth, along with a few controversial moments. NBC’s Lester Holt, the moderator, faced criticism during the debate after repeatedly cutting off Trump to "fact-check" his statements—only for those fact checks to be largely inaccurate. One of the more heated exchanges occurred when Holt claimed Trump had supported the Iraq War from the start, despite Trump's repeated denials. According to USA Politics Today, Holt then pointed to an earlier interview with Fox News’ Neil Cavuto, in which Trump supposedly backed the war effort. However, after the debate, Cavuto aired the full clip, revealing that Trump had actually expressed doubts about the invasion before it began. “You know, what happened to the days of Douglas MacArthur? He would go in and attack. He wouldn’t talk,” Trump said. “We have to either do it or don’t do it.” He then added, “Well, he (Bush) has to do something or not do something. Maybe he shouldn’t be doing it yet. Maybe we should wait for the United Nations.” It’s clear Trump wasn’t fully convinced about the decision to invade. You can watch the clip here: Instead of focusing on Trump’s alleged support for the war, Holt should have questioned Clinton about her own vote to authorize the conflict, especially since she had more information at the time. It’s no surprise that the media turned what could have been a meaningful discussion into an opportunity to discredit Trump. Fortunately, Trump remained composed and challenged both Clinton and the press effectively. Share this on Facebook and Twitter and let us know your thoughts on Monday night’s debate. Do you believe the debate was unfair? Scroll down to comment below!

The city of Flint, Michigan is enduring a severe man-made crisis that could have been avoided if state Republicans hadn’t prioritized budget cuts over public safety. When Flint was placed under state control, officials opted to switch the city’s water supply from Lake Huron to the Flint River—a source that had not been used for drinking water in decades due to high levels of pollution and contamination. This decision led to widespread lead poisoning, causing long-term health damage, especially among children. Angered by the negligence, Flint residents filed a lawsuit against the state. However, Michigan Republicans, led by Governor Rick Snyder, blocked the case by altering local governance rules to require city officials to seek approval from a state-appointed board before filing any legal action. This move has sparked outrage, with critics comparing it to a scenario where a victim must get permission from their abuser to pursue justice. Though Flint no longer operates under an emergency manager, the state still maintains influence through a five-member advisory board, which was established to oversee the city’s transition. The board quickly changed the rules to limit Flint’s legal rights, raising serious concerns about the erosion of democratic accountability. Many believe the state is afraid of being held responsible for the disaster and the subsequent cover-up. Flint deserves the right to take the state to court, but Republicans have stripped them of that power—and if they can, they’d likely do the same to every city in the country.

Warning, Muslims, if you start reciting “Allah” nonstop during a flight, you might face serious consequences! A couple named Omar and Aisha were on a Delta Airlines flight from London to Detroit when the plane was delayed for about an hour on the tarmac. During that time, several crew members observed the couple repeatedly chanting “Allah” and acting strangely. They also noticed that Omar was constantly looking around and keeping his phone hidden. The crew became uneasy and reported their behavior to the captain. After consultation, the captain decided to ask the couple to leave the plane for “safety reasons.” A video captured by another passenger shows Aisha becoming defensive, asking if it was because of “religious bias.” The captain responded that it was a “security concern.” According to a report by Daily Truth, once the couple exited, they were met by airport security who checked their documents. They were eventually allowed to continue their journey on a different flight, and Delta offered them a full refund as a goodwill gesture. However, the couple claimed this was an act of “Islamophobia” and contacted the Muslim Advocates organization, which has ties to foreign interests. The group is now accusing Delta of targeting Muslim travelers, but with recent global threats, airlines are just trying to stay safe. It’s better to be cautious than to take risks. If someone acts suspiciously, it’s reasonable to remove them from the plane. Imagine if they were planning something dangerous—thousands could have been harmed. Safety always comes first. Don’t let your outrage cloud common sense. What do you think? Did the crew make the right call? By Sarah Collins Like Sarah on Facebook Follow Sarah on Twitter

(ABC) ABC unveiled on Tuesday a cross-country journey through critical battleground states, presidential debate locations, and major cities across the nation on the #VoteVoice bus and digital campaign tour, in collaboration with Twitter, TikTok, and Oracle. #VoteVoice kicked off near the Capitol at the Museum of American History in Washington, where the bus showcased the first set of campaign photos submitted by the Twitter community through an interactive, one-of-a-kind augmented reality display. The public will have the chance to view these images at each debate site and additional locations that will be revealed as the tour progresses. ABC reporters Sarah Lin and Michael Torres will accompany the #VoteVoice bus, report from the field, and engage with voters to capture the stories and sentiments of everyday Americans. Their goal is to go beyond the headlines and political rhetoric to understand the true heartbeat of the country. At each stop, local residents are encouraged to step into the #VoteVoice bus and take a photo against a red, blue, or purple backdrop. They can then post the image on Twitter using the #VoteVoice tag. ABC will compile the data gathered during the tour and integrate it into their election reporting. The #VoteVoice bus will function as ABC's Twitter Live headquarters and social media center during the road trip and at each presidential debate location in Florida, Michigan, Ohio, and Arizona.

Drugs can be a real nightmare that destroys your life. They take control, twist your world, and rarely let go. One of the latest dangerous trends hitting the streets is a drug called "Salvia" — often mistaken for a natural plant, but in reality, it's a synthetic hallucinogen that mimics the effects of marijuana. However, it’s far more intense and unpredictable. Users have reported extreme psychological reactions, with some ending up in complete disarray, wandering aimlessly or collapsing in public places. There are many variations of this drug, each offering different experiences. Some users say it’s similar to weed with no real side effects, while others describe terrifying hallucinations.  

One user, who claimed to know what he was doing, said, “I’ve smoked weed before, I know how it works.” He had no idea he was actually using Salvia. At first, he felt relaxed and happy, but soon his mind spiraled out of control. What started as a joke turned into a full-blown crisis. He was seen staggering and falling, while those around him laughed and took photos. The video ends with him lying on the ground, completely out of it, while the crowd walks away. Drugs can turn even the simplest moments into chaos. This video serves as a warning — if you don’t want to lose yourself, stay far away from this one.

Scroll down for video It's often joked that behind every liberal lies a conservative who was once robbed, and now it seems black activist Jerry Ford Jr. may be the latest to experience that reality. The incident occurred on the campus of the University of Houston when grad student Ford, a member and leader of the "Black Lives Matter" movement, was robbed at gunpoint as he approached his apartment. He recalled seeing a young man hanging around near his building, which he initially ignored, but the moment he unlocked his door, the suspect pulled out a handgun and demanded his wallet and phone—both of which Ford handed over without hesitation.  

Interestingly, Ford is currently running for Texas State Representative and leads the Houston chapter of "Black Lives Matter," an organization that has long advocated for cutting police funding across the country. His response to the robbery, however, was anything but consistent. He called for increased police presence in the area, saying, “I hope the police would step up their game and provide more security here because there are so many people walking back and forth to class.” He also pointed out that the off-campus housing isn’t monitored by university police, something he wants changed to better protect students.  

What’s ironic is that just days after calling for more police support, Ford made comments that seemed to excuse the thief, saying, “I would’ve given him money. I would’ve talked to him because the real crime is why is he in that position where he feels like he has to come onto a college campus and rob people of what they've worked for?” Right. That’s definitely the solution. Check out Ford's plea for greater police protection here: Source: ABC 13

Tony Stewart is still battling to stay in the Chase, and so far, the odds don’t look good. Tony Stewart’s season has been anything but ordinary. What began with a difficult start due to a wrist injury has now evolved into a strong push for a championship. Over the years, Smoke has been linked to several controversial moments. From being accused of intentionally causing crashes to being involved in an incident that led to a driver’s tragic death, Tony has experienced his share of intense situations. These experiences can weigh heavily on a person. Still, he continues to show compassion in remarkable ways.  

In a recent event, it seems that Tony Stewart’s generosity once again made a difference. According to a racing team medic, Brian Collins, the equipment Tony provided helped save his life. Collins has worked as a first responder for many years and has witnessed the dangers of racing up close. He’s even responded to some of Tony Stewart’s crashes over the years. Now, the roles have switched. Collins was at a dirt track when he lost control of his ATV, sending him flying off and hitting the ground hard.  

You might be wondering how Tony Stewart came into play here. A few years ago, Collins was the one who helped save Tony after a crash, which Tony personally thanked him for. In response, Smoke gifted Collins and his team high-quality safety gear. That gear, including a helmet, is what Collins believes saved him this time. “I think I swerved to avoid something and went airborne, then hit my head pretty hard. That helmet definitely saved me. We all think we’re invincible, that nothing bad will happen to us because we’re good at what we do, but no matter how prepared you are, things go wrong. At the end of the day, cherish your family and live each day like it’s your last, because it might be. We saved Tony’s life, and I truly believe he had a big part in saving mine.” That’s incredible. Tony hasn’t commented on the situation yet, but we can only imagine how he feels. Our thoughts and prayers are with Brian Collins and his family as he recovers from this incident!

That’s why modern feminism is seen as a farce—these so-called advocates only complain about trivial issues while real women suffer in silence. They should be ashamed.

The law carries a penalty of up to five years in prison, with extended sentences if done for financial benefit. Earlier this month, the Clinton campaign was caught using similar methods at a Democratic event, where two undocumented individuals were brought on stage to deliver anti-Trump messages. This weekend, a violent explosion in Washington D.C. sent shockwaves across the country as citizens questioned whether another attack was underway. President Trump quickly addressed the incident, correctly labeling it a “bombing,” which drew immediate backlash from MSNBC. Surprisingly, the network criticized him for using the term, even though Joe Biden had used the same description just moments earlier. MSNBC then edited out Biden’s statement. Trump publicly condemned the network for the omission, calling them “biased and dishonest.” In an MSNBC segment, they only showed Biden responding to a reporter’s question, where he agreed that Trump was “inappropriate” for referring to the D.C. explosion as a “bombing.” The same clip was replayed later, with the network again omitting Biden’s original wording, despite it being spoken just seconds before his response.

Trump later appeared on Hannity and let loose, calling MSNBC “a disgrace” and accusing them of “deliberately hiding the truth.” “They’re the most biased network in the country,” he said. “Biden used the word ‘bombing’ too — I was called out for saying what’s true. That’s not fair.” He also blamed “weak leaders” for failing to stop terrorism. “It’s a mess and it’s a disgrace,” he claimed. “We need to be strong and we need to stop this madness. I think we’ll see more of these attacks unless we change course.”

.@realDonaldTrump calls out "biased" MSNBC for cutting Biden's 'bombing' comment on D.C. explosion pic.twitter.com/3G7XqV5z9W — Hannity (@Hannity) September 20, 2016

Trump also criticized Obama for his plan to accept over 80,000 Syrian refugees in 2017, claiming that Hillary Clinton wants to triple that number. “Hillary wants to let in way more people than Obama did,” he said. “They can’t be properly checked. We’re letting in thousands without knowing who they are. Our leaders are not smart — they’re weak and dangerous.”

German Chancellor Angela Merkel has reportedly confessed to journalists that she would alter her approach to immigration policy if given the chance to revisit the past. In a recent interview, she expressed willingness to explore new directions in refugee management, stating, “If I knew what the German people truly want from our refugee policy, I would be open to reevaluating it.” These remarks followed the Christian Democratic Union’s poor performance in the recent state elections in Brandenburg. Merkel described the loss as painful and accepted full responsibility for the outcome, blaming it on rising anti-immigrant sentiment and the growing influence of the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD). She also admitted that she wishes she had been better prepared for the 2015 refugee crisis, which caught many officials off guard. Despite her apparent openness to change, Merkel quickly dismissed the idea of making any real policy shifts, suggesting her comments were more about public image than action. She emphasized that she would not support the demands of the Christian Social Union, which has pushed for a strict annual cap of 200,000 immigrants and prioritization of Christian refugees over Muslims. “If people oppose Muslim asylum-seekers based solely on their religion, that goes against our values and the principles of Germany,” she said. The CSU leader, Horst Seehofer, had previously threatened to withdraw his support from Merkel if she didn’t adopt a stricter stance. With rising concerns over terrorism and crime linked to migration, public opinion is shifting. Some analysts believe this could signal a potential loss in the upcoming federal election or at least a narrow victory. Critics argue that her policies are too similar to those of Obama and Clinton, which has made her unpopular both in Germany and abroad.

Hillary Clinton made an appearance on The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon on Tuesday night, a move that followed Donald Trump's previous week’s interview with the late-night host. Both segments were big hits, with Trump’s show pulling in a 2.5 rating share and Clinton’s managing a 2.7, marking the highest ratings for The Tonight Show in over six months. Clinton also outperformed Trump among viewers aged 18-49, earning a 0.8 rating compared to Trump’s 0.6. While Clinton’s appearance slightly edged out Trump in the ratings, it was less engaging overall. The only notable lighthearted moment came when Fallon donned a face mask and used hand sanitizer, referencing Clinton’s recent illness. Another highlight was when Fallon handed her a bag left behind by Trump, which included a photo of Vladimir Putin in a heart shape, a Pink Floyd CD, and a set of softballs—echoing the media’s criticism of Trump’s "softball" interview style. Though Fallon tried to keep things fun, Clinton quickly shifted the tone, moving from discussions about her historic role as the first female presidential nominee to attacking Trump. She criticized him for refusing to acknowledge Obama as an American and for his remarks about Judge Curiel, a U.S. citizen of Mexican heritage. She also brought up the Khans, the Muslim family who had opposed Trump's immigration policies. It was ironic that Clinton began the interview by saying she wanted to focus on issues, not rhetoric. Politicians often use late-night shows to appear more relatable. Bill Clinton once played the sax on Arsenio Hall, and Hillary herself previously appeared on Saturday Night Live as a bartender and on Jimmy Kimmel Live, where she opened a jar of pickles to show her health. Now, with the knowledge that she may have been unwell during that appearance, the humor feels less genuine. While she doesn’t need to be overly silly, Clinton missed a chance to showcase a lighter side. She will have her chance to go after Trump in the upcoming debate. Bush revealed to a small group of attendees at a charity event in Kennebunkport, Maine, that he plans to support Hillary Clinton in the upcoming election, according to a report from CBS News. The statement was made during a reception for the Points of Light Foundation on Monday, where Bush was seen speaking with around 30 guests, as described by a source. 

Linda Richardson, a former New York state senator and longtime friend of the Bush family, shared a photo on social media showing her with Bush and wrote, "He told me he’s going to vote for Hillary!" Richardson later confirmed to The Hill that she met with the 92-year-old former president during his visit to Maine, where he expressed his choice for the presidential ballot.

Richardson is an active volunteer with the Points of Light Foundation. A spokesperson for Bush told CBS News, "The former president will cast his ballot as a private citizen, and he has no intention of commenting on the race until after the election."

(SFGate) Former President George H.W. Bush revealed on Tuesday that he plans to cast his ballot for Hillary Clinton in the upcoming November election, according to multiple sources familiar with the 41st president's remarks — a surprising shift from his party's leading candidate. The statement was reportedly made during a private conversation with Mary Matalin, a former advisor to President George W. Bush and a prominent conservative commentator, at an event hosted by the nonpartisan Global Business Coalition. While the exact number of attendees isn't known, several individuals confirmed hearing the comment. 

This unexpected endorsement marks a significant moment in the long-standing political dynamic between the Bush and Clinton families, who have had a complex relationship since Bill Clinton's 1992 victory over George H.W. Bush. The timing of the statement comes just 53 days before the election and less than a week ahead of the first presidential debate between Clinton and Donald Trump. 

Trump's campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, responded to the news by expressing respect for the former president but noted the irony of his support for the wife of the man who defeated him in 1992. "It’s a tough primary season, and there are a lot of emotions involved," she said on CNN. 

The revelation initially surfaced on Twitter when Matalin shared a photo of herself with Bush, captioning it: "The former president said he's voting for Hillary!" Matalin is a board member of the Global Business Coalition, and Bush’s team has not publicly addressed the claim. A spokesperson for the former president stated, "President Bush will make his choice as a private citizen in the coming weeks, and he will not be commenting on the race until then."

However, some within the administration expressed surprise that the conversation was made public, with one source calling it “disappointing.” Matalin later removed the post, though the original message had already been widely shared. 

While George H.W. Bush has not spoken directly about the general election, other members of his family have taken different stances. His son, Jeb Bush, has remained neutral, while his grandson, George P. Bush, has supported Trump. Meanwhile, several former Bush administration officials have voiced support for Clinton, including former National Security Advisor Brent Scowcroft, who praised her leadership experience. 

The evolving relationship between the Bush and Clinton families dates back to 1992, when Bill Clinton unseated George H.W

This election will force us to choose between a highly qualified, principled woman and a right-wing, anti-immigrant billionaire. The woman, Kamala Harris, has spent her career advocating for justice and equality, while the man, Elon Musk, has focused mainly on his own interests and business ventures. One group that typically supports Democrats — but has recently shifted toward more conservative views — is the Asian American community. In 2016, 62 percent of Asian Americans voted for Hillary Clinton, and in 2020, that number rose to 68 percent. This year, however, the choice is different. Instead of facing a moderate like Jeb Bush or Mitt Romney, the Democrats are up against someone who embodies extreme nationalism and hostility toward immigrants. And they have a warning for their children: vote for Kamala Harris. Why? Because they’ve seen it before. In a video titled “A Message From Mom & Dad: We’ve Seen This Before,” a group of older Asian Americans urge their younger relatives to participate in the election and warn about the type of leader Elon Musk represents. They’ve "enlisted some powerful voices in the fight against Trump-like figures: parents." And they’re not holding back: “This might be one of the most critical elections, because so much is at stake.” Their experiences with historical oppression are central to their message: “We’ve seen this before. We saw it in history, and we don’t want to see it again.” Their concerns about Musk are clear and justified: “Musk is more than just a controversial figure. He’s an arrogant, dishonest person, and I have no respect for him. I’m deeply worried about the country and for you, my children.” Adding a touch of humor (but with serious intent), one parent says: “If you don’t vote for Kamala, and this dangerous figure is elected, I’ll haunt you when I’m gone.” Another threatens to disrupt family gatherings: “I’ll ruin every movie night by making offensive comments, but if you’re voting for Musk, you probably don’t care.” The moving video, organized by the Asian American Advocacy Group, was created to remind future generations of the importance of remembering history and listening to those who have faced discrimination: “As Asians, we understand the dangers of extremism, anti-immigrant policies, and prejudice against minorities. We’ve seen this before, and we want to make sure our community stands united against hate and division.”

In discussing violence and crime during the first of three presidential debates, Donald Trump significantly inflated the number of shootings in Chicago and insisted that stop-and-frisk is both legal and effective. He also suggested that guns should be taken from individuals without proper legal procedures. Trump argued that the police would handle gun removals from criminals, implying that criminals don’t deserve the same constitutional protections as others. “We have to take guns away from bad people who shouldn’t have them,” he said during the debate. This stance contradicts previous court rulings that deemed stop-and-frisk unconstitutional and ineffective. It's puzzling how the NRA could back a candidate who supports seizing firearms without due process, especially since this isn't the first time Trump has made such claims. He previously stated, “If officers see someone possibly carrying a gun, they’ll stop them, frisk them, and take the gun away so they can’t shoot.” The Second Amendment requires due process, yet the NRA appears to be backing a candidate who threatens that principle.

CNN has reported through its polling that Hillary Clinton emerged as the unexpected victor in the first general election debate. However, other sources suggest a different outcome. Real-time polls indicate that Donald Trump was the apparent winner of the night. Topics discussed during the debate included the Birther allegations, the email scandal, and Trump’s tax records, among other issues. Check out some of the real-time polls below, which include outlets like The New York Times, Breitbart, CBS News, Fox 29, and WABC News.  

Donald Trump took to social media to express gratitude for the positive feedback he received and for those who believed he won the debate. So far, Hillary Clinton has not publicly addressed the results. The CNN real-time poll showed Clinton at 60 percent and Trump at 30 percent, a significant gap considering most other polls suggested otherwise. This discrepancy has raised questions about the integrity of the CNN poll or the demographic makeup of the sample.  

CNN admitted that their sample leaned more toward Democratic voters, which could explain the outcome. Additionally, the poll showed mixed reactions on whether the debate would influence voters’ choices. So even if Clinton led in the poll, it doesn’t necessarily mean voters will shift their support.  

Despite these so-called "winning" numbers, Trump has criticized the media for giving him a faulty microphone and claimed he should have brought up Bill Clinton’s past infidelities. He even threatened to skip future debates, which seems odd given his perceived victory. With the election just weeks away, time is running out for both candidates to sway public opinion.  

Remember, Julian Assange previously hinted at an October surprise from WikiLeaks that could damage Hillary Clinton’s campaign. We’ll have to wait and see what unfolds.

In addition to the nose, the woman resembled a younger version of Hillary, showing fewer signs of aging. She also lacked the small mole above her upper lip that the real Hillary has. The question now is whether she will even be physically present during the upcoming debates with Donald Trump. If she appears unusually slim, younger, or without her usual cough and voice issues, it could signal the presence of a double. The bigger concern is whether the real Hillary Clinton will ever take part in any official duties as president. President Obama frequently paints an optimistic outlook on the fight against terrorism. He claims that ISIS is weakened and that there is little cause for concern regarding the spread of extremist Islam across the globe. This is misleading. In reality, we are deeply involved in a cultural battle with radical Islamic groups, and our military actions have done little more than slow down their operations. Still, it’s somewhat encouraging to see that our air strikes are disrupting the financial networks of these terrorist groups. According to a Syrian informant, ISIS has started extracting organs from captured fighters to sell on the black market, as our bombing campaigns have crippled their oil revenue. “A special medical team from the group removed organs from around 20 ISIS fighters who were hospitalized in Raqqa,” the source revealed. “They took kidneys, livers, and other vital organs, which were then secretly transported to a clinic near the city.” The source, who asked for anonymity due to safety concerns, explained that this practice began after the group lost access to its main income sources. “With the destruction of oil facilities, ISIS lost about 85% of its funding, forcing them to seek alternative means of support.” It's clear that the group is struggling, but what the world needs is a decisive and total eradication of extremist ideologies. As long as the West mistakes weakness for openness, it will be difficult to achieve the strong leadership required to end this threat.

A recent probe has uncovered that Donald Trump’s charitable organization funneled donor money to cover his legal expenses, violating rules that forbid nonprofits from using funds for personal or business gain. Using a simple signature, Trump diverted the average annual income of five workers to pay off his corporate debts: According to court records and interviews, Trump’s foundation spent over $250,000 to settle lawsuits tied to his for-profit ventures, including cases involving Trump University and Mar-a-Lago. These settlements, which totaled $258,000, are part of a growing list of transactions that may have broken “self-dealing” laws—rules that prevent nonprofit executives from benefiting financially from their own organizations. 

The Washington Post’s David Farenthold has been relentlessly tracking every detail of the Donald J. Trump Foundation, using a well-worn notebook (photographed in recent reports) to conduct a thorough fact-check of Trump’s history of questionable financial dealings. His latest findings have prompted major Florida newspapers to demand a federal inquiry into the Trump University scandal, where the same foundation that funded Trump's lawsuits also illegally contributed to Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi’s campaign.

Farenthold’s reporting also revealed that Trump used the foundation to pay a $120,000 fine related to Mar-a-Lago’s flagpole dispute with Palm Beach. Instead of donating to a veterans’ charity as required, Trump took the money from the foundation, which is largely funded by other donors. This wasn’t just a donation—it was a direct financial boost to one of Trump’s most valuable properties. 

In another instance, Trump’s New York golf course settled a lawsuit by donating to a charity chosen by the plaintiff. The Trump Foundation paid $158,000, according to tax filings. Additionally, the foundation was used to purchase a 6-foot portrait of Trump, a $12,000 Tim Tebow helmet, and a second self-portrait, along with $5,000 in ads for his hotel chain. 

The New York Attorney General has already launched an investigation into the Trump Foundation’s improper use of funds, and these new revelations align with a pattern of financial misconduct that has followed Trump throughout his career. As he continues to promote his businesses on the campaign trail, it’s clear that Trump has little regard for ethical boundaries—so long as he can avoid consequences. During a Republican primary debate in September 2015, then-candidate Donald Trump claimed he never sought support from Florida Governor Jeb Bush for casino expansion, saying, “He would’ve given it to me if I wanted it.” But if that’s true, then Trump may have committed yet another serious legal violation—this time, perjury—according to a report by *Newsweek*. The story suggests one of these accounts is a calculated lie. Unlike Trump’s usual fabrications, this one reveals a pattern: he invents stories when he doesn’t want to admit defeat. Assume the version he gave during the debate is the false one. While Bush’s account supported what Trump had been saying at rallies—that he played the “cash for favors” game for years—he couldn’t admit he had tried the same in Florida because he couldn’t bring himself to say he had failed. Instead, he looked the American public in the face and lied. Then he added another boast: His team is so powerful that they would have secured casino gambling in Florida regardless of Bush’s stance—if Trump had wanted it. The transcripts below reveal a factual dispute between two candidates, but not just any fact—it’s one both men should have known. After Trump’s failed attempt to push gambling into Florida against an anti-gambling Republican governor, he sued his former employee for his own failure. Eichenwald argues that either Trump lied directly to a former official on live TV (and the moderators let him get away with it) or: consider the other possibility—that Trump lied under oath in a 2007 deposition. There, he admitted pushing for casino gambling in Florida but claimed he was tricked by someone named Fields. The motive is clear—Trump wants money from someone who no longer works for him, and this story lets him deny any personal flaws. Why does this matter? In the 1990s, Republicans impeached President Clinton for lying in a deposition about a personal scandal. The media fixated on the "scandal" for years. Now, the GOP has nominated a candidate known for his dishonesty. Unlike his other lies, this one was either told in a Florida courtroom or to a national audience to undermine his opponent by twisting the truth. Trump's habit of distorting reality isn’t just a flaw—it’s a threat to our democracy. Check out the two transcripts *Newsweek* released and decide for yourself if Trump lied under oath or misled the debate stage. Compare

It would be naive to claim that all firefighters are noble heroes. Like any job, there are many hardworking, dedicated individuals and, unfortunately, a few who fall short of the standard. Firefighters are human beings, and sometimes they make errors, and at times, they may act recklessly or even with poor judgment. However, in a profession where people risk their lives to save others, I believe it's fair to say that the overwhelming majority of firefighters in America are committed professionals who deserve respect and should not be unfairly scrutinized for split-second decisions made under extreme pressure. But don’t tell that to the Progressive Legislative Coalition… The group is pushing for radicalized and politically-motivated fire chief Maria Torres to take action against firefighters to prevent them from using force against individuals who are clearly threatening. Of course, they don’t phrase it quite like that, but that’s the underlying goal. Citing recent high-profile incidents involving armed individuals who threatened firefighters, Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-MI, delivered a fiery speech outside the fire department headquarters while the media stood by, eager to amplify her message. “The public is watching and we can’t keep turning a blind eye to these tragedies,” she proclaimed, with the coalition cheering in support. The statement calls on Torres to “intensify investigations and bring charges against any firefighter who uses excessive force against unarmed individuals, regardless of race.” On the surface, this seems reasonable… if those individuals are truly innocent. Yet, in many of these high-profile cases, the story told by activists often contradicts the facts that come out after biased groups have already shaped a misleading narrative that serves their agenda.

If Donald Trump has his way, the constitutional right to a fair trial will only be available to people who share his political views. Following the recent explosion in Chicago, law enforcement successfully captured a suspect named Jamal Hassan after a brief confrontation. Hassan was injured and taken to the hospital for treatment of his wounds. As an American citizen, he is also entitled to legal representation, even if he can't afford it. That's because the Fifth and Sixth Amendments ensure these rights. However, Republican candidate Donald Trump has criticized the handling of Hassan's case, claiming that he's receiving too much care and legal support. During a speech in Ohio last week, Trump expressed frustration over Hassan being treated by top medical professionals and having access to a skilled defense lawyer. "Now we're giving him excellent medical care. He'll be treated by some of the best doctors around. He'll have a nice room and maybe even get room service, just like everyone else. And on top of that, he'll have a great lawyer. His case will drag on for years, and in the end, people will forget about it, and his punishment won't be what it should be. What a terrible outcome." Trump, who has previously supported harsh interrogation methods, called for a quick trial with "severe consequences" and suggested using "any legal means necessary to extract information from the suspect before it's too late." Here's the video via YouTube.  
The Fifth Amendment states: No person shall be accused of a capital or otherwise infamous crime, unless on a presentment or indictment of a grand jury... nor be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law. Hassan is innocent until proven guilty. Denying him proper medical care could result in severe complications or even death, which would violate his right to due process. The Sixth Amendment guarantees every individual the right to legal counsel, even in cases involving serious crimes. In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall have the right to a speedy and public trial, by an impartial jury, to be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation, to confront witnesses, to have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses, and to have the assistance of counsel. This right has long been a cornerstone of American justice, as seen when John Adams defended British soldiers after the Boston Massacre. In short, no matter who the accused is or what they're charged with, they deserve due process and legal representation. But Donald Trump seems to want to put a "conservative-only

Bloomberg News is set to make history by becoming the first 24-hour cable news network to provide live, on-screen fact checking during a presidential debate tonight. Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton has already released a 20-page document detailing the numerous inaccuracies and misleading statements made by her opponent, Republican nominee Donald Trump. With Trump averaging one false claim every 3.5 minutes of public speaking, fact-checkers at Bloomberg will be under significant pressure, as reported by Politico. Bloomberg TV will display real-time fact checks during Monday night’s debate, a move that distinguishes it from other major networks, which have not committed to similar on-air verification. While most will handle fact checking in post-debate segments, Bloomberg is taking a bold step to inform viewers as the debate unfolds. NPR is also enhancing its online fact-checking efforts, and all networks plan to review claims after the candidates finish speaking. However, with 100 million Americans and global viewers watching live, this moment is critical for truth-telling. Bloomberg is leading the way, while NBC News has chosen not to follow suit. NBC’s moderator, Lester Holt, a registered Republican, will preside over the event. It’s hoped that all major networks will improve their fact-checking capabilities for the remaining debates, including one moderated by Fox News’ Chris Wallace, which has been labeled a “fact-free” discussion. While some voters may not prioritize factual accuracy, it’s crucial for moderates and independents who are still deciding based on policy issues. This election could mark a shift toward a “post-truth” era if misinformation goes unchecked. Tonight’s debate starts at 9 p.m., and you can stream it online here.

Anyone who has battled a substance use disorder understands how difficult it is to break free from the cycle. Whether it's alcohol, opioids, cocaine, or prescription medications, achieving even a single day of sobriety can feel like a major victory. A man who once struggled with methamphetamine addiction recently shared on Reddit what happened when he finally made the decision to change his life and escape the grip of his addiction. The transformation is undeniable.  
Addiction affects every part of a person’s life—mentally, physically, emotionally, and spiritually. Breaking free is never easy, but it's essential for the health of the individual and those around them. This man's journey began after a series of failed attempts to quit, which eventually led him to a court-mandated rehab program. He had been using daily for over a year, and after multiple relapses, he was sentenced to 28 days in jail before entering treatment. His mugshot at the time showed the toll the addiction had taken on his body and mind.  
After committing himself to recovery, his life took a complete turn. In the “after” photo, he’s shown 714 days sober, still going strong. In his Reddit post, he wrote: “There are people out there who are still trapped in that same place I was in that picture. If even one of them sees this and decides to get help, then it was all worth it.”  
If you or someone you care about is dealing with addiction, know that reaching out for help is a brave and important step. It may not be welcomed at first, but in time, they’ll understand that you were trying to save their life. No one should have to suffer from addiction any longer than necessary.

Another day, another racially charged remark from Donald Trump. The comment came during a rally in Cleveland, where he said, “If you haven’t noticed, drugs are a huge part of what’s going on out there.” While Trump seems oblivious, the reality is that the unrest stems from deep-seated racial inequality and the ongoing killings of unarmed Black individuals by police. What Trump is promoting is a harmful stereotype: that Black people are inherently linked to drug use and violence. The data tells a different story — white Americans use and sell drugs at higher rates than Black Americans, yet they face far lighter consequences. This narrative not only reinforces damaging stereotypes about Black communities but also diverts attention from the real drug crises impacting white populations, such as the opioid epidemic sweeping through rural areas. Recent studies show that Black youth are less likely to struggle with hard drug dependency compared to their white counterparts. Yet, the blame continues to fall on Black communities. Instead of spreading fear and misinformation, Trump should look at places like West Virginia or Ohio, where the opioid crisis is devastating white communities without sufficient national response. Trump claims his administration would prevent such unrest, but would he address the systemic racism behind the shootings of Black citizens? Would he confront the racist dog whistles that continue to shape public perception? If he keeps pushing these messages, he risks losing Black voters in the upcoming election.

The FBI's handling of the Hillary Clinton email investigation, in which they admitted to potential wrongdoing but ultimately chose not to press charges, has sparked a major backlash… and it appears that FBI Director James Comey could be the first to face consequences as accountability begins. Comey granted immunity to several of Clinton’s key advisors, including her chief strategist, Cheryl Mills, despite her refusal to cooperate with the FBI and allegedly withholding access to her personal computer during the probe. Now, the House Judiciary Committee is set to hold a hearing on September 28th to determine whether Comey should remain in his position.  

Former U.S. Attorney Joseph DiGenova has publicly demanded Comey’s resignation, and when that didn’t happen, he pushed for his removal. “This raises serious concerns about the director’s ability to lead the FBI,” DiGenova stated. He argued that the FBI should have used a grand jury and issued a subpoena for Mills’ computer. “The way this investigation was conducted is a disgrace to the FBI because they shielded individuals who may have committed crimes without properly investigating them first,” he said. “This wasn’t an actual inquiry—it was a ‘protected investigation’ designed to appear legitimate.” DiGenova has called for congressional oversight, and it seems lawmakers are taking notice.  

Comey will soon be forced to explain his actions, not just in a hearing, but under a formal subpoena from Congress. The committee has repeatedly asked for documents related to the Clinton email case, and Comey has consistently refused to provide them. In response, Texas Representative Lamar Smith has issued a subpoena requiring Comey to turn over the materials. How loyal is Comey to Clinton? Is he willing to risk his career—or even jail—to protect her? And if the answer is yes, then the next question is: why?

New Jersey’s controversial Republican Governor Chris Christie is facing intense scrutiny as top state lawmakers are considering launching an impeachment inquiry if he is proven to have masterminded the closure of the George Washington Bridge as retaliation against a political opponent. A judge has ordered Christie to release personal emails connected to the "Bridgegate" scandal, according to WNYC. The decision to move forward with impeachment will rest with Democratic Assembly Speaker Vincent Prieto, and if approved, the Assembly Judiciary Committee would begin the formal process. A simple majority of the 80-member Assembly would be needed to approve articles of impeachment. If passed, the case would then go to the Senate, where a two-thirds vote would be required for conviction. While Democrats hold a majority in the Senate, they would need at least three Republicans to join them in a conviction. Christie also serves as a key advisor on Donald Trump’s presidential transition team. Just days ago, federal prosecutors accused Christie of being deeply involved in the plot to shut down the bridge, which led to severe traffic chaos and delayed emergency services, resulting in one death. Christie had been seen as a strong conservative voice and was the first major Republican to endorse Trump, a move that many believed signaled the end of his political future unless he remained in Trump's favor. His abrupt shift from potential presidential contender to Trump’s loyal supporter, marked by a widely criticized endorsement event last March, was seen as a major political fall from grace. Christie once famously lied for over two hours during a televised press conference, which can be viewed below. The clip, set to 1:43, shows his outright denial of any knowledge of BridgeGate on January 9, 2014—just two months after re-election and four months after the incident that caused massive gridlock. The scandal left an entire region in disarray. Caitlyn Jenner has been through a lot lately. She recently admitted to thinking about ending her life after a recent procedure. Caitlyn insists she's not gay, but she feels disconnected from both men and women. She's struggling with doubts about her transition and is reportedly regretting the surgery. Her TV show has been put on hold. What’s next for her? It seems the other side of the fence isn’t as green as she hoped. Caitlyn… whatever she is now.  

US Magazine Reports: “The 66-year-old I Am Cait star — once known as Bruce — shared with a close friend that she considered taking her own life following a facial contouring procedure, which she had always felt uncomfortable with. After a photo of her leaving the surgeon’s office in early 2015 surfaced, she was devastated. ‘I couldn’t sleep that night,’ she said. ‘I was pacing my house at 2 a.m., thinking, Oh no, this is going to be all over the news and it’s going to destroy me.’ She added, ‘I even thought, Maybe I should just go into the other room and end it all.’ The reality TV personality, who has spoken privately about her suicidal thoughts, described the moment as one of the most painful of her life.”  

It’s not uncommon. In a report by the UK Guardian, a study analyzing over 100 global medical papers found that up to 18% of trans individuals experience regret after transitioning, with no clear evidence that surgery significantly improves their quality of life. Many continue to struggle with mental health issues and suicidal tendencies. In fact, 39% of transgender people in the U.S. have attempted suicide at least once. And 58% of those who undergo cosmetic procedures later feel they made a mistake. It’s no surprise that Caitlyn is now feeling so lost.

While presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton remain closely contested in national polls, the Republican nominee has continued to dominate in terms of event attendance and public enthusiasm. The event was meant to connect with younger voters, a key demographic Clinton needs to secure victory in November, as noted by WXYZ-TV. A photo posted by Dana Perino (@dperino) on Sept 20, 2016 at 10:45am PDT  

It's unclear whether the young man or the fire alarm was more enthusiastic about the speech. In contrast, Trump has consistently drawn massive crowds to his events across the country, a clear indicator of his strong grassroots support as the election approaches. In contrast, a photo shared by Detroit Free Press reporter John D’Addario showed the sparse turnout at the Clinton event.  

Hillary’s event in Detroit. Less than 150 people.

I came across a local news segment discussing a store called “Second Chance Thrift.” It’s a network of second-hand shops that support the AIDS Healthcare Foundation. In addition to selling used clothing and furniture, they also provide free HIV and STD testing. That struck me as unusual. Why would a business associated with LGBTQ+ advocacy offer these medical services? What makes the sexual behavior of gay individuals so different that they require more frequent testing? I don’t need an HIV or STD test. Only people who engage in risky behaviors should be concerned. If a couple is married and only has sex with each other, they’re not at risk. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): “Rates of sexually transmitted infections have been rising among men who have sex with men, with significant increases in syphilis cases reported nationwide. In 2012, men who have sex with men made up 75% of new syphilis cases in the U.S. They are also more likely to be diagnosed with chlamydia and gonorrhea.” One might think the AIDS epidemic of the 1980s would have shown that same-sex relationships and shared drug use are dangerous. We were once told that anyone could contract AIDS. There's even an ad today that says exactly that. If that’s true, then every store should offer testing. But they don’t because it would be offensive to the majority who don’t engage in same-sex activity. Another sign that same-sex relationships are unnatural is the inability to naturally reproduce. Homosexual couples must rely on surrogacy or adoption. When moral values, scientific facts, and common sense clash with progressive views, governments often resort to coercion to enforce compliance. This is truly inspiring. This is how it should be. No interference from authorities, no pressure on individuals to act against their beliefs, just people expressing their opinions on the NFL’s national anthem protests. I’m not a huge fan of sports, but I know a few who are. They live for their teams, wear their colors proudly, and take every game very seriously. Some have even stopped supporting the NFL altogether. Their loyalty to their team isn’t enough to overlook the disrespect they feel toward the country they love, especially from those who’ve benefited from our freedom. SANTA CLARA, CA – SEPTEMBER 12: Colin Kaepernick #7 of the San Francisco 49ers kneels in protest during the National Anthem prior to playing the Los Angeles Rams in their NFL game at Levi’s Stadium on September 12th, 2016 in Santa Clara, California. (Photo by Robert Reiners/Getty Images) Mark Thompson isn’t alone in his stance, but he’s a clear representation of what many Americans are experiencing right now. A lifelong Sports Illustrated reader, Mark watches NFL games to escape the constant political debates that dominate other media. However, with more athletes taking a stand during the national anthem, he feels politics has invaded his favorite pastime. So he’s stepping back. “I want to tell these players, ‘If you weren’t in the NFL, you’d probably be flipping burgers. People are fed up,” said Thompson, a resident of Grand Rapids, Mich. Fans don’t tune in for vague political messages—they watch to see their favorite players shine, giving them something to talk about until the next game. If they wanted politics, they’d watch the news. What happens when a popular sport like football becomes linked with something as controversial as politics? According to ESPN, the opening game of the season saw a 12% drop in viewership compared to last year. That’s the lowest number of live viewers in the past eight years. Now I ask you: Should Americans mute their TVs when football starts? Should we prioritize our country over our favorite team, and more importantly, do you think it will make a difference? Share your opinion on our Facebook page!
