Lionel McGee, a Black officer in the sheriff’s office, echoed this sentiment, noting that not all BLM supporters back law enforcement. “Some people in the movement will never support cops,” he said. “I’ve had this conversation with my own sister about the Michael Brown case. I probably would have done the same thing. The incident with Eric Garner—he could have just gone to jail instead

A key figure in Trump's campaign in Cuyahoga County, Ohio—a pivotal area in the state—made a statement that has sparked widespread outrage. She claimed that racial discrimination only began after Obama took office, calling it the most outlandish remark of the season. While it's easy to dismiss her claim as nonsense, we'll take a closer look at why it's not only false but deeply harmful. In an interview with a local news outlet, Sarah Thompson, the county's campaign director, said: “There was no racism before Obama. We didn’t have these issues back then.” It seems she’s suggesting that white people were somehow unaware of the deep-rooted nature of racism in their own culture. This is, of course, completely untrue. She continued with a series of damaging remarks about the Black community, ignoring the systemic challenges they face daily: “If you're Black and haven't succeeded in the last 50 years, it's your fault. You had the same opportunities, the same schools, and even extra help to go to college that white kids didn’t get. You just didn’t make the most of it.” *Disgusting*. For someone who clearly doesn’t understand history, let’s explain why this is not only wrong but offensive. She even insisted that racism wasn’t an issue during her childhood in the 1970s. What? Segregation, Jim Crow, and ongoing discrimination? Black people have faced a justice system that disproportionately targets them, breaking up families and limiting future opportunities. Many attend underfunded schools dominated by white administrators who still carry the legacy of racism. Black people were stripped of their freedom and wealth for generations, and the effects of that oppression are still felt today. This person is living in a fantasy world, and their views pose a real threat to our society. And all of this, according to her, is Obama’s fault. Former President George H.W. Bush is breaking with his party's presidential candidate and has decided to support Hillary Clinton in the upcoming election, according to a member of another prominent political family, the Kennedys. At 92, Bush had planned to remain neutral in the contest between Clinton and Donald Trump, a quiet indication of his discomfort with the GOP nominee. However, his preference for the wife of his predecessor, President Bill Clinton, was revealed through Kathleen Hartington Kennedy Townsend, a former Maryland lieutenant governor and daughter of the late Robert F. Kennedy.  

The story broke when Townsend posted a photo on her Facebook page showing her shaking hands with the former president, accompanied by the caption: "The President told me he’s voting for Hillary!!" In a recent phone call, Townsend said she met with Bush in Maine and that he confirmed his intention to vote for a Democratic candidate. “That’s what he said,” she told The New York Times.  

When asked about Townsend’s post, George H.W. Bush’s spokesperson, Jim McGrath, responded via email: “President Bush will cast his vote as a private citizen in about 50 days, and he will not be commenting on the presidential race until then.”  

The Bush family has largely remained out of the current political spotlight after supporting their son Jeb’s failed presidential campaign earlier this year. Neither George H.W. Bush nor his son, George W. Bush, attended the Republican National Convention in Cleveland where Trump was officially nominated.  

Several former GOP figures from both Bush administrations have also expressed support for Clinton over Trump, including national security advisor Brent Scowcroft and former Commerce Secretary Carlos Gutierrez. However, former Vice President Dan Quayle has continued to back Trump, telling POLITICO earlier this year that he still hopes both Bushes would eventually endorse the Republican candidate. “I hope they’ll come around, but they can speak for themselves,” he said in an interview.

How can you tell when a candidate is so exhausted and out of touch that they’re clearly not ready to face the public for an hour? While opinions may vary, there are definite red flags. Joe Biden has been campaigning nonstop for weeks, constantly under the spotlight, with little time to recharge. At 80 years old, he shows no signs of slowing down. He’s not only preparing for a high-stakes debate with a seasoned leader (regardless of his denials, he knows the truth) but instead of taking a break, he suddenly flies to Youngstown to hold a rally. It’s starting to show. On Friday night, just hours before he’s set to step onto the stage for what could be the most critical moment of his campaign, Joe Biden is displaying signs that he’s pushing himself beyond his limits. His latest social media post is all over the place—jumping from one unrelated topic to another. This incoherent message suggests his mind is unfocused, and while each subject might have once been a key issue to appeal to different groups, together they make no sense: A mass shooting in Texas by a foreign national. A surge in violent crime across the Midwest. And a protest in Pennsylvania! — Joe Biden (@JoeBiden) October 1, 2020. What on earth is he trying to say? If you want to appeal to voters who fear violence, you talk about crime. If you want to connect with those worried about rising violence in their communities, you address it directly. If you're trying to win over younger voters, you focus on protests and social issues. Bringing them all together shows one thing: Biden is losing his grip. He’s clearly not prepared for the debate and may not be fit to lead. This could be the beginning of the end for the Biden campaign. Featured image from file.

Viewers of tonight’s debate between Joe Biden and Donald Trump who decide to drink every time Biden makes an exaggerated claim could potentially face severe health risks, according to the US Surgeon General. Following the chaotic exchanges of the 2016 debates, there was a noticeable spike in alcohol-related emergency room visits, with over 60,000 additional cases reported in the following week. Given the frequent overstatements from Biden during his campaign, medical officials are warning of a possible surge in alcohol poisoning incidents tonight. According to The New York Times, Biden made at least one misleading statement every four minutes during a recent five-day stretch. Similar concerns were raised last year before the Democratic primary debates, when emergency services saw a rise in alcohol-related calls. Surgeon General Vivek Murthy stated, “We are preparing for an alarming increase in alcohol poisoning across the country as people participate in drinking games during the debate. The risk is especially high when watching political debates filled with unverified claims.” With the current candidates, the likelihood of exaggerated statements has never been higher. The Mayo Clinic warns that symptoms of alcohol poisoning include slurred speech, loss of coordination, unconsciousness, slow or irregular breathing, and cold, clammy skin. Please stay informed and make responsible choices while watching the debate.

Guess who George H.W. Bush is supporting this election? He lost to Bill Clinton in 1992, and his son, George W. Bush, also served as president. Yet it appears that the former president is so unimpressed with Donald Trump that he's actually planning to vote for Hillary Clinton. According to sources close to the former president, Bush had initially intended to stay out of the public conversation about this election. As a lifelong Republican, his decision to support a Democratic candidate is quite surprising. However, it wasn’t Bush himself who made the revelation. It was Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, daughter of the late Robert Kennedy, who shared the news on her social media: “On Monday, Townsend posted a photo on Facebook of herself shaking hands with the former president, captioning it: ‘The President told me he’s voting for Hillary!!’” She later confirmed the statement when speaking to reporters. According to Townsend, George H.W. Bush would rather back his old opponent’s wife than the controversial figure that is Donald Trump. A representative for the Bush family declined to confirm the claim, stating that the former president’s choice remains private. While Bush hasn’t spoken publicly, some of those close to him have been more open, according to Townsend. Earlier this year, Bush made it clear he had no intention of endorsing Trump, calling it a bold move for a Republican, given that Trump’s policies and rhetoric clash with traditional conservative values. His admiration for Russian leader Vladimir Putin further fuels concerns about his alignment with autocratic tendencies. This isn’t the first time a prominent Republican has distanced themselves from Trump — earlier this summer, a former aide to George W. Bush announced she would be voting for Hillary Clinton. Jeb Bush has also expressed difficulty supporting either major candidate. A former Republican president choosing not to back the party’s nominee is a significant and unexpected shift.

Amazing how these politicians seem to know what's best for us. They've done the thinking for the public, deciding that this is the way forward. It looks like American voters don’t really have a voice. No matter who you vote for, let the political factions fight among themselves, and let the public support their chosen side. But what do these leaders tell voters about the trade policies they pass? Why are these deals kept secret until after the votes are cast? Why is it that the public only learns about these agreements after they’ve been approved? Did they even ask voters if these trade deals should be signed? Did they seek input on whether they should be changed or canceled? The corporate elite are focused on maximizing profits, even if it means sacrificing American jobs, and free trade pacts have become their guiding principles. Donald Trump, the self-proclaimed “law and order” candidate, painted a grim portrayal of life in America’s “inner cities.” “We have inner cities where African-Americans and Hispanics are living in constant danger—this is a crisis,” he stated earlier this week. He praised former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani’s controversial “stop-and-frisk” policy as a way to reduce crime in urban areas. However, his claims were quickly challenged by data and officials from his own city. The NYPD’s Assistant Commissioner for Communication & Public Information, J. Peter Donald, directly refuted Trump’s misleading statements during a recent debate. He criticized the Republican nominee for spreading falsehoods and suggesting that the NYPD isn’t capable of maintaining public safety. Trump, according to Donald, is trying to appear tough on crime, but his proposals are really just coded appeals to white nationalist supporters. The “stop-and-frisk” program was not only ineffective, but it also disproportionately targeted minorities. After its suspension in 2011 under Mayor Bloomberg, crime rates actually dropped. Trump is promoting a dystopian image of America that doesn’t reflect reality—and the police officers he’s trying to win over aren’t fooled.

Through the course of this election cycle, a shadow has loomed over Trump’s campaign – not just one shadow, but several. Racist, bigoted, and misleading ones. But the one that’s grabbing attention is “why hasn’t Trump released his tax returns?” The answer, as Trump revealed during the first presidential debate, is that he hasn’t paid any federal income tax in years. Trump accused Clinton of wasting taxpayer money, claiming it could have been used for vital infrastructure projects — the kind Republicans like Trump usually oppose. Clinton seized the moment to take a jab at the GOP candidate’s financial history. “Maybe because you haven’t paid any federal income tax in a long time,” she said, skillfully setting the trap. And Trump didn’t take long to fall into it. In an attempt to counter her, he accidentally confirmed her claim: “It would be wasted too, believe me.” Note the word “would.” If Trump had actually paid taxes, he wouldn’t have used that phrasing, especially after calling taxes “smart” earlier in the debate. Could this be why he’s resisting disclosure, claiming he’ll only release them “against his lawyer’s advice” if Clinton releases her deleted emails? Is Trump trying to hide the fact that he’s a tax avoider who doesn’t contribute his fair share? When Trump says “believe me,” take it to heart — not about the money being “wasted,” but about his own belief that it “would” be if he had paid. Watch the clip below:

This is a true story. General Stanley McChrystal served as the top U.S. commander in Afghanistan and often clashed with his political leadership over strategy. One day, he was summoned to the Oval Office, sensing his military career might be ending. When President Barack Obama called him in, McChrystal knew the meeting wouldn’t end well. Obama accused him of not backing him politically. “Sir, my duty is to support you as Commander-in-Chief, not as a politician,” McChrystal said, then handed in his resignation.  
Barack Obama has long been seen as unfriendly toward the military. He rarely lets people have the last word, but this time he didn’t get the final say. After accepting McChrystal’s resignation, the president made a sharp comment: “I bet when I’m gone, you’ll be glad to pee on my grave.” The general saluted and replied, “Mr. President, I always vowed I’d never stand in line again after leaving the Army. Good job, General McChrystal. I’m sure after a few years, the line will be shorter, and you won’t have to wait. You’re an honorable man — I know you’d never cut in front of others.”

Scene number one – Cairo, Egypt: I am packing my suitcase. Finally, I’m about to make my dream come true. I’m heading to a country that values knowledge and respects its scholars. I’m ready to step into the modern world. Scene number two – Los Angeles, America: I feel nervous. This is my first time stepping on American soil. I’m excited, but also anxious. It’s a new chapter, and I’m full of hope, yet I can’t shake the fear. What if this is all just a fantasy? Scene number three – Chicago, Illinois: I’m not dreaming — it’s real. I’m in an American classroom for the first time. I pinched myself to confirm I was awake. Scene number four – a few weeks after arriving: I had a terrible nightmare. I walked out of the lecture hall and saw all the professors, staff, and students lined up. At the front, there was a TV in the dean’s office. A major incident had taken place. I prayed it was just a dream. But it wasn’t. It was real. Scene number five – I stood in line, heart pounding: What if they were from my country? Please, God, don’t let them be Muslims. The news broke — they were Muslims, and worse, the leader was from my homeland. I was stunned. I covered my face in shame and tried to walk away. An American professor placed a hand on my shoulder, offering comfort. A young student whispered: “Be careful. Some people might act out of fear.” I didn’t have a car, but a stranger offered to drive me home. I came here to study and build a future. Later, I realized the greatest benefit was being surrounded by open-minded people. Scene number six – many weeks later, I was at the airport: Every time I tried to board, I was randomly selected for a full body search. This time, after being checked thoroughly, I was about to step onto the plane with my carry-on when a security officer said: “Sir, you can’t bring that bag on board.” I shouted, “I have the right to carry this!” He repeated, almost pleading: “Please, you can’t have that bag.” His fear silenced me. I handed it over. I whispered, “What’s a little harassment compared to what others have sacrificed for this country?” The views expressed in this opinion article are solely those of their author and are

Reince Priebus openly warned Kasich and other Republican figures that they must fully back Donald Trump or risk losing their political futures. John Kasich, however, remains unmoved by Priebus’s intimidation tactics. During a recent interview, the GOP chair suggested that Republicans who refuse to align with Trump could face serious consequences in future elections. “Those people need to get on board,” Priebus said, “and if they’re thinking about running again, I think we’ll look at the nomination process and it won’t be easy for them. In South Carolina, you have to commit to the nominee, no matter who they are. The question is, what’s the penalty? It’s not a threat, but we have a process in place.” Kasich has consistently refused to endorse Trump and has strongly criticized Priebus’s approach. His campaign spokesperson, John Weaver, responded sharply, stating, “There are still leaders who prioritize principle over party loyalty. While some in the party may see politics as a game, Governor Kasich is focused on the bigger picture. He’s working across the country to help down-ballot Republicans avoid a major loss under Priebus’s leadership.” Weaver also suggested that Priebus should be grateful to Kasich. As Kasich looks toward future elections, it will be interesting to see whether Priebus will follow through on his threats or reverse course. Threatening politicians with political destruction simply because they don’t support a party’s chosen candidate sounds more like the behavior of authoritarian regimes than a democratic institution. This kind of pressure undermines the values of freedom and fair representation. If anyone is responsible for the current toxic climate in the GOP, it’s Reince Priebus. Those who stand up to Trump are the ones defending the party’s integrity.

Months ago, former First Lady Laura Bush surprised many when she expressed her preference for voting for Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton over any Republican in the upcoming election. While Jeb Bush and both George W. Bush and George H.W. Bush have largely stayed silent on the race, they’ve now made a bold statement. Rumors are circulating that George H.W. Bush has decided not to support the GOP’s chosen candidate, a move that has caused quite a stir. Not only is he refusing to back his own party, but he's reportedly casting his ballot for the Democratic nominee instead. This decision has sparked intense debate, with some calling it a strategic choice for the country’s future. The Trump campaign, unsurprisingly, has reacted strongly. In a recent appearance on CNN, Kellyanne Conway criticized the elder Bush’s decision, suggesting it was driven by personal feelings rather than political judgment. She pointed out the irony of Bush supporting “the wife of the man who beat him in 1992,” and blamed the painful primary season for his apparent shift. Conway stated, “Jeb Bush didn’t meet expectations, and there are definitely hurt feelings.” You can watch the full interview below: “Jeb Bush really failed…there are a lot of hurt feelings” @KellyannePolls on Bush 41 voting #Clinton https://t.co/iyhiLRgrPL — OutFrontCNN (@OutFrontCNN) September 20, 2016  
This kind of reaction from the Trump team is expected. The Bush family is making a thoughtful, informed choice, something that clearly challenges the campaign’s narrow perspective. This election isn’t just about party lines—it’s about choosing a leader who can steer the nation in the right direction, and the Bushes seem to understand that.

There has been growing debate about the fatal shooting of Keith Scott by Charlotte police. According to the police, the incident was a necessary response as Scott was holding a gun and posed a threat. However, Scott’s supporters argue that he was simply waiting for his kids at the bus stop and was holding a book, not a weapon. The truth remains unclear, but new information from Scott’s wife could offer further insight.  

Investigations into Scott’s past reveal that Rakeyia Scott had previously filed a restraining order against him, alleging physical abuse. In the document, she stated, “He hit my 8-year-old daughter in the head with his fist three times… He kicked me and threatened to kill us with his gun. He called himself a ‘killer’ and we should know that.” The form also asked if law enforcement should consider him a threat, and she responded “yes,” noting that he carried a 9mm handgun. The order was submitted on October 9th, 2015, but was later dropped by Scott’s wife just days later.  

This detail appears to support the police claim that Scott was armed and dangerous. Police have released dashcam and bodycam footage, along with images of the gun found on Scott at the scene. The weapon was reportedly the same one stolen from a home during a break-in.  

Officers also dispute the claim that Scott was peacefully waiting for his children. They initially noticed him rolling a blunt, which they did not immediately act on. However, when they saw him holding a gun, they intervened, citing the danger of combining drugs and firearms. The officers, who were in plain clothes at first, then put on marked uniforms and repeatedly ordered Scott to drop the weapon. He refused. DNA and fingerprints matching Scott were found on the loaded gun, reinforcing the police's stance.  

Once again, critics say the Black Lives Matter movement is using a lawful police action to incite unrest and promote a narrative of injustice.

Comedian and actor Zach Galifianakis recently had former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on his improvisational comedy interview show, *Between Two Ferns*. He’s previously interviewed President Obama, as well as stars like Leonardo DiCaprio and Ariana Grande, but there's one person he's absolutely not interested in featuring. In a recent chat with *Rolling Stone*, Galifianakis was asked if he’d ever consider having Republican nominee Donald Trump on the show, following the success of his Clinton segment — and his response was both sharp and funny. “No way. It doesn’t interest me. Doing it the other way around? Not my style. He’s the type who craves attention — any kind of attention. So you’re dealing with someone who’s a little unhinged. I wouldn’t want to put someone in that position who’s so mentally unstable. It would be taking advantage of them. And you can quote me on that.” *Between Two Ferns* is famous for its awkward exchanges and the host’s tendency to ask provocative questions (he once asked Obama, “How does it feel to know you might be the last white president?”). The humor comes from both sides trying to stay calm and not react. Considering how Trump reacts aggressively to even minor criticism and never lets anything slide, it's clear Galifianakis made the right call. But it's deeply concerning that someone who can't handle a comedy interview could still be a serious contender for the presidency — he’s repeatedly shown he’s not suited for the role.

It appears that FBI Director James Comey is finding himself in a deepening firestorm, with the heat rising by the day. He allowed Hillary Clinton to escape without consequence over the email scandal, despite acknowledging her dishonesty and potential guilt. The reasoning behind this decision remains a mystery to many. Comey released heavily redacted transcripts from his conversations with Clinton, which offered little clarity. Meanwhile, Attorney General Loretta Lynch faced criticism for meeting with Bill Clinton shortly before Hillary's case was dropped, raising questions about whether she was briefed on how to respond during her testimony. Congress has repeatedly asked Comey for specific documents related to the email investigation, but he has consistently refused to hand them over. In response, Texas Representative Lamar Smith issued a subpoena demanding the release of these materials. According to the Daily Caller, FBI Director Comey’s recommendation to not pursue charges against Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton for her use of a private email server while at the State Department continues to draw sharp criticism from political analysts. The handling of the case, including Comey's release of censored interview notes and Lynch's private meeting with Bill Clinton, has come under intense scrutiny. After questioning Comey on Capitol Hill, lawmakers requested the documents to better understand the extent of Clinton’s off-the-record email activities. However, Comey has yet to provide them, prompting Congress to push harder for transparency. The Washington Times reported that House Science Committee Chairman Lamar Smith, R-Texas, issued a subpoena to Comey for information regarding the security of Clinton’s private email account and server. Smith had previously requested the documents in a letter, but the subpoena followed after Comey failed to comply. “The committee still has concerns about the structure and security of the email system used by former Secretary Clinton and whether she and her staff met the cybersecurity standards required by FISMA,” the committee stated. But I suspect they’ll face the same resistance as always — from the Obama administration, the FBI, and the Clintons. It seems the three branches of government are no longer independent. The Executive Branch holds too much power, the Judicial Branch is too compliant, and the Legislative Branch is left powerless. There’s no clearer example of this imbalance than the ongoing controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton.

I’d say our leader is ineffective, but honestly, this goes way beyond that and into outright negligence. He’s made some questionable decisions and said a few thoughtless things in the past, but this? This is just out of touch in the worst way. If you're reading this, you’ve probably been following the news or at least aware of recent events. If so, you already know about the shootings in Chicago and Dallas last week, as well as the fire that broke out in Phoenix. You’d expect that something like this would prompt an immediate response from our leaders, but you’d be wrong. You’d hope the person you elected would at least show some support for the victims, especially when it's happening right here at home. You’d hope they'd do it for the people, even if not for the sake of genuine concern, just for political gain. Well, apparently, our leader doesn’t feel that way. In a time when government and media continue to expand, a dedicated American has uncovered what the Department of Justice and major news outlets have failed (or refused) to reveal: Evidence suggesting that Hillary Clinton was involved in a deliberate effort to conceal her use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State. Thanks to the reach of social media, a Twitter user known as @ConservativeThinkTank has compiled a series of digital clues that have now been shared with the House Judiciary Committee, prompting a fresh inquiry. Paul Combetta, the IT expert who worked for Hillary Clinton, is alleged to have sought assistance from the public via the online forum Reddit under the username “stonetear” during the summer and fall of 2014. He posted numerous questions asking for technical guidance on how to delete or alter emails, specifically referencing an "unknown high-profile client" whose details needed to be removed from both active and archived email systems. One of his posts read, “I’m dealing with a situation where I need to remove a VIP’s email address from a number of archived messages. They don’t want this information exposed. Any advice on how to do this safely?” The House Judiciary Committee has requested that Reddit preserve all related content for further review. While the outcome of the investigation remains uncertain, it is clear that ordinary citizens have unearthed what powerful institutions have tried to suppress: potential evidence of illegal activity by Hillary Clinton. The key question now is whether the username “stonetear” can be definitively linked to Paul Combetta. If not, the case remains circumstantial. If it can, it would establish a direct connection between Clinton and a suspected cover-up. @ConservativeThinkTank has presented several pieces of evidence supporting the claim that “stonetear” is indeed Combetta. This story has not received much attention, likely due to media reluctance to spotlight a regular citizen's investigative work. As more people become aware of this development and the evidence is formally submitted to the committee, the efforts of everyday Americans—like @ConservativeThinkTank and the writers at IPatriot—will continue to challenge the status quo. The Benghazi scandal and the misleading narrative that Hillary Clinton has spun around it is something she’d probably like to erase from history. Fortunately, there are brave citizens across the country who won’t let her get away with it. Take this young man, for example. His name is Ethan, and unlike many of his peers, he’s a firm believer in conservative values. This was clearly shown when he showed up at school wearing a bold "Hillary for Jail 2016" T-shirt. He regularly debates politics with one of his teachers, who happens to be a known liberal. What happened next was nothing short of inspiring.  

Ethan wore his “Hillary for Jail 2016” shirt to high school, which caught the attention of a pro-Clinton teacher with whom he often discusses politics. According to a post from his father on social media, the teacher asked, “Did you wear that for me?” Ethan calmly replied, “No, for Chris Stevens.” The teacher was taken aback, and the class was left in stunned silence. The story, originally shared online, has since been removed, likely due to pressure from those who don’t want such voices to be heard. But Ethan's courage deserves recognition. He stood up against political bias in a classroom setting, reminding everyone that it's okay to speak out—even when it's uncomfortable. Christopher Stevens, the U.S. Ambassador to Libya, died during the Benghazi attack under Hillary Clinton’s tenure as Secretary of State. This tale, though briefly circulated online, highlights the importance of standing firm in one's beliefs. (Source: American Free Press) h/t Mike Lindell

Germany's chancellor Angela Merkel has long championed the admission of large numbers of Syrian refugees, pushing for an open-door policy that led to a dramatic surge in migration. This decision quickly spiraled into chaos, with reports of widespread crime, including numerous sexual assaults and violent incidents across German cities over the past year. Faced with growing public anger, the German electorate delivered a severe blow to Merkel’s conservative party, voting them out in overwhelming numbers. In response, Merkel took the podium to backtrack on her earlier stance, admitting that the migrant crisis could have been managed better and expressing regret over her decisions. She described multiculturalism as a “false promise,” and echoed her famous slogan, “we can do this,” while hinting that Germany needed to regain control over immigration flows. “Continuing the current pace of arrivals will eventually strain the state and society beyond its limits,” she warned. Despite the backlash, she refused to set a strict cap on incoming migrants, instead pledging to reduce numbers through coordinated efforts at the national, European, and global levels. She defended her initial decision to allow mass migration, calling it a “moral obligation,” and urged the party to draw on its historical resilience to overcome the crisis. Merkel proposed a combination of stricter border controls, increased support for Turkey to manage refugee flows, and a more equitable distribution system among EU countries. She also highlighted steps already taken in Germany, such as expediting deportations of those whose asylum claims were denied. Having led the country for over a decade, she tried to project optimism, claiming Germany was no longer the “sick man of Europe” and was becoming a more open, tolerant, and forward-looking nation. While some may appreciate her shift, many feel it’s too late to undo the damage. As the U.S. election approaches, the same pattern is repeating—Hillary Clinton continues to push for more immigration, and if she wins, the consequences could be dire. It’s time to take a stand and vote wisely in November. (Source: Daily Mail)

Donald Trump, the self-proclaimed “law and order” candidate, painted a grim image of urban life, claiming that African-American and Hispanic communities in inner cities are trapped in a cycle of violence and danger. "We have inner cities where people are living in hell because it's so unsafe," he stated earlier this week. He praised the now-defunct "stop-and-frisk" policy, originally used by former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani, as a way to combat crime in densely populated areas. However, his claims were quickly challenged by factual data, and the police department in his own city called him out for spreading misleading information and implying that the NYPD isn't doing its job effectively. During the debate, NYPD Assistant Commissioner for Communications and Public Information, J. Peter Donald, directly addressed Trump’s false narratives, stating that the Republican’s push to bring back "stop-and-frisk" is nothing more than coded language for his far-right supporters. The policy, which was ended under Mayor Bloomberg in 2011, was widely criticized for disproportionately targeting minorities and failing to reduce crime. In fact, crime rates dropped significantly after its cancellation, thanks to improved policing strategies. Trump is attempting to scare the public with a dystopian vision of America that doesn’t reflect reality — and the officers he’s trying to win over aren’t fooled.

Did he break in? Be honest. Weiner is a total scumbag and will likely face serious consequences. About time.

Warning, Muslims, if you try to recite prayers loudly on a flight, there could be consequences! A couple named Omar and Layla boarded a United Airlines flight from London to New York. The plane was delayed on the tarmac for about an hour. During that time, several crew members observed the couple repeatedly chanting “Allahu Akbar” and appeared nervous. Their behavior made some staff uneasy, according to a report by The Guardian. One of the flight attendants, after consulting with the captain, asked the couple to leave the plane due to “safety concerns.” In a video shared online, Layla became upset, questioning whether it was “religious discrimination.” The captain responded that it was a “security issue.” According to a source, when the couple disembarked, a U.S. airport security officer was waiting and reviewed their documents. They were briefly questioned but allowed to proceed. A United Airlines representative later stated that the crew had concerns about their unusual behavior and felt it was necessary to remove them for the safety of everyone on board. The couple was rebooked on a different flight and received a refund as an apology. However, they took the incident as evidence of “anti-Muslim bias.” They immediately contacted the Muslim Advocates group, which criticized the airline for alleged discrimination against Muslim travelers. The group claims that such incidents are becoming more frequent, though United denies any bias. Meanwhile, some passengers support the crew’s decision, saying that in today’s climate, airlines must take every precaution. If someone acts suspiciously, they may be removed, no matter their religion. After all, safety should always come first. What do you think? Did the crew do the right thing? By Sarah Mitchell Like Sarah on Facebook Follow Sarah on Twitter

His talent for delivering blatant falsehoods with complete confidence has made him a unique and controversial figure on the campaign trail. While Williams pressed Clinton on her policy positions and the controversy surrounding her email server, he appeared to back down when confronting Trump. Many critics were outraged by the lack of accountability, particularly when Trump falsely claimed that he had always been against the Iraq War—a claim that is easily disproven and one that Williams likely knew was untrue.  

There was hope that the actual debates would be different. If Trump continues to spread misinformation during the events, moderators should be prepared to challenge his statements directly. Naturally, Trump has been the loudest voice criticizing this idea. In a recent appearance on Fox News, he suggested that there would be “people watching” to ensure he isn’t interrupted, and that he should be allowed to speak freely. He even criticized Candy Crawley, who famously corrected Mitt Romney during the 2012 debate, calling it an unfair tactic.  

Trump prefers a free-for-all format where he and Clinton can go at it without interruption, regardless of whether what he says is true. “I think there’s a lot of pressure on [first debate moderator Lester Holt],” he said. “He’s a good guy, but there’s a lot of pressure.” He also mentioned his recent town hall meeting with Clinton, where he faced tough questions but still came out looking strong. “They went after Matt Lauer, and I’ve never seen anything like it,” he added. “That’s what they’re doing with Lester Holt—and a lot of people are watching to see if he gives in.”  

The contrast between Trump's team and Clinton’s is clear. While Democrats are pushing for factual accuracy and accountability, Republicans—especially Trump—want moderators to stay out of the way. As reporter Greg Sergent from the Washington Post pointed out, one side wants truth, the other wants silence. Whether this is about fairness or strategy is debatable, but the fact remains that Trump lies far more often and more brazenly than Clinton. What do Tom Brady and Colin Kaepernick have in common? Neither is a starting quarterback in the NFL anymore. The other difference is that Tom Brady is a legendary leader and respected figure, while the other is seen as divisive. Brady remained quiet when asked about Kaepernick’s protest during the National Anthem and his criticism of a system that many believe mistreats people of color. Brady is known for his leadership on the field, his charitable work, and his long-standing reputation as a team player. His comments on Kaepernick were brief but pointed: “People have the right to express their views,” Brady said, “but it’s important to do it in a way that respects everyone.” The key word here is “respect.” Kaepernick, who makes millions as a backup quarterback, should consider where and how he chooses to speak out. He could protest on social media, at a Black Lives Matter event, or even outside a Walmart where workers are fighting for fair wages. But protesting during the national anthem, especially when you’re being paid to play football, comes off as disrespectful to fans and the country. Saying you’re oppressed is just an excuse for not taking responsibility. How did Martin Luther King Jr. achieve change? He worked for it, not by complaining. Name one person who’s truly oppressed, and I’ll show you why they could have done more. Oppression is a lie used by those who don’t want to put in the effort. If anyone is oppressed, it's people who lost opportunities because of reverse discrimination. Brady stayed quiet because he knows how to handle the spotlight. He’s focused on his future and helping others. Good for Brady, and I hope he finds a new role that fits his talents. Screw Kaepernick.

(CNN) Former President George H.W. Bush revealed Tuesday that he plans to support Hillary Clinton in the upcoming election, according to multiple sources familiar with the 41st president's remarks — a rare and unexpected statement from a member of his party's presidential candidate. The information surfaced during a brief exchange at a gathering hosted by the nonpartisan Points of Light Foundation, where Bush was speaking with Kathleen Hartington Kennedy Townsend, daughter of Robert F. Kennedy and former Maryland lieutenant governor. The conversation took place among about 30 attendees, and while not everyone in the room heard it, several confirmed the remark. 

This development marks a surprising shift in the long-standing political dynamic between the Bush and Clinton families, whose histories have been intertwined for decades. The timing is especially notable, as the first presidential debate between Clinton and Donald Trump is just 50 days away. 

Kellyanne Conway, Trump’s campaign manager, responded to the news by expressing respect for the 92-year-old former president but noted the irony of his choice. “It’s interesting that he would support the wife of the man who defeated him,” she said on CNN. “But we all know how tough this primary season was.”

The initial report came through social media when Kennedy Townsend shared a photo of herself with Bush, captioning it: “The President told me he's voting for Hillary!” She later removed the post, sparking some controversy over the disclosure of a private conversation. A spokesperson for Bush emphasized that the former president would not be commenting on the race until after the election. 

While Bush has not publicly addressed the issue, several members of his administration have expressed support for Clinton. Former national security advisor Brent Scowcroft endorsed her earlier this year, praising her leadership experience. Similarly, former Commerce Secretary Carlos Gutierrez called her a "great choice" and voiced concerns about Trump’s potential impact on the country.

However, not all members of the Bush family are in agreement. Marvin Bush, the former president's son, has indicated he will vote for Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson, while his grandson, George P. Bush, supports Trump. Jeb Bush, who previously ran against Trump in the primaries, has also declined to take a side.

The relationship between the Bush and Clinton families has evolved over time, beginning with Bill Clinton's 1992 victory over George H.W. Bush. Despite their political rivalry, both families have collaborated on various charitable efforts. Recently, Bill Clinton and George W.

Progressive Democrats are the "nanny state" of America. They try to shield people so intensely that they prevent real growth and self-reliance, which is contrary to the original vision of our Founding Fathers. One group particularly harmed by this overprotectiveness is African Americans. Don’t take my word for it—check out a powerful article by Thomas Sowell in National Review that explores this issue. In the 1960s, when a significant number of Black students first enrolled at a prestigious Ivy League school, a chemistry professor was asked off the record about his approach. He responded, “I give them A’s and B’s. Let them deal with it.” Many of these students had lower entrance standards, and he knew that accurate grading in a difficult class like chemistry could result in many failures—and that would lead to unnecessary conflict from both students and administrators. He wasn’t willing to waste time on what he saw as unproductive drama. He also believed that his leniency was ultimately hurting the students, as they wouldn’t truly grasp the material. Such attitudes were rarely spoken openly then, and they’re even more hidden today. However, many political leaders have benefited from policies that appear helpful but actually hinder long-term progress. Sowell points out how the expansion of the welfare state has led to increased dependency. In 1960, only 22 percent of Black children lived in single-parent households. By 1985, that number had risen to 67 percent. A recent example of this trend is the Obama administration's relaxed discipline policies for Black male students, which have resulted in lower rates of punishment compared to other student groups. Read the full piece here and share it with your progressive friends—it might just surprise them!

Scammer-turned-reality-TV-phenomenon-turned-Republican-presidential-candidate Donald Trump sat down with Fox News’ Tucker Carlson last night and launched into a tirade against the U.S. military, a common tactic for a candidate trying to appeal to patriotic conservatives while running for president. During the interview, Trump criticized President Barack Obama and took aim at the military, calling soldiers “the group that can’t hit the target.” In just 14 seconds, Trump used the word “win” or “winning” eight times, without offering any real strategy on how he would achieve these so-called victories.  

“Winning is what I do,” Trump told Carlson. “I’ve always won. I win in business, I win in sports, I win in everything. But our country isn’t winning. We don’t win in trade, we don’t win against ISIS, and we sure don’t win in the Middle East.” He continued, “Imagine if General Patton or General Eisenhower were alive today. They’d be spinning in their graves watching how we fight.”  

Trump also claimed the U.S. had mistakenly bombed Syrian government forces, saying, “We announce we’re sending people over at a certain time, everything’s political, and then we bomb the wrong people. You saw it over the weekend. We killed more than 80 of their troops.”  

At one point, Trump expressed concern that Russia might be upset with the U.S., even though they had been informed beforehand. “Now Russia is furious,” he said. “But we bomb the wrong people. We’re like the group that can’t hit the target.”  

The U.S. later apologized to Russia for the accidental bombing, but Russian officials—eager for a Trump presidency—spread a conspiracy theory blaming the Obama administration for aiding ISIS. Meanwhile, Trump offered no concrete plan to avoid such mistakes, instead repeating the word “win” over and over again. His supporters, of course, lap it up.  

And surprisingly, Sean Hannity has remained silent since Trump attacked the military. The rest of the media seems to be waiting for Hillary Clinton to make a misstep. Photo by Sara D. Davis via Getty.

Since the Clinton administration, Americans have been fed a narrative that suggests inherited wealth holds more value than money earned through hard work. While Republicans advocate for completely eliminating estate taxes on inherited wealth, Democrats generally oppose this stance. The current agreement is that only estates worth $5.45 million or more ($10.9 million for married couples) are subject to taxation. Anything below that threshold remains entirely tax-free. Now, Joe Biden, under pressure from progressive activists, has updated his approach to the estate tax, and let me tell you, Donald Trump’s children may not be pleased. Earlier, Biden had pledged to return the estate tax to its 2009 levels, increasing the rate from 40% to 45%, and lowering the threshold to $3.5 million. But now, he’s taken a page from his former rival and is proposing a progressive estate tax—meaning it will hit the wealthiest estates even harder—with a top rate of 65%. The last time the estate tax reached this level was in 1981, though back then it applied to smaller inheritances as well. In addition, Biden has indicated he would significantly limit the "step-up in basis" rule, which allows heirs to avoid capital gains taxes on assets passed down. In total, the plan is expected to generate roughly $200 billion over the next decade. Source: The New York Times Currently, the estate tax system is a farce. In 2015, a massive $1.4 trillion was transferred through inheritance. Of that, less than 1% was actually taxed. As for the Republican claim that estate taxes harm small businesses, in 2014, only 15 family-owned businesses and farm estates across the country faced estate taxes. Another common Republican argument is that estate taxes represent “double taxation,” but in reality, most large estates consist of untaxed capital gains. Even if Biden wins, passing this reform could be difficult, especially with Mitch McConnell controlling the Senate. He wants Trump’s children to pay nothing in estate taxes. And who knows, maybe Trump himself pays nothing at all.

Conservatives have consistently challenged her on this issue, and many believe she deserves the scrutiny. A young student once confronted her during an event, capturing the exchange on video. When he asked her about her ethnic background, she reportedly became visibly uncomfortable and quickly exited the scene, much like someone caught in a lie. The incident took place at Ohio State University, where Warren was supporting Democratic Senate candidate Ted Strickland in his campaign for Hillary Clinton. During the event, they urged voters to support Clinton at the state level and work toward a Democratic Senate majority. The student pressed her on her past losses to Donald Trump, but when she insisted they would win, he challenged her again, accusing her of lying about her ethnicity to gain advantages. You could see the tension in her reaction as she left the stage in a hurry. As the saying goes, conservatives don’t take kindly to lies, and liberals often react strongly to the truth. Trump faced criticism for referencing her Native American claim, calling her "Pocahontas" in a clear sarcastic tone. But as the old adage goes, what goes around comes around. The truth is hard to ignore, and Warren’s past deception continues to follow her wherever she goes.

The absence of a strong border barrier has led to an influx of illegal narcotics that are destroying communities across the U.S. These drugs have also brought immense wealth to foreign criminal organizations. One of the most notorious figures, El Chapo, was so rich he owned a private wildlife sanctuary. He reportedly imported exotic animals from different countries for his personal enjoyment. This was all funded by the drug trade. Foreign drug cartels are making billions, and their corruption is influencing governments worldwide. It's high time America takes action, and Trump has a unique plan. In a recent speech on immigration, Trump pledged that Mexico would fully fund his proposed border wall. Some suggest that the Mexican drug cartels could be the source of this funding. According to *LifeZette*, a top Trump campaign official hinted that a future Trump administration might use assets seized from drug gangs to pay for the wall. This strategy makes sense — using money from the illegal drug trade to combat illegal border crossings. While a wall isn't the only answer, it serves a critical purpose. The project is estimated to cost $8-10 billion, which could boost economic growth. More importantly, it would reduce the number of undocumented immigrants entering the country. The goal is to encourage people to use the legal immigration process. The plan reportedly includes a "joint border security fund," where assets seized from both sides would be used to build and maintain the wall, benefiting both nations. The Justice Department alone seized $8.7 billion in drug-related funds in 2015, and that’s just what's publicly known. The real amount is likely much higher, not to mention what Mexico has taken. The wall is a direct challenge to drug cartels, which threaten Mexico and have serious consequences for Americans. It addresses corruption, drug trafficking, human smuggling, illegal immigration, and even terrorism all at once. “For years, the illegal drug and weapons trade has devastated lives in both Mexico and the U.S.,” said an anonymous Trump immigration advisor. “It would be a form of justice to take their ill-gotten gains and use them for good.” Trump’s approach is different from Washington’s usual tactics. That kind of thinking is exactly what America needs. H/T Newsmax

Last night, the American public finally witnessed a rare moment — Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton sharing the same stage. And as expected, there was some intense back-and-forth. By the end of the debate, it was clear who came out on top: Hillary Clinton. No one should be shocked. While the media has been hyping up the idea of a "Trump turnaround," the truth is still the same — what we saw was the same old Trump: loud, unprepared, and full of empty rhetoric. The experts know it. The polls know it. The public knows it. Clinton won because she was ready, composed, and articulate. But of course, Trump and his team didn't get the message. They still think they won. Why not? Trump and his allies are blaming Lester Holt for being biased, claiming the microphone was rigged, and saying Clinton was "over-prepared" to gain an unfair edge. They’re making excuses again. He was unprepared, disrespectful, and couldn’t even answer basic questions without lying. But let’s focus on why Clinton clearly dominated. Her best line of the night was: “I think Donald just criticized me for preparing for this debate. And yes, I did. And you know what else I prepared for? I prepared to be president.” It's been reported that Clinton spent months studying the issues, doing extensive research, and practicing relentlessly. Trump, however, took a laid-back approach, and it showed. He couldn’t explain his positions, lacked civility, and had no response for Clinton’s facts — only more lies. The bar was low, and Clinton rose above it. She faced a loud, unpredictable, and aggressive opponent, but she stayed calm, challenged him when necessary, and kept her composure. She wasn’t “too loud” as some claimed, but she was firm when needed. And, despite the nonsense, she smiled. One of the main reasons people dislike debates is because moderators often fail to control the conversation. They let candidates dominate, go over time, and interrupt each other endlessly. But this time, Trump was in stark contrast to Clinton. She respected Holt’s time limits and rarely interrupted him to attack Trump. Meanwhile, Trump interrupted Clinton 51 times, while she only interrupted him 17 times. At the end, Clinton shook Holt’s hand, and Trump did not. While Trump’s “Crooked Hillary” meme was trending on social media, the facts tell a different story.

Update: According to a recent report, our account of the incident and the individuals involved has been called into question. We have thoroughly refuted the claims made by the source. You can read our updated piece here. ~~~ It's hard to believe, but people used to spread wild tales without any evidence. Now, with video everywhere, it's easier than ever to verify or expose the truth. This is one of the most shocking events I've come across. Two men were in the middle of a street, and it looked like a confrontation was about to happen. After all, fights are more intense when they're in the middle of a busy road. Suddenly, someone throws a flaming object at them. FLAMES. THEM. ON. FIRE. They're running around in panic, dangerously close to oncoming traffic. Pure madness and one of the worst things I've seen since the Amanda Knox case. What kind of person would think, "This is the perfect moment to set them on fire"? Yeah, let's just throw that Molotov their way and watch them burn. Who even carries the materials for a Molotov cocktail? Was this planned? I don't keep those items lying around unless it's for a fancy drink on a Saturday night. Back in the old days, when people were more responsible and society was better, things were handled differently. If two people were about to fight in the street, decent people would step in to protect them from traffic and ensure the fight stayed fair. That was when people had more respect and empathy. Now, everyone pulls out their phone and turns a minor issue into a viral disaster just for views. No one cares anymore. It's time to care about others and stop setting people on fire.

Washington, D.C. (BBC) The Pentagon is exploring a plan that could deploy an extra 400 soldiers to Syria to support Kurdish and local forces in their effort to push ISIS out of Raqqa in the near future, a US military source told the BBC. Reports about potential troop increases have been circulating for weeks, with some outlets covering the possibility. The New York Times was the first to highlight the proposed addition of up to 400 additional personnel. No official decision has been announced, the source said. If approved, this would likely mark the last major troop increase for the operation against ISIS, as Raqqa is considered the final significant ISIS stronghold in Syria, the source added. The move would raise the current limit of US troops in Syria from 3,800 to just over 4,200. A number of additional soldiers are already rotating in and out of the region on temporary assignments. Currently, around 3,650 troops are deployed under the existing cap. The military is not disclosing exactly what roles the new forces would take on. Some are expected to serve as tactical advisors and trainers for Syrian partners, while others may assist with supply lines and movement of equipment across the front lines, the source explained. Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican from South Carolina and a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, expressed concern over the development. "We’re hearing about another small boost of 400 troops in Syria, another step toward deeper involvement," he stated Thursday.

Jason Falconer, an NRA-certified firearms instructor and former police officer, who stopped an ISIS-linked attacker from killing multiple people at a St. Cloud, Minnesota mall, is someone that Hillary Clinton is determined to shut down. If elected president, she plans to take aggressive action against him and his business, which she sees as a threat to her agenda. Falconer, who saved lives by confronting a violent jihadist, runs Tactical Advantage Firearms Training, Inc., a company that teaches responsible gun ownership and self-defense. This is exactly the kind of organization that Clinton opposes—especially one that promotes Second Amendment rights and trains law-abiding citizens to protect themselves. Clinton has long criticized the 2005 Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act (PLCAA), which shields businesses like Falconer’s from baseless lawsuits. She wants to eliminate this protection, making it easier to target gun training facilities through legal attacks. Falconer, a dedicated defender of public safety, has spent years educating others on how to use firearms responsibly. His actions in St. Cloud have made him a hero to many, but to Clinton, he’s a dangerous symbol of the very freedoms she seeks to undermine. If she gets into office, she’ll do everything she can to silence men like him. Don’t vote for Hillary Clinton—she doesn’t just want to control guns; she wants to control the people who protect us.

They argue that pro-life advocates shouldn’t impose their beliefs on others through laws that force women to carry pregnancies against their will. After all, the issue only directly affects the woman and the unborn child, who, of course, has no voice in the matter. (Though the child is not technically part of the woman’s body.) You could apply the same reasoning to slavery. It only affected the slave owner and the enslaved person, but at the time, slaves weren’t seen as full human beings—similar to how some view unborn children today. So, if you opposed slavery, that’s fine, but don’t force your views on others. In fact, one activist and leader of an abortion advocacy group has drawn a parallel between abortion and slavery. She argues that denying federal support for abortion is like enforcing slavery, while allowing it is about “liberating women.” According to CNS News, Kierra Johnson, executive director of URGE: Unite for Reproductive and Gender Equity, recently spoke before the House Judiciary Committee discussing the Hyde Amendment, which restricts federal funding for abortion except in cases of rape or incest. She compared the amendment to slavery, stating that repealing it would be a step toward “freedom” for women. When asked about the effect of the Hyde Amendment on low-income women, Johnson referenced a previous comment from Rep. Trent Franks (R-Ariz.), who likened the Supreme Court's Dred Scott decision to abortion, saying, “When you control someone’s decision-making, you control them.” “The Hyde Amendment is about expanding access to reproductive care,” she said. “It’s about giving women control over their bodies. It’s about freedom.” “When you decide whether a person’s body has worth, you’re essentially owning them—whether you label them as black or not. Newly uncovered video has added disturbing details to a 2011 police shooting in St. Louis, revealing an officer fatally shooting a black man and then placing a weapon at the scene. Officer Jason Stockley and his partner Brian Bianchi were pursuing drug suspect Anthony Lamar Smith during a high-speed chase. In the footage, Stockley is heard saying, “I’m going to kill this guy.” The police forced Smith’s vehicle off the road, and the video shows Stockley firing five shots into the driver’s seat of the stopped car. Additional footage now shows Stockley retrieving a gun from a bag in the back of his patrol car and placing it on Smith’s body. Stockley claimed in his report that Smith had aimed the gun at him, justifying the lethal force. However, DNA testing on the weapon found no evidence linking it to Smith. Stockley is now facing charges of first-degree murder, with his first court hearing scheduled for October 3rd. The video of the incident is available here:

In a highly charged interview on Fox News, Trump was confronted about labeling Hillary Clinton as a "racist." When pressed for specific reasoning, he struggled to articulate his claims and attempted to shift the conversation, which only made him appear more defensive. Here's part of the exchange:  
Anderson Cooper: You've called Hillary Clinton a racist. What makes her a racist?  
Trump: Well, she's a racist.  
Anderson Cooper: But what specifically makes her racist? Racism involves prejudice against a particular race.  
Trump: She doesn't support the communities she's supposed to help.  
Anderson Cooper: (Again) So you're saying she has prejudice or hatred toward African Americans?  
Trump: Her policies are racist.  
Anderson Cooper: But you said her policies are "personally racist."  
Trump: Oh, she is. Of course she is. There's no question about that.  
Anderson Cooper: But that suggests she has animosity, hatred toward, I guess in this case, African Americans. I don't want to assume, but is that at the core of it?  
Trump: Maybe she's just lazy.

A top Trump ally in Silicon Valley is now facing a major federal investigation over alleged racial bias in its hiring practices. The U.S. Department of Labor has filed a lawsuit against Palantir Technologies, the data firm backed by Republican investor Peter Thiel, accusing the company of systematically excluding Asian applicants during its recruitment process. Palantir, which works with the U.S. intelligence community, is under scrutiny after a review of its engineering intern hiring showed a stark disparity. According to the lawsuit, 73% of applicants were Asian, yet only four Asians were hired compared to 17 non-Asians. The report states that the odds of such a result happening by chance are less than one in a billion.  

Thiel, a Stanford graduate and early Facebook investor, has long been a quiet but influential figure in tech circles. He gained more public attention this year when he was revealed as the secret financial backer of Hulk Hogan’s defamation lawsuit against Gawker, which ultimately led to the site’s collapse. Thiel also made headlines at the Republican National Convention when he became the first openly gay speaker to address the convention, declaring his pride in both his sexuality and his political affiliation. However, his party’s recent platform, which includes some of the most anti-LGBT policies in its history, has raised questions about the alignment between Thiel’s personal views and the GOP's stance.  

The Department of Labor emphasized that federal contractors must uphold fair hiring practices. “Taxpayers deserve to know that companies working with public funds are offering equal opportunities,” said OFCCP Director Patricia Shiu. Palantir has denied the allegations, stating it will "vigorously" defend itself in court. Meanwhile, the company’s leadership, which once criticized government inefficiency, now faces the challenge of proving its hiring practices are above reproach.

I witnessed both incidents involving black men being shot recently and I want to share my take on each. The shooting in Tulsa, where I'm from, is being labeled as a white cop killing an innocent black man. That's not exactly accurate. Terence Crutcher had a long criminal record, with at least 12 prior arrests. Officers found PCP in his stalled car. What the media is saying is that he was just standing by his vehicle when the bad cops showed up and shot him with his hands in the air. He was indeed unarmed, but according to the video, he kept walking with his arms raised after being told multiple times to stop. He finally reached his car and started to reach inside. That’s when a white female officer shot him. His lawyer claims the window was closed when she arrived, but it seems clear he was trying to get something from the car. Two officers fired at the same time—one with a taser and one with a gun. It was a justified use of force—he wasn’t shot while his hands were up. From what I saw, the officer followed protocol. Should she have waited to see if he pulled a weapon and shot first? No, that’s not how they’re trained. He wasn’t obeying orders and looked high. Hundreds turned out in Tulsa last night for protests—again, Black Lives Matter. At first, people said he was a preacher, which isn’t true. He was a criminal, and the officers acted in self-defense. Now, moving on to North Carolina, where another black man was shot and killed—this time by a black officer.

Anyone who has battled with a dependency knows how hard it is to break free. Whether it's alcohol, cigarettes, opioids, or something else, achieving even 24 hours of sobriety can feel like a major victory. A man, once addicted to meth, shared on Reddit what happened when he finally decided to take control of his life and escape the grip of his addiction. The transformation is undeniable. Addiction isn't just a physical struggle—it affects your mind, emotions, and spirit. Staying sober is difficult for that reason, but it’s essential for the health of the person and those around them.  

The man in question fell into meth addiction after a series of personal setbacks, including the loss of his job and a broken relationship. After years of relapse and failed attempts at recovery, he finally made the decision to get help. He was sentenced to 14 days in jail for violating his probation before entering a rehabilitation program. As seen in his arrest photo, he was clearly suffering from both the physical and emotional toll of his addiction.  

When he finally committed to recovery, everything changed. His "after" picture shows him 615 days clean and still going strong. In his Reddit post, he wrote: “There are people out there who are still stuck in the same place I was. If even one of them sees this and decides to change, then it’s all worth it.” If you or someone you care about is dealing with addiction, remember that reaching out for help is not an invasion of privacy. It may be hard to hear at first, but in time, they’ll understand that you were trying to help. No one should have to suffer from addiction any longer than necessary.

On Tuesday, Congressman Matt Gaetz (R-FL) took to Twitter to reference the arrest of the main suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing investigation, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, as a way to subtly criticize NFL quarterback Tom Brady, in what many saw as a poorly timed and tone-deaf attempt to link his recent kneeling protests with domestic terrorism. Gaetz tweeted, “You’re welcome,” following news that Tsarnaev had been apprehended, clearly aiming to imply that Brady should be grateful for law enforcement’s actions. However, the online reaction was swift and harsh, with the tweet quickly being labeled as “Thanks, Brady” — a nod to the infamous “Thanks, Obama” meme used by liberals to mock conservative attempts to tie unrelated events to presidential policies. Just like “Thanks, Obama,” the phrase “You’re welcome, Brady” now serves as a punchline for how far some on the right will go to twist public sentiment against athletes speaking out on social issues. The tweet gained traction on multiple verified accounts, including reaching prominent media figures like Anderson Cooper. In the end, it’s clear this was not the political maneuver Gaetz had envisioned, and many are hoping he takes the lesson to heart — and stops using national tragedies to boost his own image.

His family fueled the unrest, as did a Muslim spokesperson who supported them. They should be held accountable.  

From The Federalist Papers Project: Robert Gehl reported that during the second night of riots in Charlotte, demonstrators attempted to throw a journalist into a fire they had lit in the middle of the street. Legendary athlete LeBron James released a public statement addressing the ongoing issues of racial injustice and police relations. James said, “As an American father and someone who has seen the pain of violence firsthand, I am deeply concerned about the tragic deaths of African-Americans at the hands of law enforcement. At the same time, I’m also upset by the attacks on officers who risk their lives every day to keep our communities safe. I stand with the families who have lost loved ones, because I understand that pain all too well.” He continued, “My parents always taught me to treat everyone with respect, no matter where they come from. That’s why I’m troubled by the growing division and hostility in our country. I believe we can do better, and I can’t stay quiet any longer. We need to create real change that ensures people of color are treated fairly and that police officers—those who protect us daily—are respected and supported.” James also highlighted his appreciation for law enforcement, sharing personal stories of how officers have helped him and his family over the years. However, he acknowledged that many African Americans have had negative experiences with police and don’t feel the same sense of safety. His most powerful message was a call for unity and collaboration to bring about real reform. In a bold move, James announced he would be donating $1 million each to two organizations: the National Police Foundation and the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. While he admitted that money alone won’t fix everything, he hoped it would help these groups make meaningful progress. Social media quickly responded with backlash, with some calling him a sellout and questioning the impact of his donation. But what he said was incredibly significant. Not only did he recognize the systemic issues facing Black communities, but he also validated the challenges faced by law enforcement. He managed to speak from both perspectives, showing true understanding. And he backed his words with action, giving a substantial amount of his own resources. A rare example of someone who not only speaks but acts. Too often, people talk without taking real steps. He did just that. Unlike others who remain silent or take sides without offering support. He is able to bridge the gap, and as an African American leader, his voice carries more weight. It’s the voices of our own that tend to resonate most. Whether we admit it or not, many Black people are more likely to listen to someone who looks like them. That’s why his message matters so much.

When Republicans chose a candidate who pledged to stop catering to the wealthy for political favors, few anticipated that their presidential nominee would hand over control of America’s most powerful offices directly to the same elite class. Reports suggest that Donald Trump is considering naming energy magnate Rebecca Hart as Secretary of the Interior, a move that breaks from the tradition of appointing officials from the rural Western states to oversee the management of public lands, national parks, and wildlife. This could be disastrous for environmental protections, the enforcement of the Endangered Species Act, and animal welfare, as Rebecca Hart has a long history of opposing animal rights legislation and supporting industries that exploit animals for entertainment. According to a recent article in The Hill, Hart, who owns a large ranch and sits on Trump’s agricultural advisory board, has donated heavily to organizations that oppose the Humane Society and PETA, while promoting hunting, factory farming, and rodeo events. A source familiar with the transition team confirmed that Hart was among a small group of candidates under consideration for the role, which has drawn attention from influential anti-environmental figures. In a clear sign of the cronyism Trump plans to institutionalize, it was also reported that his daughter Ivanka is being seriously considered for a top position in the administration. The Department of the Interior controls 28% of the nation's land, oversees national parks and forests, manages the federal Fish & Wildlife Service, and plays a key role in regulating tribal gaming operations. It also holds significant influence over mineral leasing and drilling on public lands, making it a critical player for the energy sector. The Natural Resources Defense Council issued a dire warning about the implications of Trump’s potential appointment: “Putting an energy mogul in charge of our public lands and coastal areas is a direct threat to the environment and a promise that Trump will open up every protected area to oil drilling if he wins.” Hart is known for her fierce opposition to animal protection laws, having actively worked against a Missouri ballot initiative in 2012 that aimed to end cruel puppy mill practices. It’s alarming to see how Trump is offering high-level government positions in ways that seem almost absurd. If the only options are a corporate oil executive who will exploit the country’s natural resources without restraint and supports animal cruelty as part of his platform or a privileged, far-right figure who takes joy in hunting endangered species with high-powered rifles, one might wonder if this is all scripted. But Trump is not joking — and the danger he represents is very real

New Jersey’s controversial Republican Governor Chris Christie is facing intense scrutiny as top state lawmakers are considering initiating impeachment proceedings if he is found responsible for orchestrating the closure of the George Washington Bridge to retaliate against a political opponent. A court has ordered Christie to release personal emails connected to the "Bridgegate" scandal, according to WNYC. The decision to move forward with impeachment rests with Democratic Assembly Speaker Vincent Prieto, and if approved, the Judiciary Committee would begin the formal process. A simple majority of the 80-member Assembly would be required to approve articles of impeachment. If passed, the case would then go to the Senate, where a two-thirds vote would be needed for conviction. While Democrats hold the majority in the Senate, they would need support from at least three Republicans to secure a conviction. Christie also serves as a key advisor on Donald Trump’s presidential transition team. Just days ago, federal prosecutors accused Christie of being deeply involved in the scheme that led to the bridge closure, which caused severe traffic chaos and delayed emergency services, resulting in one death. Christie had been seen as a major conservative voice and the first high-profile Republican to back Trump, a move that many believed signaled the end of his political future, as his career now seemed tied to Trump's success. From entertaining presidential ambitions to endorsing Trump in a widely criticized event last March, it was seen as a major fall from grace. Christie once famously lied for over two hours during a televised press conference, which you can watch below, starting at 1:43. In it, he flatly denied any knowledge of BridgeGate, just two months after re-election and four months after the incident that caused massive gridlock and emergency delays. It was later revealed that Christie had been personally informed about the bridge closure during the 9/11 memorial ceremony in 2013 by his aides, yet he remained silent. His aides later confronted him in emails, accusing him of lying to the public. Once viewed as a rising star in the Republican Party, Christie now faces potential removal from office due to his alleged role in a politically motivated act of retaliation. We will continue to monitor this story and see how Donald Trump responds to the impeachment charges against the New Jersey Governor, who remains a central figure in the Republican presidential campaign.
