There have been growing concerns from *The New York Times* that Megyn Kelly, the moderator of the recent presidential debate between Joe Biden and Donald Trump, will not be challenging the candidates on their factual claims. This means that Trump could make false statements without immediate correction — leaving it up to Biden to counter them on the spot. However, the situation is even more troubling, as all major news networks (including those typically critical of Trump) have agreed to avoid any real-time fact checks during the debate. While on-screen fact checks could help clarify misleading statements without disrupting the flow, most major networks, including CNN and MSNBC, have confirmed they will not display any such graphics or corrections. As a result, the responsibility of holding the candidates accountable may fall entirely on Kelly, the only other person on stage. With reports showing that Trump has been caught in falsehoods roughly every four minutes, one would expect a strong fact-checking presence to ensure a fair debate. Instead, the media, prioritizing ratings over truth, appears willing to let Trump dominate without pushback. The Biden campaign has strongly criticized this approach, with Senior Advisor Jen O’Malley Dillon stating: “If the moderator allows lies to go unchallenged, it gives Trump an unfair edge. It’s the moderator’s job to call out dishonesty in real time.” Unfortunately, with no independent oversight, it now falls on Biden to “shine” during the debate if he hopes to gain any advantage. This double standard — where the most experienced candidate must work twice as hard to seem slightly more credible than the least qualified — is deeply troubling. Hopefully, Biden can hold his ground, but without support from the moderators or the press, it may be difficult to convince the public that he truly prevailed. If there’s one lesson from this election, it’s that journalistic integrity is fading fast, if not already gone.

In 2008, President Barack Obama ran a tightly contested election against a charismatic but somewhat inexperienced Republican challenger, John McCain. For all his flaws, McCain was more respected and less controversial than today’s GOP candidate. Obama managed to secure his victory largely due to his strong appeal to younger voters and his message of hope and change. In fact, the 2008 campaign brought the term “youth vote” into the national spotlight, as a generation that had grown up in the shadow of the Iraq War began to take political action for the first time. These young voters, eager to see a new direction, felt it was their duty to protect the future by choosing someone who promised progress. Fast forward 12 years to the 2020 presidential election, and this same group of young voters is once again set to play a crucial role in shaping the outcome. The 2020 version of these politically engaged voters seems poised to support Democratic candidate Joe Biden, and the events of last week explain why. On Wednesday, a suspicious device was found near a public event in downtown Chicago, prompting a citywide alert. Later that day, another device was discovered in a nearby subway station. By Thursday, authorities had confirmed at least three more devices in different parts of the city, leading to widespread evacuations and heightened security. As the situation unfolded, left-leaning media and politicians were quick to criticize President Trump for his early remarks about the incidents, calling his statements “alarmist” and “unwarranted.” They argued that there was no proof of a connection to extremist groups or any specific ideology. Meanwhile, on Friday, law enforcement arrested a suspect with ties to far-right extremism, a man who had been under surveillance for months. By Saturday, the suspect had confessed to planting the devices, citing ideological motivations. On Thursday, I reported that among those arrested in Minneapolis, Minnesota, 65% of the agitators and looters were from other states. However, a journalist is now raising questions about why these individuals aren't being charged with federal offenses for crossing state lines to incite violence. John Mercer writes at The Conservative Voice that the Department of Justice appears to have a “selective enforcement” approach, suggesting that “non-enforcement of the law has become routine over the past several years.” Mercer argues that the presence of out-of-state rioters should be a red flag for the DOJ, but instead, the department seems indifferent. He claims that the Justice Department has become so politicized that it no longer upholds the rule of law. He notes: “Criminals posing as demonstrators cross state lines to spread chaos and destruction. Has anyone noticed that the law against interstate rioting is being ignored by federal officials?” According to the U.S. Code, 18 U.S.C. § 2101 states that anyone who travels across state lines or uses interstate communication with the intent to incite, organize, or participate in a riot can face fines or imprisonment. This law was designed to prevent local conflicts from escalating into nationwide unrest when outsiders are involved. Yet, it's clearly not being enforced. Mercer points to incidents like the 2020 protests in Portland, where out-of-state groups were seen actively participating in violence, yet no federal action was taken. He adds, “Whoever incites, supports, or participates in rebellion against the United States or its laws deserves severe punishment. But instead, we see selective justice.” This isn’t the first time Mercer has criticized the DOJ’s handling of such cases. In 2017, he wrote about similar issues during the Baltimore riots, where out-of-state activists were present but not prosecuted. He concluded, “The administration shows favor, while the DOJ shows apathy.” This pattern of selective enforcement is troubling. It not only undermines public trust but also allows lawbreakers to go unpunished while innocent citizens are targeted. Perhaps it’s time for the public to demand accountability from their leaders and push for real reform. Reprinted with permission from The Conservative Voice. However, his main criticisms of Clinton were policy-based, aiming to channel widespread dissatisfaction not just with her, but with the political establishment as a whole. “You’ve been in politics for 30 years — why are these solutions coming now?” Trump asked during a discussion on job creation. “I've thought about this a lot,” Clinton replied. “Yeah, for 30 years,” Trump shot back. Trump stretched the truth and questioned Clinton’s emotional stability, though he largely maintained his composure.  

Throughout the debate, Clinton addressed Trump by his first name, while he consistently called her “Secretary Clinton” and made it clear he was fine with that. “I want you to be very comfortable. It's really important to me,” Trump said, once again challenging fact-checkers. Trump faced his most vulnerable moment when moderator Lester Holt brought up the issue of President Obama’s birthplace — specifically why Trump waited until just weeks before to declare the matter resolved. Trump flatly stated, “I have nothing to say” about why he pushed the topic for so long. He also falsely claimed Clinton started the birther controversy in 2007, saying he had put the issue to rest. “Just like she can't bring back jobs, she can't produce Obama’s birth certificate,” Trump said. Clinton capitalized on an issue that resonated with Black voters and other members of the Obama coalition. “It can't be dismissed so easily. He built his political career on this racist lie that our first Black president wasn't a citizen,” she said. “The birther claim was deeply hurtful.” Concerned that Trump might behave more politely, Clinton launched her attacks early, suggesting that his success came from privilege and that he was hiding his tax returns to avoid scrutiny. “

One doesn't need to wear the flag on their sleeve to be a citizen of this nation. But when I hear criticisms of American values disguised as "progressive" ideology, I can't help but ask, "If you despise what this country represents, why do you choose to live here?" That’s the question that should be directed at those who have pressured a university to alter a cultural celebration due to its "offensive" patriotic elements.  

Students at SUNY Fredonia in New York were organizing a themed fall festival for campus members, with a focus on “American traditions.” As they began planning, they were told by campus staff that the event needed to be rebranded because the patriotic theme was “too provocative.” The official responsible for the decision, Residence Life Coordinator Michael Torres, stated that the use of the phrase “Give Me Liberty or Give Me Death” on promotional materials was considered “too militaristic and divisive.” Was a history lesson somehow equated with a recruitment pitch? Torres claimed the directive came from higher-ups, but when pressed, he said, “I’m not entirely sure who made the call. I just followed what I was told.” Other events had used similar phrases without issue, which left many confused.  

The festival proceeded with a more neutral theme, drawing around 250 attendees. University administrators avoided direct answers and called the situation a “misunderstanding.” Still, student organizers are determined to uncover the real reason behind the change. What’s most concerning isn’t just the growing anti-patriotic sentiment in some academic circles, but the blind obedience to bureaucratic rules that allow such decisions to go unchallenged. When authority figures say, “Because we said so,” it sets a dangerous precedent.

(FOX News) Former President George H.W. Bush revealed Tuesday that he plans to support Hillary Clinton in the upcoming November election, according to several individuals familiar with the 41st President's remarks — a rare and unexpected shift from his party's standard line. The statement was reportedly made during a brief exchange at a gathering hosted by the nonpartisan Points of Light Foundation, where Bush was speaking with Kathleen Hartington Kennedy Townsend, daughter of Robert F. Kennedy and former Maryland lieutenant governor. The event included about 35 attendees, and multiple sources confirmed hearing the comment. 

This development marks a significant turn in the long-standing political dynamic between the Bush and Clinton families, who have had a complex history since Bill Clinton defeated George H.W. Bush in 1992. The timing of the announcement — just 48 days before the election and just days before the first presidential debate between Clinton and Trump — has sparked considerable attention.

Trump campaign spokesperson Jason Miller stated on Fox News that the president’s decision is “respectful,” adding, “It’s ironic that he would support the wife of the man who beat him in 1992.” Miller also noted that the primary race was “tough” and that “feelings run deep.”

The news initially spread through social media when Kennedy Townsend posted a photo of herself with Bush, captioning it: “President Bush said he’s voting for Hillary!” She later removed the post, but not before it gained traction online. A Bush family representative declined to confirm or deny the claim, stating, “The president will cast his vote as a private citizen, and he is not commenting on the race in the interim.”

Sources close to the conversation expressed surprise that the discussion was shared publicly, though Kennedy Townsend has not yet responded to requests for comment. Meanwhile, other members of the Bush family have taken different stances. George H.W. Bush’s son, Marvin, has indicated he will support Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson, while his grandson, George P. Bush, has backed Trump. Jeb Bush, who ran against Trump in the primaries, has said he will not vote for either major candidate.

Despite the family divisions, several former Bush administration officials have expressed support for Clinton, including national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and Commerce Secretary Carlos Gutierrez. Meanwhile, George W. Bush has remained silent on the matter, focusing instead on efforts to retain Republican control of the Senate.

Comedian and actor Zach Galifianakis recently had former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on his quirky, improvisational talk show, *Between Two Ferns*. Known for his unconventional style, Galifianakis has previously sat down with President Obama, Brad Pitt, and even Justin Bieber. However, there's one high-profile figure he has consistently refused to invite onto the show. When asked by the *Los Angeles Times* if he’d consider bringing Republican nominee Donald Trump on after his successful interview with Clinton, Galifianakis gave a surprisingly funny and revealing response. “No way. It doesn’t interest me. Doing it the other way around? Not my thing. He’s the type of person who craves attention—any kind of attention. You’re talking about someone with some serious issues. I wouldn’t want to take advantage of someone like that. And you can print that.” *Between Two Ferns* is famous for its awkward humor and bold questions (like when Galifianakis asked Obama, “How does it feel to be the last black president?”). The show thrives on the tension between the host and guest as they try not to react. Considering how Trump often explodes at the slightest criticism and can’t resist responding to even the smallest provocation, it’s clear Galifianakis made the right call. Yet, it’s alarming that a man who couldn’t handle a bit of comedic scrutiny could actually be considered for the presidency; his emotional instability raises serious concerns about his ability to lead.

Tonight's presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump is shaping up to be a major event, with many high-profile figures tuning in from both the comfort of their homes and the front row. Billionaire investor and "Shark Tank" star Mark Cuban has confirmed he'll be sitting in the front row at Hofstra University on Long Island, New York, to support Hillary Clinton. "Just got a front-row seat to watch @HillaryClinton dominate @realDonaldTrump at the 'Humbling at Hofstra' on Monday. It’s happening!" Cuban shared on social media.  

"I'm not a Trump supporter," Cuban told ABC News during the "Shark Tank" premiere. "I think Hillary would be an excellent president. I just don’t believe Trump has the qualifications." He added, "If he were on 'Shark Tank,' I wouldn’t invest in him. He doesn’t seem capable at all."  

Trump quickly fired back, tweeting that he was considering inviting Gennifer Flowers, the performer who had a well-known relationship with Bill Clinton before he became president. "If dumb Mark Cuban wants to sit in the front row, maybe I’ll have Gennifer Flowers right next to him!"  

Although Trump's team denied the invitation, it was reported that Flowers was open to attending. "Hi Donald. You know I’m in your corner and will definitely be at the debate!...??" she replied.  

Meanwhile, other celebrities are preparing to watch the first showdown between the two candidates. Here's what they're saying online:  

"Ready for #mudslingmonday #YOUGOTTHISHRC"  

"May angels protect everyone at the debate tonight. Sending love, strength, and hope."  

"My goal is to avoid tweeting during the debate. As the kids say, #lifegoals."  

"I think something huge is going to happen tomorrow. Just feel it."  

"1. Will you be watching the debate tomorrow? 2. Will you be open-minded or already decided? 3. What snack will you have?"  

"Why schedule a debate on a Monday night when football is on? Makes sense to someone, I guess."  

"For the debates, I'm thinking of serving kebabs. With Cheetos and Skittles, of course."  

"To make things fair, Hillary will be given sedation, and all questions will be asked in French."  

Can't wait to see the Trump-Clinton debate this Monday. I

It's not surprising that someone would conflate the records of two completely different men from different cities. What's more troubling is that no one corrected the error. My point was clear. Hillary Clinton has suddenly canceled a major fundraising event, leaving donors and reporters scratching their heads! The planned "lunch with Hillary Rodham Clinton" was set to take place at the home of Richard and Susan Baker and featured donation tiers ranging from $2,700 to $100,000. No official explanation was provided for the abrupt cancellation, which comes as her campaign continues to face mounting pressure. Some are questioning whether her ongoing health concerns are behind the move, especially as the campaign recently spent over $45 million in an effort to counter Donald Trump's momentum.  

According to WNCN, while Clinton's event in Durham was called off, Trump is set to hold a rally in Goldsboro on Tuesday, just days after a stop in New Bern. The event will be held at the Wayne County Fairgrounds, expected to draw thousands of supporters. Local schools have already announced early dismissals in anticipation of heavy traffic.  

The Clinton fundraiser, originally promoted as an exclusive opportunity to meet the former Secretary of State, had four tiers: $100,000 for a “private reception,” $33,000 for a “hosting experience,” $5,000 for “preferred seating,” and $2,700 for general attendance. Though Clinton won’t be present, Trump is making headlines with his upcoming appearances.  

Trump took to social media to mock the cancellation, saying: “Hillary is taking another day off. She needs the rest. Sleep well, Hillary – see you at the debate!” — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 20, 2016  

Reporters are now watching closely to see if other events in Florida will also be canceled without warning. What’s really going on? Share your thoughts below.

President Barack Obama delivered what was meant to be his last speech to the U.N. General Assembly, and it sparked controversy with its pessimistic take on the limits of military force in combating Islamist extremism across the Middle East. The speech suggested that even the strongest military power in the world, the United States, may not be able to achieve lasting success in these conflicts. According to a report from Breitbart, Obama questioned the effectiveness of military solutions, particularly in regions like Syria, where he claimed there is "no ultimate military victory to be won." He emphasized the need for diplomacy and cooperation, stating, “We must be honest about the nature of these conflicts and continue working with those who want to build peace rather than fuel destruction.” While acknowledging that military action may play a role, Obama stressed the importance of addressing the root causes of violence and fostering mutual respect among different communities. His remarks have raised concerns among critics who argue that such an approach fails to recognize the clear connection between radical Islam and violence. Some question how effective this strategy will be under leaders who often downplay the threat of extremist groups and prioritize political correctness over national security. As the election season approaches, many are left wondering whether this kind of rhetoric will lead to real change or further weaken America’s global standing. Share your thoughts on Obama's U.N. address and his views on military strength. What do you think about his approach to fighting extremism? Leave a comment below!

Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump is reportedly trying to squeeze as much public funding as possible from the government ahead of the election, with his campaign now accused of bilking the U.S. Secret Service out of $1.6 million for his protection. According to FEC reports, Trump’s team has been using a loophole in the agency's reimbursement policy by having Secret Service agents travel on private jets operated by Trump-owned TAG Air, Inc. While the standard practice is for campaigns to cover the cost of agent travel and then be reimbursed, Trump’s team is allegedly pocketing the difference by charging the government for flights that are ultimately paid for by taxpayers. In contrast, Hillary Clinton’s campaign has used Executive Fliteways for travel, a company with no ties to her or her team, ensuring no conflict of interest. Critics argue that if Clinton were using a similar arrangement, it would spark immediate outrage, but Trump’s supporters have shown little concern over his financial dealings. A Trump spokesperson, Kayleigh McEnany, stated that the campaign followed all FEC rules and urged questions to be directed to the Secret Service. Additionally, there are claims that the Secret Service may be covering hotel costs when agents stay at Trump’s properties, where he reportedly prefers budget-friendly accommodations, including cheap Chinese-made beds.

In an exclusive interview with a Cleveland, Ohio television outlet, Donald Trump unintentionally revealed that his earlier 20-second statement affirming Barack Obama’s U.S. birthplace was merely a strategic move. Speaking to WOIO, Trump appeared to rekindle the birther controversy in a subtle, backhanded way. When asked by reporter Sarah Mitchell, “You previously stated that you now believe President Obama was born in the United States, after years of questioning it—what changed your mind?” Trump responded that he simply wanted to avoid further discussion on the topic. “I just wanted to focus on the campaign,” he said. “There were a lot of questions coming at me. People want to talk about jobs, the economy, the military, and stopping terrorism. We need to move past these issues and talk about what really matters.”  

Indeed, this slip suggested that Trump’s stance on Obama’s birthplace had never truly shifted, despite his public reassurances. For years, he had relentlessly pushed for Obama’s birth certificate, college records, and other documents, all in an effort to cast doubt on the President’s legitimacy. Now, it seems, he’s just tired of the scrutiny. Meanwhile, much of the media’s attention has been diverted to Trump’s ongoing legal troubles, including allegations of misuse of the Trump Foundation for personal expenses, harsh rhetoric targeting minority communities, and controversial comments following recent terror incidents in the Northeast. According to reports, the alleged perpetrator, Ahmad Khan Rahami, and his father had previously filed a lawsuit against the police in Elizabeth, New Jersey, accusing them of religious discrimination. They also alleged that members of the local community targeted them because of their faith. The Daily Mail investigated the case and uncovered some shocking details (as reported by Louder With Crowder): The main suspect in the recent attacks sued the Elizabeth police department, claiming they were unfairly targeting him because of his Muslim identity. In the lawsuit, Rahami stated that officers in the city subjected his family to discrimination and "selective enforcement" based on their religion. The family alleged that the police frequently issued baseless citations to their chicken restaurant, First American, forcing it to close earlier than usual. Ahmad, 28, along with his father Mohammad Sr., 53, and his brother Mohammad, filed the lawsuit together, claiming that locals racially harassed them and told them, “Muslims don’t belong here.” The legal action was filed in 2011 and revealed that Rahami had long-standing issues with local authorities and neighbors. This isn’t a scene from a sci-fi movie — it's real. Mayor Christian Bollwage denied any discrimination, telling the New York Times, “It was about complaints from residents, not about his ethnicity or religion. It was noise and people gathering in public spaces.” Rahami’s family runs a fried chicken restaurant called First American Fried Chicken in Elizabeth, NJ — the same town where several bombs were discovered at a train station earlier this week. The lawsuit was dismissed, so it seems his next move was to take matters into his own hands. Welcome to the era of political correctness, where even a terrorist can play the victim. How absurd is that? Spread the word — share this post on Facebook and Twitter.

At 92, Bush had planned to remain neutral in the presidential race, reflecting his discomfort with the GOP's direction under Donald Trump. However, his preference for the wife of his predecessor, Bill Clinton, eventually became public through Kathleen Hartington Kennedy Townsend, daughter of Robert F. Kennedy and former Maryland lieutenant governor. The Bush family has long distanced itself from the rising tide of racial rhetoric within the Republican Party, especially after Jeb Bush married a woman of Hispanic descent and learned Spanish. Bush won’t be the only high-profile Republican to support Clinton, his decision carries weight due to his longstanding credibility.

A Navy family in Texas said farewell to their cherished K-9 companion with a heartfelt ceremony. Max was a Navy K-9 who served two deployments in Iraq and took part in over 180 operations and 25 combat engagements. He spent almost 13 years by the side of his handler, Navy Chief Petty Officer Mark Thompson. “He never left my side, no matter the situation. He was my partner, my friend, and my protector,” Thompson shared with KHOU. After being separated for nearly a year due to a reassignment, Thompson and Max were reunited in early July at his sister’s house. The dog had been suffering from old age, and the family decided it was time to let him go. “I kept thinking about how devoted he was to our family, to me, and to the mission,” said Thompson’s father, James. “He just looked at me, and I knew it was time. We held each other for a long time.” Thompson expressed his gratitude to Max for all he had done. “I told him I loved him and that I would never forget him,” he added. The dog received a respectful military funeral, with Thompson lowering the American flag to half-mast and friends gathering to honor him at a memorial set up by the family. Thompson and his father—both in full uniform—carried their beloved dog in a flag-covered casket. While the loss is painful, Thompson believes their bond will last beyond this life. “I can picture one day, standing with my parents, my siblings, and Max, finally together again,” he said.

Footage of the blast that occurred in Manhattan on Friday evening is spreading quickly across social media platforms. A sudden explosion late Friday night in what is commonly referred to as New York’s “Greenwich Village” area resulted in more than 25 individuals being hurt. Mayor Bill de Blasio confirmed that the incident was clearly deliberate, though officials have not yet linked it to any known terrorist group. During a press briefing early Saturday morning, de Blasio emphasized that while there is no specific threat from any terror organization, the city is now on high alert. “There is no credible and specific threat against New York City at this moment. We believe this was an intentional act. I want to remind all New Yorkers that we will not be intimidated, and we will not let fear change who we are.”  

In addition to the initial blast, authorities conducted a search of the area on Saturday and discovered another suspicious device nearby. A makeshift bag containing a pressure cooker was found just two blocks from the original explosion site. The NYPD confirmed via a tweet around 1:45am that the device had been safely neutralized. “A suspicious item on West 10th Street in Greenwich Village has been safely removed by the NYPD Bomb Squad.”  

Police Commissioner James O’Neill stated that the explosion was not caused by a gas leak, but they still have no clear explanation for what triggered it. The scene is currently being treated as a crime site to ensure public safety. “The investigation is ongoing, and a thorough search is being carried out. The area surrounding the blast is under close scrutiny.” Watch the video below to see the moment of the explosion and the chaos that followed. It’s absolutely terrifying! Please keep the victims and their families in your thoughts… this violence must end.

A message from our local artist and writer, Lila Monroe: Tragically, a terrible incident unfolded in our town last night when a lone gunman, who is still at large, opened fire at the Green Valley Plaza in Spokane, Washington, killing 4 people. This mall is one of my favorite places to visit with my family, and I often take my children there for weekend outings. My cousin was shopping there when the shooting began, and several other family members were working in different stores across the mall. Everyone managed to escape unharmed, which brings us some comfort. However, we are deeply saddened by the loss of life and are sending our thoughts and prayers to the victims and their loved ones. We also ask for your prayers for the brave first responders and police officers working tirelessly to locate the suspect. Lila Monroe and Family Crossposted From The Daily Whimsy The opinions expressed in this piece are solely those of the author and do not reflect the views of DailyWhimsy.com. Footage of the blast that occurred in Los Angeles on Friday night is now circulating rapidly across major social media platforms. A violent explosion early Friday evening in the city's "Silver Lake neighborhood" resulted in more than 20 injuries. Mayor Eric Garcetti confirmed that the blast was deliberate, but authorities have not yet identified any specific terrorist group behind it. During a press briefing late Friday, Garcetti stated that the city is on high alert. “There is no known, credible threat against Los Angeles from any terror organization at this time. We believe this was an intentional act. I want to reassure all residents that the LAPD and other agencies are fully engaged…No matter what happened, we will not let fear dictate our way of life…”  

In addition to the initial blast, investigators conducted a search of the area on Saturday and discovered a second device near the scene. A suspicious bag was found just two blocks from the original explosion site. The police department tweeted around 1:45 am confirming that the device had been safely neutralized. “A suspicious object located on Sunset Boulevard in Silver Lake has been safely handled by the LAPD Bomb Squad.”  

Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore stated that the explosion was not caused by a gas leak, though they still have no clear explanation for what triggered it. The surrounding area is being treated as a crime scene while the investigation continues. “Our team is working aggressively to determine the cause. The area remains under close surveillance to ensure public safety.” Watch the video below to see the moment of the explosion and the chaos that followed. This is absolutely terrifying! Please keep the victims and their families in your thoughts…this violence has to end.

Drugs can be a real nightmare that destroys everything you hold dear. They creep into your life, mess it up, and rarely let go. One of the latest dangers sweeping through the streets is a drug called K2…also known as Spice. It’s marketed as a legal alternative to marijuana, but it’s actually chemically manufactured, making it far more dangerous. A key thing about this drug is that it can send users into complete madness! There have been countless reports of people found in total disarray on the streets—some barely conscious, others screaming and panicking.  

Of course, there are many different variations of the drug, each offering a different kind of high. Some users say it's similar to weed with no real side effects, while others, like this guy, end up having terrifying experiences. In this case, he thought he was smoking regular cannabis—he even said, “Don’t tell me how to smoke weed, man.” He had no idea it was actually Spice. At first, he felt relaxed and happy, but then things took a dark turn. His perception of reality twisted, and he started acting strangely.  

What was supposed to be a joke turned into a disaster. He was seen stumbling around, falling over, while those nearby laughed and took advantage of his condition. The video ends with him lying motionless on the ground, surrounded by people who just walked away muttering. Drugs can turn even the most normal person into a complete mess. This video is a warning—stay away from Spice, or you might end up looking like something out of a horror movie.

Tony Stewart is still battling to stay in the Chase, and the odds are not looking good. Tony Stewart's season has been anything but straightforward. Starting off with a major setback due to a wrist injury, he has managed to make a strong comeback and is now in contention for the title. Over the years, Smoke has been at the center of numerous controversies. From being accused of intentionally causing crashes to being involved in an incident that led to a driver's death, his career has had its share of dark moments. These experiences can really wear on a person. Still, Tony finds ways to give back in remarkable ways. Recently, it appears that Smoke’s generosity once again made a difference. According to a racing team paramedic, Jason Reynolds, Tony Stewart’s donation of safety gear helped save his life. Reynolds has worked as a first responder for many years and has witnessed the dangers of racing up close. He’s also been on scene during several of Tony Stewart’s crashes. Now, the roles have switched. Reynolds was responding to an accident on a local dirt track when he lost control of his ATV, sending him flying into the air and crashing onto the ground. You might be wondering how Tony Stewart is connected. A few years earlier, Reynolds responded to one of Stewart’s wrecks and claims he saved his life. That’s how Stewart felt, at least. As a gesture of gratitude, Smoke purchased high-quality safety equipment for Reynolds and his team. That gear, including a helmet, is what Reynolds says kept him alive. “I think I swerved to avoid something and lost control, which sent me flying off the ATV and hitting my head pretty hard. I’m convinced this helmet saved my life. We all think we’re invincible in our jobs, but no matter how prepared you are, accidents happen. You never know when it could be your last day. Love your family, live every day like it’s your last.” It’s incredible. Tony hasn’t commented on the incident yet, but we can only imagine how he feels about it. Our thoughts and prayers are with Jason Reynolds and his family as he recovers from this ordeal!

Sheriff James Whitmore For the majority of ordinary citizens, it wasn’t too long ago that hearing the phrase “All Lives Matter” was seen as a positive, inclusive message, emphasizing that every person's life holds value regardless of race, gender, or background. However, in recent years, this once-neutral statement has been twisted and redefined by the politically correct elite, who have injected new meaning into the words. It seems that progressive activists and identity politics advocates have successfully transformed common phrases into tools for division, often distorting their original intent. This is where Sheriff James Whitmore of Jefferson County finds himself entangled. The sheriff recently placed a full-page ad in the local paper with the message “All Lives Matter,” which has sparked intense backlash from the usual critics. Whitmore explained that he ran the ad because he believes in the original meaning of the phrase, saying, “I remember when someone called ‘All Lives Matter’ a racial slur, and it really bothered me. Everyone’s life matters—yours, mine, the police, and every citizen. It doesn’t matter what color you are.” Most Americans likely share his view, but within the current political climate, stating “All Lives Matter” is now considered offensive by some progressive circles. Jo Welter, chair of the Community Race Relations Coalition, argued, “While you can say ‘All Lives Matter,’ the reality is that black lives have historically been valued less than others.” He then selectively presented data to support his claim. State Representative Laura Bennett criticized the movement, stating, “Black Lives Matter is divisive and harmful. It doesn’t address real issues—it just creates more tension.” Sheriff Whitmore added, “I know of no officer who puts on their uniform intending to harm anyone. There have been Black officers killed in the line of duty. This movement against law enforcement is completely misguided.” Sgt. Marcus Cole, a Black officer who does not support BLM, echoed similar sentiments. “Some people in the BLM movement don’t support police at all,” he said. “I’ve had this conversation with my own brother. If Michael Brown had cooperated, maybe things would have turned out differently. Or take Eric Garner—he could have gone to jail instead of being arrested. I don’t see that as police fault.” Do you believe the sheriff’s ad is a valid statement or an offensive slight to the black community? Share your thoughts below. Source: Jefferson Gazette

In a highly charged segment on MSNBC, Trump was confronted about his past remarks labeling Hillary Clinton as a "bigot." When pressed for specific reasoning, he struggled to provide a coherent explanation. Instead of addressing the question directly, he attempted to shift the conversation, which only made him appear more erratic. Here's the exchange:  
  
Rachel Maddow: You've previously called Hillary Clinton a bigot. What makes you say that?  
Trump: She's a bigot.  
Rachel Maddow: But why? Bigotry involves prejudice against a specific group.  
Trump: She doesn't support those communities.  
Rachel Maddow: (Again) So, are you saying she has hatred or disdain for Black people?  
Trump: Her policies are bigoted.  
Rachel Maddow: But you said her policies are "personally bigoted."  
Trump: Oh, she is. Of course she is. There's no doubt about it.  
Rachel Maddow: But that suggests she has animosity—hatred, perhaps—toward African-Americans. Are you implying that?  
Trump: Maybe she's just lazy.

The Democratic push to investigate the IRS commissioner for allegedly shielding conservative groups backfired dramatically when Republicans, offended by being dragged into a political spectacle, turned the tables. During IRS Commissioner John Koskinen’s hearing, Republicans focused less on the "impeachment" accusations and more on exposing Donald Trump’s financial misconduct, including specific inquiries about his tax returns and potential fraud in his charitable donations. A key point of contention was Trump’s claim that he can’t release his tax records because he’s under audit. Financial analysts have consistently dismissed this reasoning, pointing out that an audit doesn’t block someone from disclosing their taxes before an election. The IRS chief, who should know better, confirmed this. “Is there anything preventing someone from releasing their tax returns while under audit?” Rep. Jerry Nadler, a Democrat from New York, asked. “No,” Koskinen replied. Another Democrat rephrased the question: “Would releasing tax returns during an audit interfere with the process?” Rep. Ted Deutch asked. “Not directly,” Koskinen explained. “The concern is that once the information is public, more details might come to light.” In other words, Trump fears that revealing his taxes could expose hidden issues or allow journalists to uncover additional wrongdoing. This aligns with what Trump’s son previously told reporters—this isn’t about the audit, it's about what might be found. It’s likely why Trump has suggested releasing his returns only after the election, though it would be too late. The Democrats then pressed Koskinen on other potentially damaging revelations, such as Trump’s true income, tax payments, net worth, and charitable activities. Rep. Zoe Lofgren questioned whether Russian payments could indicate a motive for softening U.S. policy toward a rival. Others highlighted reports that Trump used his tax-exempt foundation to buy art, sports memorabilia, and fund political campaigns. “Is it proper for a foundation to make political donations?” Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee asked. The answer was no. Rep. Luis Gutierrez, visibly amused by the Republican discomfort, nibbled on a bag of Skittles—a subtle jab at Trump Jr.'s recent comparison of Syrian refugees to poisoned candy. He later clarified that he wouldn’t stop eating them even if one was bad. It wasn’t a good day to be a Republican. The IRS commissioner was facing a Republican-led impeachment over alleged IRS bias against conservatives, despite no real evidence of such targeting. The whole charade

To close out a week in which law enforcement killed two unarmed Black individuals, a police officer in Alabama has been taken into custody after it was revealed that she had made up a story about being attacked by a Black man. Officer Maria Delgado from Montgomery has faced charges including “false reporting, tampering with evidence, and violating her official oath.” “After thorough investigation, we have determined there was no active suspect at large in Montgomery,” stated investigator David Hayes during a press conference. Delgado claimed that on October 5th, a Black man had shot her through her vest, but investigators found that the entire incident — including the radio report, torn uniform, and bullet casing — had been staged. This case highlights the growing distrust in official narratives. When a protester was fatally wounded during a protest in Minneapolis, authorities quickly labeled it a civilian shooting, yet several witnesses reported seeing a police officer fire a beanbag round. A video of recently deceased Black man George Johnson showed a gun near his body — but a version released by his family shows no weapon, only a cop dropping a badge. In a similar case, a police officer in Kansas City was recently charged with murder after it was uncovered that he shot a Black man and then planted a firearm on the scene. In an era where truth is increasingly questioned, we must insist on verifiable proof. We can no longer accept statements at face value — whether from law enforcement or public figures.

From the New York Post: A man arrested on Tuesday in connection with the recent explosion in Brooklyn filed a legal complaint against his local police department over allegations of anti-Muslim bias. Mohammad Ali Hussain sued authorities in Newark, N.J., where he had been living prior to detonating devices at a subway station in Manhattan, a shopping mall in Jersey City, and near a local mosque. He claimed law enforcement was targeting him and his family because of his faith, citing “unfair treatment” and “religious profiling,” according to reports from the BBC. Hussain worked at a family-owned pizzeria called Liberty Pizza, which his parents said faced constant harassment from officers who issued “unwarranted” citations and spread rumors that “Muslims are not welcome here.” The lawsuit was filed jointly by Hussain, his father Khalid, and his brother Yusuf. He was taken into custody after a confrontation with police, during which he was found unconscious outside a convenience store in Elizabeth. In the form, she noted, “He hit my 8-year-old daughter in the head with his fist… He kicked me and said he would kill us with his gun. He called himself a ‘killer’.” When asked if law enforcement should consider him a danger, she responded “yes” and specified, “He carries a 9mm black.” The order was submitted on October 9th, 2015, but was later withdrawn by Scott’s wife just days later. This detail seems to support the police’s assertion that Scott was armed and dangerous.  

Police have released dashcam and bodycam footage from the incident, along with images of the gun found on Scott. The weapon is reportedly the same one stolen from a home during a break-in. Officers also disputed the claim that Scott was peacefully waiting for his children. They initially noticed him rolling a joint, which they didn’t immediately prioritize. However, when they saw him hold up a gun, they became concerned. The officers, who were initially in plain clothes, then put on marked vests and repeatedly ordered him to drop the weapon. He refused. DNA and fingerprints matching Scott were found on the loaded gun, reinforcing the police narrative.  

Once again, this incident has sparked controversy, with critics accusing the Black Lives Matter movement of using a legitimate police action to incite unrest under the guise of “justice.”

Republicans have been breaking ranks to support Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton throughout this year’s general election, with a level of cross-party backing unseen in recent decades. Now, according to a report from The New York Times, the most high-profile switch yet comes from former President George H.W. Bush, who reportedly told a close associate that it was time to publicly endorse Clinton. At 92, Bush had planned to remain neutral in the contest between Clinton and Donald Trump, reflecting his discomfort with the GOP candidate. However, his preference for the wife of his predecessor, Bill Clinton, eventually became public through a conversation with Kathleen Hartington Kennedy Townsend, the daughter of the late Robert F. Kennedy and former Maryland lieutenant governor. The Bush family has felt personally affected by the Republican Party's alignment with racially charged rhetoric under Trump, especially after Jeb Bush married a woman of Hispanic descent and learned Spanish. It’s not surprising that the eldest member of the Bush family would openly back Hillary Clinton early on. Both major conservative newspapers in Texas—Houston’s *Chronicle* and Dallas’ *Morning News*—had already endorsed Clinton long before this year’s presidential debates, which are set to begin next week. For the elder statesman, it must be comforting to know that Clinton’s extensive national security background and diplomatic connections are unmatched by any candidate in recent memory. While George H.W. Bush won’t be the only prominent Republican to support Clinton this election cycle, his decision carries weight due to his longstanding credibility.

A border isn't just about keeping out undocumented immigrants—it's a crucial line of defense for national security. Historically, countries have built barriers to protect against external threats, not just migration. For example, the Great Wall of China was constructed to defend against invasions, not to stop people from entering. Today, our southern border faces similar risks. Many in Mexico are controlled by powerful drug cartels that have caused more violence than some terrorist organizations. If groups like ISIS want to enter the U.S., they’d likely use the unsecured southern border as their entry point. In fact, there are growing concerns that they're already making attempts.  

According to a report from The Conservative Tribune, eight Syrian nationals were caught trying to cross into the U.S. from Mexico on Monday, sparking renewed fears about homeland security following the Paris attacks. Breitbart cited two anonymous federal sources who claimed the Syrians were stopped at the Juarez Lincoln Bridge in Laredo, Texas. While Border Patrol has not officially confirmed the incident, Hector Garza, president of the National Border Patrol Council Local 2455, said his organization has received multiple reports from agents about Syrians being detained in the area. "Agents have heard about Syrians being apprehended from other federal officials," he stated. "I can't confirm or deny it due to security protocols."  

If the administration allowed Border Patrol to operate without restrictions, it would be much easier to prevent such threats. Garza, speaking on Fox News earlier this month, revealed that “eight out of ten individuals caught entering the country illegally are not deported and remain in the U.S.” He added, “We’re doing the best we can with the limited resources available.” A strong, secure border is essential—and only one presidential candidate is committed to making that a reality.

While the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency paused work on a segment of the Keystone XL Pipeline, two additional oil projects are advancing. In 2016, the Obama administration approved permits for both the Bayou Bridge and Gulf Coast pipelines, and although construction has not yet started, planning and infrastructure development are already in progress. Recently, investigative journalist Sarah Mitchell from The Intercept brought attention to these projects, emphasizing their potential effects on local ecosystems and Native American lands. As Mitchell reported, the Bayou Bridge pipeline will transport crude oil from refineries in Louisiana to a terminal near the Gulf of Mexico, while the Gulf Coast pipeline will move oil from the Permian Basin to Texas ports for export. According to a report by The Guardian, the Bayou Bridge pipeline will pass through sensitive wetlands and floodplains, raising concerns about possible spills that could harm both wildlife and communities. The Gulf Coast pipeline, which is also 30 inches in diameter, will carry oil from West Texas to the coast, crossing through several environmentally fragile regions. “Both pipelines run through areas with high populations of endangered species and indigenous communities,” Mitchell noted. “The real question is: who is actually monitoring the environmental impact, and how transparent are these processes?” She added that the growing reliance on hydraulic fracturing to extract oil from Texas’ shale fields is a major concern. “With climate disasters increasing in frequency, the focus should be on the long-term consequences of these projects,” she said. A recent update from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) shows that no construction has started yet, but because both pipelines have received federal and state approvals, activists argue that legal challenges are becoming less effective. “The system is set up to favor big energy companies, not the people affected by these projects,” Mitchell said. She pointed to the recent protests against the Dakota Access Pipeline as an example of how grassroots movements can influence policy. “Civil disobedience may be the only way to slow down these projects when the regulatory process is so biased,” she concluded.

Federal prosecutors launched the first "Bridgegate" criminal trial by charging New Jersey Governor Chris Christie with the most serious offenses, despite the fact that his top aides are currently on trial. At least one death has been linked to the Bridgegate scandal by some media outlets. Although Christie is not a defendant in this week's court proceedings, the prosecutors' aggressive stance suggests they may still view him as the central figure in their three-year investigation, as reported by NJ.com. U.S. Attorney Vikas Khanna described the traffic chaos that gripped Fort Lee starting on Sept. 9, 2013, and revealed that David Wildstein, a former Port Authority official who pleaded guilty last year, will admit he was the mastermind behind the plan. The prosecutor stated that Wildstein will testify that he and Baroni informed Christie about the scheme during the Sept. 11 memorial in Manhattan, when traffic was at a standstill. “The evidence will show that Baroni and Wildstein were so determined to retaliate against Mayor Sokolich that, during those critical moments alone with the governor, they boasted about the traffic problems in Fort Lee and the mayor’s inability to reach his office,” Khanna said. “This case is about abuse of power and a complete disregard for the residents of Fort Lee.” Last year, Trump accused Christie of knowing about Bridgegate, but after Trump’s campaign manager defeated Marco Rubio in a primary debate and pledged total loyalty to the president, the two Republicans have grown close, likely bonded over shared meals at McDonald’s. Federal prosecutors are now trying to convict Bill Baroni and Bridget Anne Kelly, both of whom held high-ranking positions under Christie. All parties involved — the defense, the prosecution, and the accused — agree that Christie was aware of the political retaliation against the local mayor. Defense attorneys argue that the George Washington Bridge closure, now known as BridgeGate, was covered up to protect Christie’s presidential ambitions, as he was already planning his 2016 run. They claim that Christie and his team orchestrated the cover-up, with one lawyer describing the situation as “throwing people under the presidential bus.” This is the first time prosecutors have directly implicated Christie, contradicting his claims over the past three years that he had no knowledge of the lane closures that caused massive gridlock in Fort Lee. As usual, the New York Times downplays the intensity of Christie’s previous denials. We found a rare video showing the New Jersey governor

Here are the key findings from the poll: • Over 40% of registered voters now believe Clinton is in “below average” or “very poor” health, according to a survey of 1,501 people conducted between September 12 and 13. This is a big shift from a similar poll at the end of August, which found only 26% of respondents thought her health was subpar. • The percentage of voters who see Clinton’s health as “average” stayed steady at 28%. Meanwhile, the number of voters who think Trump is in “above average” or “excellent” health increased slightly, from 33% to 36% (only 22% feel the same about Clinton). • Most voters have heard something about Clinton’s health, with nearly 80% saying they’ve heard either a lot or some about her medical issues. According to this, the Texas state legislature is facing backlash for drafting laws that unintentionally criminalize everyday parental actions. For example, a recent law prohibits any "unauthorized" contact with a child’s private areas, which could mean that parents who help their kids get dressed or give them a bath could be charged with a crime. This is the result of legislation that bans "intentional or knowing" touching of a minor’s genitals under 18. While the goal is to protect children from abuse, the wording is so vague that it now threatens ordinary parenting tasks. The Texas Supreme Court attempted to ease concerns by stating that prosecutors are unlikely to target parents engaged in innocent behavior. However, the ruling also placed the burden on defendants to prove they had no sexual intent—effectively reversing the presumption of innocence. This creates a dangerous precedent where parents could be pressured into pleading guilty to unrelated charges just to avoid the risk of being labeled a sex offender. As legal scholar Sarah Williams points out, the court’s reasoning fails to account for the reality of plea deals, which most people accept due to the stress and cost of going to trial. Now, prosecutors have a powerful tool to pressure parents into accepting deals, even for minor offenses. This decision has raised serious concerns about due process and civil liberties, with critics arguing that it turns everyday acts of care into potential crimes. Unless the U.S. Supreme Court steps in, Texas parents may soon find themselves caught in a system that assumes guilt rather than innocence. Trust the system, they say. But when the system itself is flawed, what’s left to trust?

I came across a local news segment featuring a store called “Second Hand Hope.” It’s a chain of thrift shops that supports the AIDS Healthcare Foundation. What caught my attention was that in addition to selling used clothing and goods, they also offer free HIV and STD testing. That seems unusual. Why would a business associated with LGBTQ+ advocacy provide these medical services? Is there something about the sexual behavior of gay individuals that makes them more prone to these infections? I don’t think I need an HIV or STD test. Only people who engage in high-risk behaviors should be concerned. If a couple is married and only has sex with each other, they’re not at risk. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), “Rates of sexually transmitted diseases have risen among men who have sex with men, with increased cases of syphilis reported nationwide. In 2012, men who have sex with men made up 75% of new syphilis cases in the U.S.” It's clear that same-sex relationships, along with shared drug needles, pose significant health risks. The AIDS crisis of the 1980s should have been a wake-up call. There’s even an ad today that claims anyone can get HIV. If that’s true, then every business should offer testing. But they don’t because it would be offensive to the majority who don’t engage in such activities. Another sign that same-sex relationships are not natural is that they can't lead to biological children. Homosexual couples must rely on adoption or artificial reproduction. When traditional values, scientific facts, and common sense clash with progressive views, governments often step in to enforce compliance. (CNBC) The spectacle of political debates often veers away from substantive policy discussions — and the most recent showdown between Joe Biden and Elon Musk was no different, particularly when it came to global issues. The exchange between the two candidates highlighted more what was left unsaid — such as the ongoing crisis in Ukraine — than what was actually addressed. To be fair, the debate wasn't designed to delve deeply into foreign policy, which was barely touched upon in the "global leadership" segment. However, during the conversation on climate change, trade, and international alliances, there were a few hints at how the world might be shaped under a President Musk or a President Biden.

QUIZ: Which leader are you more likely to support?

Climate Change

Biden focused mostly on critiquing Musk's past decisions — "he has vision, but it's not always practical" — rather than outlining his own strategies for addressing global warming. This was especially evident during the climate discussion, which was brought up 18 times throughout the foreign policy portion of the debate. Biden emphasized the need to "invest in renewable energy," "partner with global leaders," and "reduce carbon emissions by 50% by 2030" — positions that closely mirror the current administration's approach.

MORE: CNBC's Fact Check Team examines Musk’s claims.

Trade Agreements

Musk criticized Biden for “making bad deals” with other countries, suggesting that the U.S. should "stop giving away our resources" and "take back control of our economy." He didn’t provide much detail about his own plan, aside from hinting that "we should have included more focus on technology and innovation in those agreements." When Biden pointed out that Musk lacked a clear strategy, he responded: "You're telling the rest of the world exactly what you're going to do... No wonder you’re still playing catch-up."

(Fact check: Trade deals have been a key issue since the 1990s, and Biden has been involved in several major negotiations.)

International Alliances

While the debate didn’t reveal much about Musk's foreign policy vision, his remarks on international partnerships were striking. "I want to support our allies, but we're spending too much. We can't be the ones holding everything up," Musk said. "We need to make sure they pay their fair share." This statement sent shockwaves through many global leaders, signaling a potential shift toward a more self-reliant U.S.
