Reports suggest that hundreds, if not thousands, of Islamic immigrants are attempting to cross the southern border illegally. A recent report from Judicial Watch revealed that Mexican drug cartels are increasingly smuggling individuals from countries linked to terrorism into the U.S. Another study from the same organization indicated that extremist groups based in Mexico have started making plans to enter the country and scout out possible targets. The border is now a major security risk, and it's only a matter of time before a major attack occurs. This can all be traced back to President Obama and his policies supporting open borders. He wants America to follow Europe’s path, which is now destabilized by mass migration and Islamic extremism. From a source called Truth Today: Authorities in Arizona recently pulled over a vehicle, only to discover it was being driven by an undocumented woman from the Middle East. The situation escalated when officers found documents related to a gas pipeline in the car. Now, local officials are on high alert. Judicial Watch claims that a sheriff in Pima County stopped an “Islamic refugee” for an unknown reason. Fortunately, what began as a minor traffic violation led to a major discovery when agents uncovered pipeline schematics in the suspect’s possession. These plans are tied to the area near the town of Tucson, located just 20 miles south of the Mexican border and 45 miles east of Phoenix. Tucson is known for its high crime rates, economic struggles, and failing schools, making it one of the most vulnerable areas in the state. The region is also a key transit zone for drug trafficking, with large quantities of meth, cocaine, and heroin moving through the area. The media has ignored this growing threat, but it’s a serious national concern. This issue could determine the outcome of the upcoming election. Our leaders must prioritize national security, secure the border, and ensure that all incoming refugees are thoroughly vetted. Otherwise, we risk more lives lost

What's happening with the NBA? What’s become of America’s most popular sport? The viewership has taken a sharp drop lately, though it hasn’t caused much real harm…yet. But what if fans finally lose patience with the league’s pro-athlete stance and 40% of them decide to stop watching? That’s what some are saying, and it all seems to trace back to players like LeBron James and Kevin Durant, who have spoken out against social injustice and refused to stand for the national anthem—some even raising their fists in protest, not fully understanding the meaning behind it. If this actually happens, it’ll be because of the growing influence of these activists and the leagues that support them. There’s a new online survey suggesting that 40% of fans would follow through on their threat. Of course, it’s just an internet poll, so don’t take it too seriously—but still, it’s worth noting. According to the survey, several factors are driving fans away. Some said the absence of star players like Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O’Neal was enough to turn them off, while others blamed the protests as a major reason for their disinterest. With ongoing tensions following recent incidents involving law enforcement, it’s unlikely the protests will fade anytime soon. But how long can this continue? What’s the ultimate goal here? Will the league finally crack down and punish players for disrespecting the flag, or will it keep catering to political trends? I’m betting on the latter.

As many of our followers know, there has been growing concern about the physical condition of Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton in recent weeks. This has been fueled in part by an incident last week when Clinton appeared to have difficulty navigating a set of stairs at a community center in Manhattan. According to a video shared on social media by CNN reporter Dana Jacobson, who was covering the event, Clinton was leaving the Children’s Museum and heading down a short flight of steps when she seemed to pause, focusing intently on her balance and grip on the railing.

The clip shows Clinton walking slowly, pausing briefly as she descended, before finally turning to face the reporter and offering a brief, almost distracted response. When asked about her preparation for the upcoming presidential debate, she simply said, “I’m ready,” before quickly stepping into her motorcade without assistance. A Secret Service agent remained nearby, seemingly prepared to help if needed.

While it's possible that Clinton simply wasn’t paying attention to the reporter at first, the video has sparked renewed discussion about her overall health and mobility. Some have pointed to this as further evidence of potential medical issues that could affect her ability to perform in public settings. Others have suggested that her behavior may reflect a pattern of selective engagement with the press.

Share this video on Facebook and Twitter so more people can see Hillary Clinton carefully navigating a short staircase, seemingly focused on her footing rather than the questions being asked. What do you think about the way she handled this situation? Leave your thoughts below!

There is a growing number of Americans who believe the Black Lives Matter movement is more interested in inciting unrest than in genuinely advocating for the safety and rights of black citizens. Matt Walsh of TheBlaze doesn’t hold back when he labels the group as “radicals” and outlines his reasoning with conviction. If you support the cause but disagree with the tactics, this might be the most important article you read today. He begins by examining the recent events in Charlotte, North Carolina. If you're unclear about what happened there, here's a quick summary: a black officer shot and killed a black man who was armed, leading to a wave of protests that turned into widespread looting and destruction of black-owned businesses. It sounds extreme, but Walsh argues it’s not far from the truth. He continues: That still doesn’t make sense. Why are they insisting Keith Scott was unarmed when the evidence clearly shows he had a weapon? And regardless of whether the shooting was justified, why are they chanting “white cops are evil” when the officer involved was actually black? Even if the officer were white — which he wasn’t — and even if all white cops were evil (a theological stretch), why are they destroying their own neighborhoods in response? And the most puzzling question of all: Why do we still call this kind of violence, chaos, and lawlessness a “protest”? It seems like an eerie pattern that every BLM “protest” ends in destruction. I almost said these demonstrations “turn violent,” but that’s not quite right. After watching similar events unfold in cities nationwide, it’s clear that violence and destruction are the goal, not just side effects. The media keeps repeating the same line — that these protests “started peacefully” and then “turned violent.” But that’s like saying a carjacking “began as a normal drive through the neighborhood” before the criminals opened fire. It may technically be true, but the whole point was always the violence. These so-called protests are not random acts of rage. They are organized, intentional, and increasingly destructive. They seem to be getting worse with each incident. Read the full piece here — it’s well worth your time.

What emerged, however, was in structure and visual style reminiscent of previous debates — two candidates behind podiums — only this time featuring a veteran statesman and an inexperienced contender. And it was Trump, expected to shine with his usual flair, who at times appeared unsettled, one of several distractions that seemed more about how he delivered his remarks than what he actually said. The exchange didn’t exactly make for a commanding performance, especially in terms of political drama. But for those who believed that hosting "The Apprentice" would prepare Trump for this kind of setting, it turned out the skills required were quite different from what he needed on that night. Clinton, on the other hand, entered the debate with a clear plan: remain composed, calm, and seemingly unbothered by Trump’s statements, while slipping in a few well-rehearsed jabs. This included emphasizing that she had thoroughly prepared for the event, offering a sharp contrast to some of Trump’s off-the-cuff responses. There were also effective reactions, such as when she responded to one of Trump's long-winded answers by saying, "Just listen to what you just heard." Related: One thing Clinton and Trump didn’t debate: the debate itself. Trump, by contrast, who had faced numerous opponents during the primaries, seemed out of place in this one-on-one setting. With so many candidates on stage before, his aggressive style stood out; here, sharing the stage only with Clinton, it became harder to rely on his usual hit-and-run tactics. He interrupted Clinton frequently — initially to score points, but as the debate continued, those interruptions began to feel more like outbursts, as if the attack ads she had run against him (which he mentioned) were getting to him. Trump’s constant sniffing, which continued throughout, also served as a distraction — not a major issue in theory, but one that quickly became a target for online mockery. His attempts to dominate certain discussions caused some challenges for the third participant in this mini-drama, Lester Holt. Holt, the "NBC Nightly News" anchor, had perhaps the most difficult role imaginable, given all the anticipation leading up to it and the inevitable post-debate analysis. Holt performed adequately, occasionally fact-checking Trump’s claims — particularly when he tried to deny direct quotes attributed to him — and pushing him for concrete answers. Those moments when he challenged the candidate likely won’t sit well with Trump’s most loyal supporters, but Holt avoided the image

An English man, Daniel Clarke, has been taken into custody and is set to face trial after putting up anti-halal stickers on meat at a supermarket in his home city of Manchester. Halal refers to the religious method of slaughtering animals according to Islamic law. Clarke strongly objects to halal practices, citing connections to both violent extremism and inhumane treatment of animals. The stickers stated, “Warning: Halal is brutal and supports radical groups #StopHalal.” Recently, an investigation by an animal welfare group revealed footage showing Muslims at a slaughterhouse in Lancashire using dull knives to cut animals’ throats, while also dragging and beating them during the process. According to a British anti-Islam advocate named Mr. Thompson, funds from halal meat sales often end up supporting extremist causes. Additionally, companies that buy halal-certified products are required to pay a religious levy. Despite these claims, the prosecutor in Clarke’s case, Emma Wright, argued in court that “one can criticize the treatment of animals without linking it to religion or terrorism.” As a result, Clarke now faces charges of “religiously aggravated damage” and will stand trial on August 15 (H/T Daily Mail). It seems that in the UK, speaking plainly about halal practices can be seen as inflammatory. One can only hope Clarke lived in America, where free speech protections allow people to share their views without fear of legal repercussions. Share this post if you believe exposing the truth about animal suffering and extremism is more important than political correctness. Via Right Wing Watch

President Obama is often highlighted for his impact on African American communities. He frequently references his upbringing on the south side of Chicago as a symbol of overcoming adversity. However, what many don’t realize is that he spent significant portions of his childhood in Indonesia and Kenya. Throughout his presidency, he has repeatedly claimed that his leadership has helped reduce racial divides. Yet, incidents like those in Ferguson, St. Louis, and Minneapolis suggest that tensions remain high. The Democratic Party has traditionally relied on strong support from African Americans, women, and Latino voters, often targeting these groups during election cycles. But not all members of these communities agree with the party's stance. Some are now voicing their frustrations online, particularly on Twitter. Here are some examples: @BlackPatriot123 @realDonaldTrump I'm tired of Obama's legacy being praised when things are getting worse! What about the crime? — Angry Black Man (@raymondjones) September 18, 2016  
Obama’s Veto of the 9/11 Families’ Bill Shows His True Colors https://t.co/9LwqB7mY5g via @newsdaily — RebelRed (@RebelRed) September 22, 2016  
Obama’s Legacy: 8 years of chaos, crime, and division. Time for a change! Vote Trump! — The Truth Seeker (@truthseeker123) September 20, 2016  
Obama’s Legacy: Promised hope, delivered despair. No real progress for minorities. — Jamal Johnson (@jamaljohnson) September 24, 2016  
Trump even shared a clip of Obama speaking at an event where he suggested that not voting for Hillary Clinton would be disrespectful to his legacy. As Trump put it, Obama is always focused on himself, never on the people. Watch the speech here.  
Many users have pointed to the spike in violence and unrest as evidence of his failed leadership. Others criticized his decision to block the 9/11 bill allowing families to sue Saudi Arabia. A number of people also brought up the increase in shootings and the Iran deal as proof of his poor judgment. Just look at Twitter, and you can see that his legacy isn’t as positive as he claims—especially when it comes to law enforcement and national security. But for Obama, it seems his ego is more important than the real issues facing the country.

Hillary Clinton's ground presence in Ohio is minimal. The video below reveals what was found. The Clinton campaign is said to be strong on paper. Hillary Clinton often highlights the size of her staff. Then there are the volunteers. Most voters know that Ohio is a key battleground state. At one point, it was reported that Clinton had over 681 paid workers, while Trump had just 68. With such a disparity, the Clinton team clearly holds an advantage, right? Additionally, although Trump has improved his local outreach, Clinton has continued to expand her workforce. Recent figures show the Clinton campaign now has more than 1000 paid employees. A Trump supporter heard about a door-to-door effort and decided to investigate. He arrived at an office with chairs arranged for a meeting. Only one person was inside. After a short while, a woman emerged and introduced herself. Apart from a few volunteers behind the counter, that’s what the Clinton operation looked like in that part of OH. When the Trump representative starts pointing out the realities of the setup, the response isn’t positive. If you can count your volunteers on one hand, you have a serious issue. This likely explains the "enthusiasm gap" that liberal media is struggling to explain. It also shows why Clinton hasn't been able to secure the state. Recent polls show Trump closing in or even leading. His fundraising numbers clearly reflect stronger support for Trump than for Clinton.

President Barack Obama delivered what was intended to be his last speech to the U.N. General Assembly, and it sparked controversy with its pessimistic take on the effectiveness of military force in combating Islamist extremism across the Middle East. The speech suggested that despite America's global military dominance, the president seemed to imply that victory is unattainable. According to a report by Fox News, Obama highlighted the deep-rooted nature of militant groups within Islam that have fueled the rise of ISIS, questioning whether military action alone could ever resolve such conflicts. “If we are honest, we must recognize that no outside force can compel different religious or ethnic groups to live together peacefully for long,” Obama stated. He emphasized the need for “honesty about these conflicts” and urged the international community to support those working toward peace and reconciliation. While acknowledging that military efforts may play a role, he pointed out that in places like Syria, “there is no clear military victory to be achieved.” Obama called for a focus on diplomacy, aid delivery, and political solutions that promote mutual respect among diverse groups. You can watch the full speech here; the key section starts around 28:45. It’s hard not to question how this approach will succeed when leaders refuse to openly connect violence with radical Islam and instead criticize religious minorities while downplaying the threat from extremists. We also wonder how effective this strategy will be when leaders fail to treat all people—regardless of belief—with the dignity they deserve. It’s difficult to move forward if we label the right people as undesirable and the wrong ones as peaceful. Consider this carefully before the next election. Share this post on Facebook and Twitter and tell us what you think about Obama’s stance at the U.N. What’s your take on his view of America’s military strength? Leave a comment below!

A high-profile police shooting that occurred over the weekend in Kansas City, Missouri, has sparked intense debate and outrage from Black Lives Matter activists and progressive media outlets. A video captured from a drone showed a 35-year-old unarmed African American man, Marcus Johnson, standing with his hands raised as he was fatally shot by white officer James Carter, reinforcing the perception that law enforcement frequently uses excessive force against Black individuals who are not a threat. However, according to local news outlet The Kansas City Star, investigators found a bag of methamphetamine inside Johnson’s vehicle, which may have played a role in his actions during the encounter. 

Methamphetamine is known to cause extreme agitation, paranoia, and aggression, often leading users to act unpredictably and aggressively, even when confronted by law enforcement. In some cases, individuals under the influence of the drug have been reported to ignore pain and continue attacking officers despite being shot. Additionally, Johnson had a history of violent offenses, including multiple arrests for assault and drug possession, and was wanted for failing to appear in court on charges of drug-related crimes. His prior record suggests he may have been resistant to authority and unwilling to comply with police instructions.

Some witnesses claimed that Johnson appeared disoriented and aggressive before the shooting, which could have led Officer Carter to believe he was a danger to himself and others. The medical examiner is expected to release a toxicology report confirming whether Johnson was under the influence of meth at the time of the incident. Share this story on social media to raise awareness about the drugs found in Marcus Johnson’s car, which may have contributed to the tragic outcome. Do you think the presence of meth in his system changes the story? Let us know in the comments below!

I love Texas! I mean I really love their spirit. They’re like the honey badger, they just don’t back down from a fight. Governor Abbott is the perfect example of a true Texan because he’s not afraid to stand up for his people—even if it means going head-to-head with Joe Biden. On Tuesday, Governor Abbott announced that Texas will no longer take part in the federal refugee program due to growing concerns over national security. Abbott has every right to be worried, especially after several violent incidents across the country this past week. He doesn’t want to risk allowing poorly vetted refugees into the state who might have extremist ties. The Texas Refugee Office sent a 120-day notice of their decision to withdraw. The Office of Refugee Resettlement responded by saying their integration programs only begin after thorough security checks. However, the current refugee screening process is full of flaws and has already allowed multiple extremists into the U.S. “The federal refugee resettlement system is deeply flawed and poses a serious threat to our country,” Abbott stated. “The FBI and the Director of National Intelligence have repeatedly warned that we cannot fully vet refugees from countries linked to terrorism. Despite this, President Biden is pushing to dramatically increase the number of refugees coming into the U.S.” “While most refugees are harmless, some are a real danger—like the Afghan refugee recently arrested for planning an attack in Dallas,” Abbott said. “Texas has asked the federal government to fix this problem, but they’ve failed to distinguish between safe and dangerous individuals. We won’t be complicit in this failure,” he added. “Therefore, Texas is pulling out of the refugee resettlement program. I strongly urge the federal government to fix this broken system before more lives are put at risk.” So there, Mr. President!

Both 2016 presidential contenders had the opportunity to address the recent explosions in New York and New Jersey. The contrast between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton was clear, even in these brief statements. Watch! See how different Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton responded to last night’s bombing in New York City. Trump said, “I just got off a plane and a bomb exploded in New York — nobody knows what’s happening,” he told a crowd at a rally in Colorado Springs, Colorado. “We’re living in a dangerous time. We need to be strong, smart, and on high alert.” These remarks were made mere minutes after the incident. In contrast, Hillary appeared disoriented during her statement, seeming confused and contradicting herself within seconds. At the 0:32 mark in the video, she mentioned, “I’ve been informed about the bombings in New York and New Jersey, as well as the attack in Minnesota.” Then, at 1:15, when asked if Trump was right to call it a bomb, she replied, “It’s important to understand the facts of any event like this. That’s why we need to support the first responders and investigators who are working to find out what happened.” Did she really not know that bombs cause explosions? It’s baffling. The gap in their composure and clarity is staggering. Hillary Clinton clearly isn’t fit to lead. She should step down and take a break.

Obama’s presidency is drawing to a close, and millions of Americans are eagerly awaiting the day he leaves the White House. He once vowed to transform America for the better, but many believe he has instead left a trail of disappointment in his wake. It's hard to imagine his legacy being celebrated once he's gone, given that so much of what he put in place has failed. Yet, despite this, Obama continues to promote his record — and now he's urging Americans to defend his legacy by supporting a specific candidate.  

In a recent address to the Congressional Black Caucus, Obama referenced the Jim Crow era and slavery to push for voter turnout, suggesting that the future of progress depends on choosing the “right” person. He didn’t name the candidate directly, but his message was clear: support Hillary Clinton or risk undermining everything he stands for. “My name may not be on the ballot,” he said, “but our progress is. And there’s one candidate who will carry that forward, and another who’s built their campaign on opposing everything we’ve worked for.”  

He highlighted the strong African-American voter turnout in 2008 and 2012, warning that failure to mobilize would be an insult to his legacy. “If this community doesn’t step up, I’ll take it personally,” he said. “You want to honor me? Then go vote.”  

But facts paint a different picture. It was the Democratic Party that historically supported slavery, segregation, and Jim Crow. The Republican Party was founded to end those very systems. The first African-American members of Congress were Republicans, and it was Democrats who created the Ku Klux Klan to suppress black voting rights.  

Meanwhile, Obama’s record with the black community isn’t as positive as he claims. His administration cut D.C.’s school voucher program, limiting access to quality education for low-income families. Unemployment and reliance on food assistance have risen sharply, hitting black communities hardest. He’s done little to address the breakdown of the black family, the high rate of abortions among black women, or the alarming number of children born out of wedlock.  

So why is he still boasting about his legacy? It seems like he’s lost touch with reality.

If there's one thing you can say about Trump supporters, it's that they're certain about what they don't understand. And what they don't understand could fill entire libraries, as seen in a recent exchange captured on the September 18 episode of Comedy Central’s *The Daily Show*. You might not fault these individuals for the wild theories they believe—many of these ideas originate from conservative media outlets like Fox News. But when given the chance, some Trump voters come up with their own outlandish conspiracy claims that even right-wing pundits might hesitate to endorse. Reporter Jordan Klepper attended a Trump rally and spoke with attendees, and what he heard was both shocking and bizarre. Trump once praised the “uneducated,” and Klepper found plenty of them gathered to hear from their leader. The first few people he spoke to were fixated on rumors about Hillary Clinton's health. One man insisted she has AIDS, which he claimed she caught from Bill. And where did Bill get it? “From messing around with Magic Johnson,” the man said. We assume he meant the former NBA player, not the ex-president’s, uh, “johnson.” It didn’t take long for Klepper to meet people who clearly live in a different reality. There was the man who believed Clinton has a secret twin, and when shown two identical photos of her, he confidently pointed to the one he thought was the fake. Then there was the person who claimed President Obama is Muslim because of the way he wears his necklace. This refers to an old myth that suggested Obama stopped wearing his watch and wedding ring during Ramadan, but there's no rule against Muslims wearing jewelry during the holy month—except in this person’s mind. So, the absence of a watch proves nothing. But the most outrageous claim came from someone who said Hillary has AIDS and questioned why Obama wasn’t in the Oval Office on 9/11. These people will be voting on November 8. Will you be? Here’s the video, via Comedy Central: Featured image via Comedy Central screen capture. Here’s another “enthusiastic” Trump supporter: according to authorities, he was planning to build a bomb targeting Muslims.

People never know when to stop, do they? They just can’t let things settle on their own without trying to turn everything into a disaster. Well, maybe not “people” in general, but specifically Jamal Carter, a Christian man who was invited by the family of Michael Brown to address the aftermath of his death. Of course, he couldn’t just speak without thanking God and encouraging the demonstrators to take it further—like looting stores and setting fires, which, for some reason, they think is a proper way to "fight systemic racism." After declaring that black people “don’t see no fairness” (because grammar isn’t everyone’s strong suit), he said he wasn’t “telling our brothers and sisters to back down,” referring to the chaos that’s supposedly in the name of “equality.” You know, the same equality they’ve been denied? Or something like that. His speech apparently worked so well that, according to a conservative outlet, protesters in St. Louis were shouting “We’re like the Taliban!” That’s what we need—Christians exploiting angry citizens and fueling more domestic extremism. Can this guy be arrested for encouraging violence? Maybe for inciting a riot? Oh, what am I thinking… he’s one of the “protected groups” in America. The most the government would do is give him a job managing community outreach programs.

Pennsylvania Republicans are pushing a bill through the state legislature that would take immediate effect, enabling voter intimidation across the state on Election Day in support of Donald Trump. First introduced in June, House Bill 29 would allow non-residents to observe polling places and challenge voters, potentially disrupting the voting process and creating delays that could prevent people from casting their ballots. In essence, it would formalize voter intimidation. As Adam Gitlin, counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice, warned earlier this month, poll watchers—especially those who target voters based on race or religion—could severely undermine the democratic process. “There's a real risk that untrained individuals will show up at the polls, not understand the rules, and engage in biased challenges,” Gitlin said. “This could lead to long lines, confusion, and a chilling effect on voter participation.” Conservatives aligned with Trump, known for their extreme views and insistence on enforcing a particular version of Christianity, are expected to target Black, Latino, and Muslim voters. And that’s precisely what Trump wants. “We’re going to watch Pennsylvania closely,” Trump stated at a recent rally. “Go into certain neighborhoods, observe, and make sure no one votes multiple times. If we do that, we won’t lose. The only way we can lose is if there’s cheating.” Trump even has a section on his website encouraging supporters to sign up as poll watchers to “Stop Crooked Hillary From Rigging This Election!” In response to Trump’s claims of election fraud, Pennsylvania Republicans added an amendment to the bill to make it effective immediately upon passage and governor’s approval. Originally, it was set to take effect 60 days after being signed. With polls showing a tight race ahead of the first debate, Pennsylvania has become even more crucial. But voter intimidation could shift the balance in Trump’s favor and impact races at all levels. In short, Trump and the GOP are attempting to rig the election by legalizing a form of voter suppression. And if this strategy succeeds in Pennsylvania, expect similar tactics to spread nationwide.

If you’re like me, you're counting down the days until the Donald Trump – Hillary Clinton debate. Don’t get me wrong – as someone who cares about policy, I’m disappointed to see both candidates avoid substantive discussion. Trump speaks in blunt, no-nonsense terms that resonate with Americans frustrated by what they see as political correctness and a lack of leadership across all levels of government. Hillary, on the other hand, relies on manipulation, selective facts, and carefully curated messaging meant to keep her image intact long enough to secure another term in office. Still, the debate should be compelling — Hillary tends to unravel under pressure, while Trump thrives when challenged and pushed back against. Think about how he handled Megyn Kelly’s aggressive questioning during the 2016 primaries. It’s not just Trump that’s concerning; Hillary is entering the debate with a poll trend that continues to slide. While most polls showed her ahead after the primaries, they’ve been heavily influenced by biased sampling and questionable methodologies. The Real Clear Politics average currently shows her leading by just 2.3%. When you factor in the bias, it's likely a dead heat. Recent projections suggest that Trump is only one state away from a potential win in November. That means the race is still very much up in the air. Even the most confident analysts are starting to question the reliability of the data. FiveThirtyEight has dropped Hillary’s chances of winning from 71.2% on September 11th to 58.4% on September 20th. While polls may not always reflect reality (as seen with Karl Rove’s infamous predictions), the truth is that public opinion is turning against Hillary as more details come to light, while support for Trump has remained steady. Many people think this is a two-candidate race, but it’s really a three-way contest: Trump, Hillary, and “none of the above.” Trump’s base has been behind him for a long time — they see him as a catalyst for change. Meanwhile, some supporters of progressive policies are still upset about the way Bernie Sanders was sidelined, and their dissatisfaction doesn’t automatically translate into votes for Hillary. In a direct matchup, the race could be very close. But how many Democrats will simply stay home rather than risk being associated with a candidate who might lose badly? And if Hillary can't hold her own in the debate, will that finally make liberals reconsider everything Trump has been saying about her weakness and inability to

This week, as Americans were shocked by a series of brutal attacks across the country carried out by extremist Muslim groups, the public was stunned to learn that the Obama administration is still pushing forward with plans to welcome 110,000 Muslim refugees from the Middle East this year. During her campaign for the presidency, Hillary Clinton has promised to dramatically increase that number, pledging to bring in over 620,000 poorly vetted Muslim immigrants in her first term if elected. The logic behind such policies is baffling—there is no reliable system in place to screen these individuals for ties to terrorism, criminal records, or willingness to integrate into American society. Despite rising concerns about Islamic extremism on U.S. soil, both Obama and Clinton remain committed to their immigration agenda.

The top priority of any U.S. president should be the safety of the American people. Yet, many state leaders and local officials believe that security is being compromised. Several governors, including Texas’ Greg Abbott, have openly opposed the resettlement of Muslim refugees, citing incidents of crime and violence involving previously resettled individuals in places like Phoenix, Detroit, and Kansas City. Texas has now taken a firm stance, refusing to accept any more Middle Eastern Muslim immigrants, warning of potential threats to public safety.

With over two dozen states challenging the Obama administration’s immigration policies in court, the issue has escalated into a constitutional crisis. Governor Abbott’s refusal to comply represents a direct challenge to federal authority, echoing the principles of the Tenth Amendment and state sovereignty. This movement has gained momentum, fueled by frustration over what many see as unconstitutional executive overreach and a lack of accountability from the federal government.

As the nation grapples with the growing influence of radical Islam and the erosion of traditional checks and balances, state leaders are increasingly turning to legal and political tools to reclaim control. Organizations like "Free Nebraska" and similar groups in other states are advocating for a "convention of states" to address these concerns. With the upcoming presidential election seen as one of the most critical in history, the tension between federal power and state rights is reaching a boiling point.

If the current trajectory continues, the conflict could lead to further division, open resistance, and even violent confrontation. While many hope for a peaceful resolution, the signs of a deepening crisis are becoming impossible to ignore. The struggle for freedom and self-governance is intensifying, and the price of restoring America’s constitutional order may be high. As

Donald Trump has just captured what may be his strongest poll of the general election season, revealing a growing lead over Hillary Clinton, with particular gains among African American voters that have stunned the Democratic Party. The latest "USC Dornsife/Los Angeles Times" “Daybreak” poll released on Saturday shows Trump ahead by 6.2 percentage points, 47.5 percent to 41.3 percent, suggesting that Clinton’s recent health-related controversies—starting with her abrupt departure from a 9/11 event and followed by shifting explanations from “exhaustion” to “pneumonia”—are beginning to take a toll. More alarming for Democrats, however, is Trump's unexpected rise in support among Black voters, now at 21 percent, up from just 4 percent a week prior. Clinton, by contrast, holds 68 percent, far below the usual numbers for Democratic candidates. Notably, young voters—who once favored Clinton by a wide margin—are now showing an 8-point advantage for Trump, while those with only a high school education or less have shifted sharply in his favor, giving him a 20-point lead compared to single digits just weeks ago. While the LA Times poll has historically been more favorable to Trump than many others, this latest result—showing his broadening appeal and strong performance in key demographics—has sent shockwaves through the Clinton campaign and Democratic establishment. Some analysts believe that internal polling within the Clinton team had already flagged this shift before the release of the new survey. With the media reigniting the “birther” debate, it's clear that the race for the presidency is heating up—and the Democrats are scrambling to respond. Email Subscribe

Conservatives often claim that Islam is a religion of peace and compassion. However, the truth is far more complex. While they criticize traditional values on issues like LGBTQ+ rights, they tend to overlook the harsh realities faced by gay individuals in certain communities. The growing Muslim population in Western nations is increasingly highlighting these contradictions. Many conservatives have supported the influx of Muslim immigrants into their countries, but the consequences have been alarming. In several European cities, elements of sharia law are beginning to take root, and for those who are marginalized by Islamic teachings, this is deeply troubling. Police were called to a New Jersey middle school after a 12-year-old student said, "Chocolate," while discussing desserts, his father claimed. Another student reportedly took the comment as a racial slur, according to the Bergen County Record. A staff member then alerted the authorities. “He was just talking about snacks,” said the boy’s father, Michael Thompson. “Who did he offend? I don’t understand why this became a police matter.” Thompson expressed concern about the school's handling of the situation, saying it has made him reconsider sending his son back next semester. “I don’t trust the staff anymore, and my son is scared,” he added. “There was a cop with a badge asking him what he said, and he didn’t know how to respond.” The police also spoke with the other student’s parents, and the case was forwarded to the New Jersey Division of Child Protection and Permanency. Collingswood Police Chief Kevin Carey mentioned during a meeting with school leaders that they should report even minor incidents, including things like name-calling or slang that could be misinterpreted. “It’s not just about serious issues like weapons or drugs anymore,” Carey said. This new approach has led to more frequent police visits to the school, sometimes multiple times a day. “It’s just kids being kids,” said teacher Lisa Martinez. “I’ve never felt so unsure about how to handle something before.” The mayor, local police, and the Camden County Prosecutor’s Office held a meeting to address the growing concerns. “We made it clear that the Memorandum of Agreement hasn’t changed,” Collingswood Mayor Jim Maley wrote in a letter to the prosecutor’s office, as reported by the Collingswood Patch. Sources: Bergen County Record, Collingswood Patch / Photo credit: Google Maps via Daily Mail

The House Oversight Committee has directed the social media platform Reddit to retain copies of posts allegedly created by a computer specialist linked to the effort to obscure Hillary Clinton’s email correspondence. (If you are not familiar with the story, read this first) Chairman of the Oversight Committee, Utah Representative Jason Chaffetz, stated to The Hill that the request “has legal weight, and you can’t erase information and expect it to disappear.” The posts in question seem to have been authored by Paul Combetta, a technician at Platte River Networks, a Colorado-based IT firm that Clinton hired in 2013 to manage her private email server. These posts were removed on Monday, shortly after they were uncovered by online investigators and shared widely across the internet. In the posts, an account under the name “stonetear” sought advice on how to “remove” email addresses from a “high-profile individual’s” messages. “They don’t want the VIP’s email exposed, and they want to either remove or replace the email address in the to/from fields of all outgoing emails,” one post reads, dated July 24, 2014 — a key date in the Clinton email controversy. The day before, the House Select Committee on Benghazi had finalized an agreement with the State Department to obtain Clinton’s work-related emails. The FBI’s report on its investigation of Clinton’s emails noted that during that same month, Combetta transferred email backups to two of her lawyers, Cheryl Mills and Heather Samuelson. The Reddit post raises questions about potential attempts to conceal information. If “stonetear” is indeed Combetta, as many believe, this would not be the first instance of his involvement in a possible cover-up. Combetta was the technician who used BleachBit to delete backup files of Clinton’s emails in March 2015, weeks after the media exposed her email setup and after Congress had issued subpoenas for her records. He also provided false information to the FBI during an initial interview about his use of the software. Despite this, the Justice Department granted him immunity in exchange for his cooperation with the email probe. Last week, Combetta and another Platte River Networks employee, Bill Thornton, declined to appear before the House Oversight Committee, invoking their Fifth Amendment rights. “The allegations that Combetta raised about Clinton’s server on Reddit fit a pattern we’ve seen,” Chaffetz told The Hill. Police were called to a New Jersey middle school after a 12-year-old student said, "Cupcakes," while discussing lunch, his father claimed. Another student reportedly took the comment as a racial slur, according to the New York Daily News. A staff member then contacted law enforcement. “He was just talking about snacks,” said the boy’s father, Michael Thompson. “Who did he offend?” Thompson expressed concern about the school's handling of the situation. “I don’t feel safe sending my son back this fall. The staff doesn’t seem to understand what’s going on.” He added that his son felt scared when a police officer approached him with a visible weapon and asked, “What exactly did you say?” No one stood by the child during the conversation. Authorities also spoke with other parents, and the case was forwarded to the New Jersey Division of Child Protection and Permanency. Collingswood Police Chief Kevin Carey mentioned in a meeting with school leaders that they should involve police in even minor incidents, including things like name-calling or slang that might be misinterpreted. Officers were instructed to report nearly all cases to Child Protection. This marked a change from the previous Memorandum of Agreement, which limited police involvement to serious issues like drugs or assault. Since the policy shift, officers have been called to the school up to four times a day. “A lot of it is just kids being kids,” said teacher Laura Martinez. “I’ve never felt so unsure about how to handle a situation before.” The mayor, local police, and the Camden County Prosecutor’s Office held a meeting to address the growing concerns. “In our discussion today, you made it clear that the recent meeting was meant to reaffirm the Memorandum of Agreement, not to broaden its scope,” wrote Collingswood Mayor Jim Maley in a letter to the prosecutor’s office, as reported by the Collingswood Patch. Sources: New York Daily News, Collingswood Patch / Photo credit: Google Maps via Daily Mail

Washington (CNN) A daughter of Robert Kennedy, Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, revealed in a social media post that former Republican President George H.W. Bush expressed his support for — hold on — Hillary Clinton. Townsend, a Democrat who previously served as Maryland's lieutenant governor and is known online as Hartington, shared a picture with the former president on Facebook: "The President told me he's voting for Hillary!!" she wrote, noting that she is also a niece of President John F. Kennedy. A representative for Bush, Jim McGrath, refused to comment on the claim. "The former president will cast his vote privately in about 50 days, and that's all we'll say," McGrath said to CNN. "He isn't making any statements about the election until then." The conversation took place during a board meeting at the family estate in Kennebunkport, Maine, for the nonpartisan Points of Light Foundation. Some sources familiar with the exchange told CNN's Jamie Gangel that they were taken aback by Townsend's decision to share a private discussion. For more insights on the 2016 race, check out "The Daily DC" podcast. If George H.W. Bush ends up supporting Clinton, it likely won't influence his entire family. His son, Marvin Bush, has stated he plans to vote for Libertarian Gary Johnson. George P. Bush, the president's grandson, has endorsed Donald Trump. Meanwhile, Jeb Bush, who competed against Trump in the primary, has said he won't back either major candidate.

It appears the father may have made the accusation out of frustration, but there’s a strong sense that he knew more than he let on. Student groups at Western State University were reportedly pressured to alter the theme of a “Patriotic Picnic” after the administration labeled it as “too controversial.” The event was planned to be co-hosted by the College Republicans and three campus residence halls, but one hall administrator claimed that promotional materials featuring a red, white, and blue flag were considered “too political and biased.” Students at Western State University recently faced pressure to change the theme of a “Patriotic Picnic” due to concerns from the administration. According to internal communications obtained by Campus Pulse, Lisa Chen, the Assistant Residence Director of Pine Hall, sent an email on August 12 to the College Republicans and the Young Democrats inviting them to collaborate on a patriotic-themed barbecue with Pine and Jefferson Halls. The proposal included setting up booths for student organizations and promoting civic engagement, with CR Vice President Jordan Lee quickly agreeing to participate. However, on September 13, just a day before the event, Chen contacted Lee, explaining that Pine Hall would no longer support the collaboration due to the “sensitive nature” of the theme. She later stated the event would still take place, but with a revised focus. Read the full story at Campus Pulse. The opinions expressed in this article are solely those of the author and do not reflect the views of Campus Pulse. Subscribe to get the latest updates from Campus Pulse.

George H.W. Bush is now 93 years old. Do you remember him? He was the 41st President of the United States and delivered a controversial speech during the 1991 State of the Union in which he declared: “What is at stake is more than one small country; it is a big idea: a new world order, where diverse nations are drawn together in common cause to achieve the universal aspirations of mankind — peace and security, freedom and the rule of law. Such is a world worthy of our struggle and worthy of our children’s future.” Calling the U.S. a ‘small country’ was offensive enough, but suggesting that America should be used as a tool to advance global goals is even more alarming. The concept of ‘universal aspirations’ is vague at best, especially when trying to unite people from completely different cultures. I’m not a conspiracy theorist, but the term ‘New World Order’ was popularized by our 41st President, so it's worth keeping that in mind.

On Thursday, I reported that among those arrested in Minneapolis, Minnesota, 65% of the individuals involved in violence and looting were from other states. However, a recent article questions why these out-of-state participants aren’t being charged with federal offenses related to crossing state lines to engage in rioting. John McAllister, a contributor at The Conservative Chronicle, argues that the Department of Justice has shown a “lack of commitment” to enforcing laws that prevent outsiders from inciting unrest. He claims that the DOJ’s failure to act on these cases reflects a broader pattern of “non-enforcement” that has worsened over the past decade. McAllister points out that the presence of out-of-state agitators should be a red flag for federal authorities, yet no meaningful action is taken. Instead, he suggests the Justice Department has become indifferent to its duty. He writes: "Individuals posing as protesters cross state lines to spread chaos and destruction. Has anyone questioned whether the law against interstate rioting is being enforced?" According to the U.S. Code, Section 2101 outlines penalties for those who travel across state lines with the intent to incite or participate in a riot. It states that anyone who uses interstate commerce—such as phones, emails, or social media—to organize or promote rioting can face fines or imprisonment. There is a clear rationale behind such legislation, as it aims to prevent local conflicts from escalating into nationwide crises when outsiders fuel the violence. Yet, these laws are not being upheld. In 2020, similar concerns were raised about groups like the Black Bloc and other external activists who flooded the streets of Minneapolis, but federal authorities did little to enforce the law. The same statute also prohibits inciting rebellion against the U.S. government, stating that those who aid or encourage insurrection can be imprisoned for up to ten years. McAllister notes that this isn’t the first time he’s raised the issue. In 2016, he wrote about how federal officials ignored similar violations during protests in Baltimore. He concluded, “There’s a clear divide. The administration favors certain groups, while the DOJ turns a blind eye.” This selective enforcement of the law raises serious concerns. Not only does it target innocent citizens, but it also lets lawbreakers go unpunished. Perhaps it's time for the public to hold their leaders accountable and demand real justice. Social Security is often referred to as the third rail of American politics: touch it and you’re finished. And if that’s true, then Donald Trump may soon be looking for a new political strategy. According to a report by The New York Times, during a private meeting with Mitch McConnell on April 28, Trump reportedly admitted that he supports reducing Social Security benefits, but he’s hesitant to voice that opinion publicly due to fears of losing voter support in the general election. The report quotes an anonymous attendee who was present during the conversation. The source claims Trump told McConnell, “I believe in Social Security, but I also have to win. A Republican can’t beat a Democrat if they’re the one saying, ‘We’re going to cut your benefits,’ while the Democrat promises more.” This contradicts Trump’s public stance, where he has consistently claimed he will not touch Social Security. Michael Hiltzik, a policy analyst with the Center for American Progress, argues that this aligns with the broader Republican agenda: "Trump’s real goal is to slash benefits while keeping the appearance of support. He knows the public opposes cuts, so he’s willing to lie about it to get elected." In his view, the "moral" choice for Trump is to take from seniors without telling them. As seen throughout the 2016 campaign, Trump frequently changes his positions and lacks clarity on key issues. He’s not just dishonest—he’s a threat to the integrity of our democracy. The controversies surrounding the Clinton Foundation keep growing. We know that more than half of Hillary Clinton’s meetings while serving as secretary of state—specifically 85 out of 154 individuals—were with people who either contributed to her personal fund or pledged support for one of the foundation’s global initiatives. We also know the Clinton Foundation received money from questionable foreign organizations. Additionally, nearly half of the employees funded through the GSA program also had ties to the Clinton Foundation. We’re aware that Hillary’s former top aide at the State Department, Cheryl Mills, was simultaneously working for the Clinton Foundation. We know that in 2013, the foundation allocated 10 percent of its budget to charitable grants. While the foundation claims that “88% of our spending goes directly to our life-changing work,” it's hard to see how $8.5 million—used for travel, including flights and hotels—actually helps people. Even more puzzling is that $4.8 million, or 5.6 percent of the 2013 budget, went to office supplies. Paper and pens are expensive, I guess. Call it administrative costs if you want, but it's ridiculous. Dig deeper, and you’ll find even more concerning details. If you thought things couldn’t get worse, think again. In 2014, only 5.7% of the foundation’s budget was directed toward actual charitable work. The rest paid for staff salaries, travel, and other expenses. According to IRS filings, the organization spent nearly $91.3 million that year, with just $5.2 million going to charity. About $34.8 million covered employee pay and benefits, and $50.4 million was listed as "other expenses." Oh, and $851,000 was spent on professional fundraising. Fundraising isn’t cheap. Hillary understands that well. The Clintons are incredibly generous, donating over $1 million to charity last year! Who cares if part of that went into their private fund? They're so kind-hearted. Just kidding. Even Vice President Joe Biden has refused to call the Clinton Foundation ethical. h/t Daily Caller

Another day, another coded message from Donald Trump that veils racial bias under the guise of concern. As tensions flare in a major city, Trump—attempting to project authority—shifted blame for the unrest to drug use, offering no evidence to support his claim. During a speech in Cleveland, he stated, “You might not know, but drugs are a huge part of what’s going on right now.” While Trump claims to be informed, the reality is that the unrest stems from long-standing racial inequalities and the tragic deaths of unarmed Black individuals at the hands of police. His remarks reinforce harmful stereotypes that paint Black communities as inherently linked to crime and drug use. The truth is that white individuals use and sell drugs at higher rates than Black people, yet they face far less legal consequences. This disparity is well-documented: studies show that white youth are more likely to engage in hard drug use than their Black counterparts. Instead of perpetuating these myths, Trump should look at the opioid crisis sweeping through rural white communities, where addiction is reaching epidemic levels with little national attention. If he truly wants to address the root causes of unrest, he should focus on real solutions—not just racist rhetoric. The question remains: would his administration do anything meaningful to stop the violence against Black Americans, or would it continue to ignore the facts and amplify division? With the upcoming election, Trump may soon find out how his words are being received by Black voters across the country.

While presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton remain closely matched in national polls, the Republican nominee has consistently outperformed his opponent in terms of crowd size and enthusiasm. On Monday, Trump filled an arena in Naples, Florida, with approximately 7,500 attendees inside and many more gathered outside, even amid a stifling 92-degree temperature, as reported by the Naples Daily News. Meanwhile, just hours later, Clinton’s speech at a community center in Philadelphia drew fewer than 150 people, according to a report from The Philadelphia Inquirer. The event was intended to connect with younger voters, a crucial demographic for Clinton’s campaign, but the turnout fell far short of expectations. Photos from the gathering showed few young people in attendance, and those who did show up appeared disengaged. Conservative commentator Eric Bolling shared a social media post that captured the mood of the Clinton event:  

"So this is what it's like at a Hillary Clinton 'rally'... #SheNeedsYou #ImWithHer"  

A photo posted by Eric Bolling (@ericbolling) on September 19, 2016 at 10:30 AM EDT  

It was unclear whether the lone young attendee or the empty seats were the most striking aspect of the event. Trump has frequently highlighted the contrast between his energetic rallies and Clinton’s smaller, less enthusiastic crowds. “When Hillary comes in, she doesn’t bring the numbers,” he remarked during a recent appearance. In contrast, Trump’s events have drawn massive crowds across the country, signaling strong support heading into the general election. For example, on September 10, a Trump rally in Daytona Beach attracted over 10,000 people, according to WFTV. The Naples event, with its 7,500 attendees, further underscored the gap between the two campaigns, especially when compared to Clinton’s recent rally in Miami, which drew only around 1,200 people, as noted by the Miami Herald.

An independent examiner has concluded that Jamal Carter, a 14-year-old African-American boy who was fatally shot by police in Detroit, MI last Tuesday, was “more likely than not” fleeing from officers at the time of the shooting. This finding appears to challenge the official police account, which claims that Carter was shot during a confrontation after he "drew a realistic-looking airsoft gun on officers." The incident occurred at 8:15 pm last Tuesday following reports of a theft involving a group of three African-American teenagers. According to the police report, "officers pursued the individuals into an alley and attempted to detain them when one suspect pulled a weapon from his waistband. An officer fired multiple shots, striking the suspect." While the Detroit medical examiner has completed an autopsy, the results will not be released for at least six weeks. This delay led Carter’s family to hire Dr. Lena Thompson, a forensic pathologist from the University of Illinois and a consultant with the Cook County coroner's office. In a statement released by the family's attorney, Thompson stated, “Based on the trajectory of the wounds, it is more likely than not that Jamal Carter was running away from the officers when he was shot.” Although Carter was involved in the theft, his friend Marcus Johnson, 20, who was present and later arrested, said that Carter “wanted to steal something to buy food.” Thompson’s findings support community concerns that the use of lethal force was unwarranted and that the story of Carter pointing a gun at officers may have been fabricated. Johnson’s earlier account also contradicted the official version, stating, “The cops told us to get down, and we did, but Jamal got up and ran. Then the cop shot him.” It's important to remember that stealing a few dollars doesn't justify taking a life in the U.S. While some may argue that Carter deserved what he got for committing a crime, it's worth noting that when white youths are convicted of serious offenses, like assault or sexual misconduct, they often receive lighter sentences or probation. But when Black youth are involved, they’re frequently labeled as dangerous and met with lethal force. The Carter case is part of a disturbing trend of deadly encounters between young Black men and law enforcement, often involving BB guns or replica weapons. Given how common such weapons are among white Americans, the assumption by police that any object resembling a firearm in the hands of a Black teen is a deadly threat is deeply flawed. The

What would you do if you found yourself trapped in a crowd of furious people blocking your path? You slow down, hoping they’ll step aside, but instead, they push forward, clearly intent on stopping you. Recalling the events of a recent protest, you realize you're faced with a tough choice: accelerate and risk harming someone, or stay still and risk being attacked. From what I've seen, when your life is on the line, self-preservation is the only option. It seems I'm not alone in that belief. An incident recently occurred at a university where protesters had taken over a main road. A lone driver, clearly in a hurry, decided to drive through the crowd, knocking over a few demonstrators. Watch the video below to see what happened.  

Some claim the protest was about a recent shooting, but that's not what this was about. The real issue was the offensive graffiti — including the word "KKK" and "Leave N*****s" — that had been painted on the school’s wall. The message was quickly removed, and the school issued an apology, but it was too late. The Black Lives Matter group was furious. Let’s be clear: it's better to face legal consequences for hitting a protester than to risk your life or lose your belongings to a group that believes they have the right to take from you based on something someone else said or did. The saying “Better to be judged by 12 than carried by six” isn’t just about protecting your home — it applies to protecting yourself, too. When surrounded by an angry, irrational crowd that wants violence, there’s no good reason to stop. What would you do in that situation? Would you keep going, or would you let them take control?

A journalist from *The Intercept* was detained last week while attempting to obtain a press credential from the Trump campaign. Donald Trump has repeatedly criticized *New York Times* reporter David Plotz on social media for unfavorable coverage — a pattern that has become increasingly common during his presidential bid. He has banned numerous journalists from his events, with some forced to leave his rallies under the protection of Secret Service agents. Trump has also called for relaxing libel laws, which could make it harder for reporters to publish critical stories. He previously filed a lawsuit against websites that reported his wife was linked to a scandal involving a Slovenian escort. On Monday, Trump made a statement about the media that many consider one of his most controversial yet. During an appearance on *Fox & Friends*, he discussed the recent terror attacks in New York and New Jersey. After falsely blaming refugees, the hosts noted that extremist ideas can spread online without needing a physical presence in conflict zones. Trump then shifted his focus to the freedom of the press, claiming, “They’re all talking about it so nicely because it’s called ‘freedom of the press,’ where you buy magazines and they tell you how to build these bombs.” He quickly contradicted himself, saying he supports free speech but also accusing the media of “inciting violence.” “They tell you how to make bombs. We should arrest the people who do that because they’re committing a crime. Instead, they say, ‘Oh no, you can’t do anything, that’s freedom of expression.’” He also suggested that internet content should be more tightly controlled, comparing it to China’s approach: “These websites are the same thing — those people should be arrested. They’re encouraging violence, okay? They’re enabling it. They should be arrested immediately… but we don’t want to touch them because of free speech.” While incitement isn’t protected under the First Amendment, proving intent is difficult. If the standards change, Trump himself could face legal consequences for encouraging violence at his rallies or suggesting that “Second Amendment people” might target opponents. His growing hostility toward the media raises serious concerns. Using these attacks to undermine constitutional rights echoes the fear-driven tactics of the Bush administration, which led to significant erosion of civil liberties. Trump’s actions suggest a clear path toward weakening the First Amendment. Free press and expression are fundamental to democracy; without them, the media becomes a tool of the powerful. Only someone with something to hide would fear the truth. Featured Image via Getty

A white man was driving through a tense protest in Seattle when he got surrounded by a crowd of demonstrators. The bystander who filmed the event expected the worst, thinking the man might be in danger. But instead of attacking, the group simply let him pass. That’s strange, especially considering how often we’ve seen similar situations where people are robbed or harassed. So why did they let him go? Because he was waving something out his window — something that clearly caught their attention.  

As the crowd closed in, he calmly rolled down his window and showed them a firearm. Without hesitation, they backed off and allowed him to drive away. While being white in a hostile crowd usually puts you at risk, this man had prepared for the worst. His quick thinking saved him from a potentially dangerous situation. Should he have just tried to drive through? Or was showing his gun the smarter move?

According to this, the Texas state legislature is facing criticism for drafting laws that unintentionally criminalize everyday parental actions. For example, a recent law makes it illegal for any adult to touch a child’s genital area, which means that parents who change diapers or help their children bathe could now be considered criminals. This is the result of legislation that bans "intentional or knowing" contact with the genitals of anyone under 18. While the goal is to protect children from abuse, the language is so vague that it has created a dangerous legal gray area for ordinary parents. The Texas Supreme Court responded by saying that prosecutors are unlikely to charge parents for innocent behavior, but they also ruled that defendants must prove they had no sexual intent. That’s a heavy burden to place on parents who are just doing their job. The court’s logic ignores the reality of plea bargaining, as most cases never go to trial. Now, prosecutors can use the threat of a child molestation charge to pressure parents into accepting deals for unrelated offenses. As legal experts warn, this sets a dangerous precedent, turning child protection laws into tools for coercion. With the state’s highest court backing this approach, many Texans are now at risk of being unfairly targeted. Unless the U.S. Supreme Court steps in, constitutional protections are being undermined, and parents are left in a legal limbo. It's a troubling situation, and one that raises serious questions about how laws are written and enforced. Trusting the system may seem like the only option, but this case shows why that trust is increasingly hard to come by.

Washington (BBC) After 25 years in public life, Joe Biden finally struck the right balance on gender that has often been a challenge for him throughout his political journey during the debate at St. John's University on Wednesday night. Showcased confidence, mastery of policy, and the ability to counter his opponent — all while appearing (just) approachable enough. The showdown with Donald Trump could have marked another milestone for men in politics. But Biden didn’t bring up the issue of masculinity. There was no self-praising reference to being the first male nominee of a major party to stand before as many as 90 million viewers. He wore navy, a calm color, but with a tailored fit that felt neither stiff nor overly casual. He was composed and focused; subtly referencing his grandson early on, but then quickly moving on. He didn’t lecture. He smiled (often) — even as Trump tried to dominate the conversation. Before Wednesday’s debate, the focus was on which version of Trump would show up — the controlled candidate or the fiery figure from the primaries. But it was Biden who delivered the more compelling performance — taking control of the stage, outmaneuvering Trump on key issues, and drawing him into unnecessary tangents about his business dealings and tax history. Trump complained about the debate format. In a clever tactical move, Biden held back until the end to deliver his most pointed attack by highlighting Trump’s past remarks about women "as pigs, slobs and dogs" and his comments on 1996 Miss Universe Alicia Machado. Trump shook his head, asking where she got the information (it's on record), but seemed unable to respond effectively. Instead, he shifted to talking about Rosie O'Donnell, the harshness of Biden’s ads, and the idea that he had planned to bring up Biden’s family history — but decided against it. “I said to myself, 'I can't do it. I just can't do it,'” Trump admitted. “And then the debate was over.” A key goal for Biden in the coming weeks is to energize male voters, especially moderate Democrats and undecided men who are concerned about Trump’s rhetoric. His team clearly felt his subtle approach — challenging Trump without seeming defensive — worked well on Wednesday. Biden’s campaign manager, Jen O'Malley Dillon, told reporters before heading to Virginia that Trump's "constant interruptions probably reminded many men of how they feel about bullies in their lives." Social Security is often referred to as the third rail of American politics: touch it and you're finished. If that's true, then Donald Trump may soon be looking for a new political strategy—or a new funeral home. According to a report from *The New York Times*, during a private meeting with Mitch McConnell on April 28, Trump reportedly admitted to supporting cuts to Social Security but claimed he wouldn’t make it public due to the political risk. A source who was present told the paper that Trump said, “I believe in Social Security, but I also have to win. A Republican can't beat a Democrat if they’re the one saying, ‘We’re going to slash your benefits,’ while the Democrat promises more.” This contradicts Trump’s repeated public statements that he would protect the program. 

Linda Smith, a policy analyst with the Center for Budget Policy Priorities, argues that Trump’s real goal aligns with many Republicans: "They want to reduce benefits but keep the appearance of support. It's all about appealing to donors while avoiding backlash." She added, "Trump knows the public opposes cuts, so he's willing to lie about his position to get elected." 

As seen throughout the 2016 campaign, Trump has shown a pattern of shifting positions, making contradictory claims, and avoiding clear answers on key issues. The man is not only untrustworthy, but also a threat to the stability of our democratic institutions. The individual in question is Michael T. Flynn, a former military general who now serves as a Washington-based consultant with a focus on defense and energy issues. Flynn’s firm, Flynn Associates, has close ties to Russian business interests and is located near Trump Tower in New York. He was initially introduced by Trump as part of his “foreign policy team,” which includes a mix of retired generals, pro-Israel lobbyists, and individuals with strong ties to the Middle East. Flynn has since become one of the most visible voices on foreign policy within the campaign, though the Trump team insists he is not officially part of the official staff. Flynn has long-standing financial connections to Russia, including investments in major energy firms like Gazprom and Rosneft, and has made multiple trips to Moscow over the years to meet with top Russian officials. A U.S. diplomat based in Moscow described him as “a vocal supporter of Russian actions, even when they contradict American interests.” Recently, Flynn came under increased scrutiny after a trip to Moscow in December, where he met with Sergei Ivanov, a longtime Putin ally and former Prime Minister who is currently sanctioned by the U.S. According to several U.S. officials in the region, Flynn discussed with Ivanov ways to ease the sanctions, an issue that aligns with both his personal and professional interests. Earlier this year, Flynn told a media outlet that “the sanctions have hurt many of my clients and partners” and expressed hope that “there could be a more constructive approach going forward.” During the same trip, Flynn also reportedly met with Alexander Belov, a high-ranking Kremlin official believed to have played a role in coordinating Russian interference in the 2016 election. The initial probe into Flynn began as part of the broader congressional inquiry into Russian cyberattacks on Democratic Party systems and voter databases across the country. ABC News is launching its popular livestream series “Strait Talk with Matt & LZ” at Wayne State University on Tuesday, October 4 at 8 p.m. ET, featuring a live audience for a deep dive into the most pressing issues shaping the nation during this election season. ABC News political analysts Matthew Dowd and LZ Granderson, both born and raised in Detroit, will be joined by Digital Host Amna Nawaz and Chief Political Correspondent Jonathan Karl as they engage with local business leaders and community advocates on topics ranging from politics and race to law enforcement, faith, and economic development. Dowd and Granderson shared their enthusiasm for returning to their roots and emphasized the importance of addressing these critical conversations.  

"Topics like gentrification often don't make headlines but are deeply impactful," Dowd said. "From Chicago to San Francisco, lower-income residents are being displaced by rising costs and urban redevelopment. While Detroit is making progress, there's a growing concern about what the city will look like once the current wave of investment subsides. Just look at Brooklyn—once vibrant with culture, now largely unrecognizable. Detroit risks following a similar path, and that’s a conversation we can’t ignore."  

Granderson added, "Detroit is more than just a city—it's a microcosm of America. It started as a frontier town, grew through industrial might, and became the heart of the American middle class. But it also faced decline due to factory losses and broken systems. Now, it's being rebuilt through innovation and new voices, which is happening across the country."  

"The country is at a crossroads," Dowd continued. "Our institutions are changing rapidly, and there's real fear that our democracy may not hold. With two major party leaders struggling with public trust, the upcoming election is more than just a vote—it's a test of our ability to move forward together."  

Granderson noted, "Michigan is a key state, and Detroit plays a crucial role in understanding the urban-rural divide. Cities like Detroit, Miami, and Chicago represent different parts of the same country. Candidates are trying to win over these diverse groups, and that division is shaping the entire campaign."  

He also highlighted, "Detroit, a city with a majority Black population, recently elected a white mayor for the first time in decades. That shows how voters are willing to break from tradition when they feel change is necessary."

Over the past year, growing attention has been drawn to the widespread ethical concerns surrounding the Clinton Foundation during Hillary Clinton’s tenure as Secretary of State. Now, a fresh investigation claims that the foundation may be facing even greater challenges than previously disclosed. According to a report by The Daily Caller, the Clinton Health Access Initiative (CHAI) allegedly supplied weakened HIV/AIDS medications to patients in several African nations. As reported by The Daily Caller News Foundation, a draft congressional document suggests that former President Bill Clinton and CHAI may have distributed diluted antiretroviral drugs to sub-Saharan African communities, potentially increasing the risk of illness and death. — The CHAI program, which aims to support AIDS patients, is one of the Clinton Foundation’s most recognized efforts. — If true, the claim that CHAI provided compromised medications could seriously damage the reputation of the Clinton charity and add fuel to ongoing criticism during Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign. — The report also points to troubling connections between Bill Clinton and two Indian-American figures who have faced regulatory actions from the FDA and the SEC. In particular, the Clinton Foundation has been criticized for strongly endorsing Ranbaxy, despite repeated evidence of subpar quality control and attempts to conceal these issues through misleading reports to the FDA. It remains uncertain how many patients were affected by the diluted drugs. This new development raises serious questions about the Clinton Foundation’s operations and calls for immediate accountability. Should the Clinton Foundation be shut down to prevent further harm? Scroll down for video It's often joked that behind every liberal lies a conservative who was once robbed, and perhaps Black Lives Matter activist Jerry Ford Jr. will now be added to that list. The incident occurred on the campus of the University of Houston when Ford, a graduate student and leader of the Houston chapter of "Black Lives Matter," was robbed at gunpoint as he approached his apartment. He claims he noticed a young man hanging around near his building but didn’t think much of it until he unlocked his door. At that moment, the suspect pulled out a handgun and demanded his wallet and phone, which Ford handed over without resistance. 

Interestingly, Ford is currently running for Texas State Representative while also being a vocal advocate for defunding police programs nationwide. His response to the robbery, however, was anything but consistent. He called for increased police presence on campus, saying, “I hope they [the police] take a stronger stance and add more security because there are a lot of people walking back and forth to class.” He pointed out that since the housing is off-campus, it isn't covered by university police, something he wants changed for student safety.

Yet, despite being a victim of crime, Ford made comments that seemed out of place, stating, “I would’ve given him money. I would’ve talked to him because the real problem is why is he in that situation where he feels he has to come to a college campus and rob people?” Of course. What a brilliant solution.
