Germany's chancellor, Angela Merkel, has long been a strong advocate for accepting large numbers of Syrian refugees, pushing for an open-door policy that led to a massive influx of migrants into the country. This decision quickly spiraled into chaos, with a sharp rise in crime across German cities, including numerous cases of sexual assault and other violent acts reported over the past year. Faced with growing public anger, the German electorate delivered a major blow to Merkel’s conservative Christian Democratic Union, voting them out in a significant electoral defeat. In response, Merkel took to the stage to distance herself from her previous stance, admitting that the refugee crisis could have been managed better and expressing regret over what she called a “failed experiment” in multiculturalism.  

According to the Daily Mail, during a party conference, Merkel repeated her famous slogan, “We can do this,” but now hinted that Germany’s ability to handle migration depends on regaining control over the flow of newcomers. “Continuing the current pace of arrivals would eventually overwhelm our society, even in a country as strong as Germany,” she said. The former “Iron Chancellor” received loud applause after shifting her position, though she refused to commit to setting a specific cap on immigration. “We want to and will significantly reduce the number of refugees,” she stated, promising a strategy that involves strengthening border controls, supporting Turkey in hosting displaced people, and working with EU partners to share the responsibility.  

Merkel defended her controversial decision to allow mass migration, calling it a “moral obligation.” She urged the party to draw strength from its historical resilience, comparing the current crisis to the post-war reconstruction that built Germany’s economic success. She also highlighted measures already taken, such as expediting the deportation of those who don’t qualify for asylum. Despite her efforts to remain optimistic, painting Germany as a “country that is open, curious, and tolerant,” many believe her reversal comes too late. As the U.S. election approaches, the same pattern repeats—Hillary Clinton remains committed to increasing immigration, and without decisive action, the consequences could be dire. It’s time to stand up and vote wisely in November. (Source: Daily Mail)

(FOX News) FOX News announced on Tuesday a cross-country journey through critical battleground states, presidential debate venues, and iconic locations across the nation with the #VoteVoice bus and digital storytelling tour, in collaboration with Twitter, TikTok and Microsoft. #VoteVoice kicked off near the Capitol Building at the National Archives in Washington, where the bus featured the first of a series of campaign snapshots submitted by the Twitter community through an interactive, cutting-edge augmented reality display. The public will have the chance to view these images at each debate site and additional spots yet to be revealed as the tour progresses. FOX reporters Sarah Lin and Michael Torres will join the #VoteVoice bus, report from the field and engage with voters to highlight the stories and sentiments of everyday Americans. Their goal is to go beyond the headlines and political rhetoric to understand the true mood of the country. At each tour stop, locals are encouraged to step into the #VoteVoice bus and take a photo against a red, blue or neutral background filter. They can then post the image on Twitter using the #VoteVoice tag. FOX will compile the data gathered during the tour and integrate it into their election coverage. The #VoteVoice bus will act as FOX's Twitter Live center and social media base during the road trip and at each presidential debate location in Pennsylvania, Arizona, Michigan and North Carolina.

It almost breaks my heart to admit it, but Israel may be the only country in the world led by someone with real backbone. Don’t get me wrong — Benjamin Netanyahu is one of my top leaders of all time. I just wish more leaders had his courage, integrity, and vision. Instead, we’re stuck with a President who seems more concerned with casual attire than serious governance. Today, Bibi addressed the United Nations General Assembly, an environment that’s not exactly welcoming to Israeli officials. After all, the UN often puts representatives from nations that don’t recognize Israel’s right to exist in powerful roles. But here's the thing — when you're speaking to people who despise you, you might as well say what needs to be said. And that's exactly what Bibi did today. Here's a clip of his speech — Here’s more of his speech — Focusing on technology, security, and innovation, Netanyahu acknowledged that the UN has earned every criticism it's received, but he insisted that Israel’s advancements could help reshape its diplomatic future. Shortly after warning diplomats that their stance on Israel would soon change, Netanyahu openly referred to Arab nations as “partners in security and stability.” “For the first time in my life, many regional countries now see Israel not as an enemy, but as an ally,” he said. “Our shared threats are Iran and extremism, and our shared goals are peace and progress.” “I hope that in the future, we can work together openly,” he added, bringing regional cooperation into the light. In his speech, delivered just hours after meeting with U.S. President Barack Obama at the General Assembly, Netanyahu emphasized the “unshakable relationship” between the two nations. “Our bond with the U.S. goes beyond politics,” he said. “It reflects the deep support for Israel among the American public, which is at an all-time high, and for which we are deeply grateful.” The fact is, women and minorities in Israel enjoy more rights than anywhere else in the Middle East, which really irks regimes like Saudi Arabia and Iran. They use the UN to target Israel for giving its people freedom, rather than forcing them into religious oppression. But just for fun — compare what women in Israel can achieve (something Netanyahu highlighted in his speech) to what women in Saudi Arabia face. It’s not even close. If I had to leave America and choose between Israel or another Middle Eastern country, I’d pick Israel without hesitation.

Podcast Pulse is a fresh show from CNN featuring two conservative journalists who engage with key figures to explore the direction of conservatism and the Republican Party. (CNN) According to Amy Walter, national editor at the Cook Political Report, this election cycle's undecided voters are notably more informed than in previous years — they know the major candidates and still aren’t satisfied. "Usually, undecided voters haven't been paying much attention," Walter told hosts of CNN's Podcast Pulse, Jason Riley and Mary Katherine Ham, during a recent interview. Walter, who also worked for former Democratic Rep. Marjorie Margolies Mezvinsky, compared these voters to students avoiding a cold pool. GOP strategist: Trump can't 'sustain his energy for 90 minutes' "These undecided voters are fully aware of their options, but they're reluctant to commit, just like when you were in school and had to jump into the cold pool during P.E. class," she said. "They don’t want to make a choice, not because they’re uninformed, but because they’re stuck between two unappealing options." Walter noted that for the first time in her career, she’s finding it hard to rely on campaign data, as undecided voters are caught in what feels like an impossible decision. Voters call this the most difficult 'lesser of two evils' race "I’ve heard people say, 'I don’t trust Hillary Clinton on foreign policy,' she explained. 'But I’m scared Donald Trump might start a war.' So, they’re saying, 'I’d rather avoid this whole election than be forced to pick between these two.'" Walter, who previously worked at CNN, highlighted how the growing divide between different voter groups — especially between white voters and those with college degrees — isn’t solely due to Donald Trump. "This is a long-term trend," she said. "You can’t blame it all on one candidate who gave a powerful speech. It’s been building for a while." To learn more about Walter's journey in politics and other insights, tune into CNN's "Podcast Pulse," a new series where two conservative CNN voices discuss the future of conservative thought and the Republican Party. Find "Podcast Pulse" on CNN, Stitcher, TuneInRadio, or iTunes.

WASHINGTON — As public polls show a narrowing gap between the two presidential candidates, Democratic strategist Robby Mook recently sent out a confidential message to key donors and volunteers outlining the various routes Hillary Clinton could take to secure the White House in November. The memo, which was shared with *The New York Times*, highlights Clinton’s strong position in several “blue” states and contrasts it with the limited options available to Donald Trump.

“While Hillary Clinton has multiple paths to 270 electoral votes, Trump only has a few viable routes,” Mook writes in the detailed 1,800-word document. “She is almost certain to win 16 states, including Washington D.C., which would give her 191 electoral votes. Adding the five states where she has a 70% or higher chance of victory—Michigan, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Wisconsin—she would only need 10 more electoral votes to clinch the election.”

Mook then outlines the possible ways Clinton can reach that number, including winning Florida (29), North Carolina (15), or Ohio (18), or capturing any two of Colorado, New Hampshire, Iowa, or Nevada. “In other words, if she wins just one of those top battlegrounds—Florida, Ohio, or North Carolina—she’ll already have the presidency,” he explains. “Trump, however, needs to win at least six of these seven states, including Florida, North Carolina, and Ohio—none of which he can afford to lose.”

This analysis aligns with broader Democratic strategy, though it contradicts some of Trump’s team’s assessments, particularly regarding Pennsylvania. Clinton’s campaign has long emphasized that the state is critical to their plan, and without it, Trump’s chances are slim.

Titled “45 Days Until Election Day,” the memo serves as both a reassurance and a call to action. With Clinton’s lead in the national average shrinking from 7.6 points in August to just 0.8 points, the message aims to quell concerns among supporters while urging them to stay engaged in the final stretch. It also reinforces Clinton’s policy positions and includes some sharp criticisms of Trump, such as a quote from GOP leader Paul Ryan, who previously called Trump’s remarks about a Mexican-American judge “racist.”

While the memo stays largely in line with Clinton’s public messaging, it takes a stronger negative tone toward Trump at a time when the campaign is trying to shift
